name: Der Präsident. –
text: I declare the session suspended on Thursday 10 September 2015 to be resumed.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: We now come to the order of business.

name: Manfred Weber (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report and for the Europe is the place where we fight for human rights and democracy, and I would like to address, on behalf of my group, an incident in South America today, namely in Venezuela. A few days ago, the leader of the opposition, Leopoldo Lopez, was imprisoned and imprisoned there. This is a massive crime against democracy in Venezuela. We would simply like to address this today and to point out that these incidents are taking place there, and we would ask you, Mr President, to also protest from the European Parliament so that we can report back that this is not in the spirit of democracy.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you very much, Mr Weber. Mr Weber, I was a guest of Mr Lopez's wife. I have received her, I have also expressed the solidarity of the House with her imprisoned husband and will also inform the Venezuelan authorities of the protest. Ladies and gentlemen! I have received a request from the Commission following on from the final draft agenda adopted by the Conference of Presidents in accordance with Rule 149 of the Rules of Procedure on 10 September. In his State of the Union address, the President of the Commission announced that proposals would be made on the migration issue, including a proposal for a Council decision to introduce provisional measures in the field of international protection in favour of Italy, Greece and Hungary. I have now received the relevant commission's draft from the Council. The proposal will be officially forwarded to the LIBE Committee. I have received a request from the Council to deal with the matter as soon as possible. In agreement with the President of the Commission and after consulting the Conference of Presidents and the Chairman of the LIBE Committee, I propose that this Commission proposal be dealt with as a matter of urgency under Article 154. Ladies and gentlemen, the refugee crisis that we are experiencing certainly makes it necessary to find an immediate solution at Union level. I think it fully justifies the use of the urgent procedure. I believe that the institutions of the European Union should already make their own, that they should show the citizens who are concerned that we are acting. I would therefore be grateful if you could agree to the motion and my proposal to take a decision under Rule 154 as a matter of urgency.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: Chair of the Committee on Civil liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. – Mr President, I am rising under this urgent procedure in accordance with Rule 154 and also, as you said, in my capacity as Chair of the Committee on Civil liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE). It is very rare for Parliament to use this procedure on such an important matter, which needs proper consideration in the House, and the first point I want to make to colleagues who have not read this, or who will read it soon, is that we are not giving up our legislative prerogatives for the future on such important matters. I know the President agrees with this.  But following the Council meeting of Monday and the lack of consensus and urgency in reaching majority agreement on an organised and compassionate response to the refugee crisis here in the European Union, it is necessary that we respond and that we have our view and that people see Parliament doing its job. In particular, the failure to reach an agreement on the 120 000 relocation mechanism to assist with the refugee crisis in Italy, Greece and Hungary will be seen to be one of the major omissions of the Council conclusions of Monday.  It is clearly vital that Parliament speak on this issue directly and immediately. We can do this by agreeing now to approve this urgent procedure and we will do so tomorrow in our vote – I hope – by majority, in expressing European solidarity on the refugee crisis, which, I believe, the majority in this House want to see. I urge you to vote for this urgent procedure. (Applause)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you, Mr Moraes, for your support. In accordance with our rules of procedure, I can now give the floor to a Member who wishes to speak in favour of this motion and the proposal by myself and Mr Moraes.

name: Manfred Weber (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the You have discussed the procedure with the group leaders, and I would like to express my support for this once again, also on behalf of the group chairmen. I believe that the concerns of the citizens, which you have also expressed, clearly demonstrate that we must act. The European Parliament proved last week that, with the support of the Commission's proposals, we are part of the solution. We are ready to act, and we hope that the Member States will also be prepared to act at the end of the day. And this signal that we are ready to act can be underlined by this procedure – hence our full support.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Does anyone wish to speak against the motion?

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the This is not a matter of urgency, but is being rushed here. Parliament must also be able to deal with the proposal in its committee, to discuss it, to formulate amendments and to vote on it. It is not possible for this to be nodded off. The situation in Europe is complicated. I would just like to refer to the situation in my own country. Germany currently receives about 43% of all asylum applications in the European Union. According to the Commission's proposal, Germany would actually account for only about 22%. It would certainly be inappropriate to redistribute 120,000 refugees now, with further admissions for Germany. That is why this should at least be able to be discussed and discussed in detail in the European Parliament.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: On the question of deliberation in the Committee on Home Affairs and the amendments you would like and the deadlines for doing so, I shall come back in a matter of time. I will inform you about this again, because you are mistaken. We shall now proceed to the vote on my proposal to proceed with Article 154 as a matter of urgency. Anyone who agrees with my request asks for a show of hands. Who is against it? Who abstains? That is accepted. I also propose that the part-session be extended until Thursday morning, so that a vote can be scheduled at 11 a.m. The only item on the agenda for tomorrow would be this vote on the Commission's proposal. Does anyone want to speak in favour of the proposal to extend the agenda so that we extend the plenary session until tomorrow? Does anyone want to speak out against it?

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I just wanted to make an absolutely important clarification about this debate and this vote; But tomorrow, at the same time, the TAXE Committee will have another important hearing. Thank you.

name: Alain Lamassoure (PPE)
text: Chairman of the Special Committee on Tax Rulings and other similar measures by their nature or by their effect. Mr President, what Mr Zanni has just said is correct. We have scheduled a joint hearing with the ECON Committee - President Gualtieri is here - and the TAXE Committee on the mandate of the TAXE Committee, that is, the taxation of multinationals, in the presence of the President of the European Commission and Commissioner Moscovici. The pre-summer emergencies, which were already immigration and then Greece, led us to postpone this hearing twice. This one is due to take place tomorrow. I trust you, Mr President, and the Bureau, to ensure that the decision that will now be taken of a vote at 11 o'clock is perfectly compatible with the possibility for our two committees to audition, for the expected period of one and a half hours, President Juncker and Mr Moscovici. I believe that, for reasons of protocol and courtesy, it is your role and I fully trust you.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr Lamassoure, thank you very much. I would like to make the following proposal to you: if we want to meet all the deadlines, we can also bring forward the deadlines for amendments and the translation deadlines, which are to be voted on at 10 a.m. Since the committee is meeting in the Chamber and the vote does not take longer than 10 minutes, I would recommend that we take the vote at 10 a.m. Then we will be ready quickly, and you will only have to switch to the other side and listen to Mr Juncker. I would then suggest that we extend the agenda until 10 a.m. on Thursday and hold the vote at 10 a.m. Then we will not come into conflict with the TAXE Committee. (Parliament adopted the proposal, the deadline for tabling amendments to the Commission's proposal: today, 6 p.m. Deadline for submission of applications for separate, separate and roll-call votes: today, 9 p.m.)

name: Miloslav Ransdorf (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, As a Member of the European Parliament, I think that you should explain to all of us, as we sit here, your scandalous and totally unacceptable statements about the fact that you want to force the Community through power. What does it mean to force Europe through the Community with power? Explain it to us.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr Ransdorf, you must have been wrong. I have never used such a phrase, and I would not use it. But you may have heard them when you gave your press conference in Crimea. (Laughter)

name: Miloslav Ransdorf (GUE/NGL).
text: – That you want to promote this Europe, the spirit of the Community by force: "Mit der Macht durchsetzen." That's what you said, so you're not lying here.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr Ransdorf, you are welcome to read the text. They are very powerful in the German language. Read it through, then you will see that you are wrong.

name: n/a
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking We all know exactly what the Lord said. These were words that should not fall, expressing disrespect for the Member States and the anti-democratic method of making political decisions. We would like to draw your attention to the fact that such statements are not only contrary to European culture, but also contrary to the mission of the President of the European Parliament, who should uphold the rights of minorities and respect all citizens and all Member States. Man makes mistakes from time to time and this is a great opportunity to apologize for this behavior.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: You are wrong, sir, just like Mr Ransdorf. I promoted the Community method in an interview and said that I believe that the crises in the European Union can only be resolved on the basis of the Community spirit. I have said that sometimes you have to fight powerfully for this community spirit. It's not that I've humiliated any country. I'm sticking to that. (Applause)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Justice and Home Affairs Council conclusions of 14 September 2015 (2015/2849(RSP)). I warmly welcome the President-in-Office of the European Council, Mr Jean Asselborn, Foreign Minister of Luxembourg!

name: Jean Asselborn
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your invitation. As you know, in the face of the deterioration of the refugee crisis in Europe during the summer months, the Luxembourg Presidency convened a special session of the Justice and Home Affairs Council on 14 September. The scale of the challenge we face requires a common European response. The short-term humanitarian situation and the need for a coherent and comprehensive EU migration policy must be addressed both in the short term. The package of measures presented to you on 9 September by President Juncker forms the basis of our immediate work. At Monday's Council meeting, ministers took note of the detailed information provided by UN High Commissioner for Refugees Antonio Guterres and William Lacy Swing, Director-General of the International Organization for Migration, on global trends in migration flows and refugees. Both speakers stressed their willingness to work with the European Union and provide it with the assistance and technical expertise needed to deal with the current crisis.  We took a decisive step on Monday with the final decision, after Parliament's opinion, on refugees arriving in Greece and Italy who clearly need international protection. From tomorrow, we can start relocating these 40,000 people and, at the same time, hotspots must be set up in Italy and Greece. Preparations are underway in many Member States. The Presidency also reached conclusions following the in-depth discussions we had on Monday on immediate actions and on the continuation of work in preparation for the Justice and Home Affairs Council meeting on 8 and 9 October. As a large majority of Member States have agreed to move forward on relocation, the Council will already meet on Tuesday 22 September to discuss the relocation of 120,000 people. Negotiations on relocation will not be easy in the Council.  Given the urgency of the situation and as announced in Parliament's consultation letter, I would like to take this opportunity to inform you that there will be a significant change from the original proposal. Hungary does not consider itself a front-line country and has informed us that it does not wish to be a beneficiary of the relocation.  Parliament will be able to take this into account in its opinion.  The Council will also begin work tomorrow on the permanent relocation mechanism and the European list of safe countries of origin.  I would like to review before you the main elements of his conclusions. The first element is our support for the UN High Commissioner for Refugees and in particular his humanitarian support. In particular, we welcomed Norway's proposal to hold an international donor conference and to help Syrians displaced by the war. We reiterated the importance of effective border control, enabling better management of migration flows.  We have agreed to deploy what are called RABIT, the rapid response teams, to the field.  We need to respond positively by sending human resources and equipment to the field as soon as we receive requests to do so. This is a European way that we already have; implement it where it is needed. Greece's request for support to the EU to better manage the massive influx is particularly important. We are referring to the new proposals in the immigration package presented by the Commission on 9 September and, moreover, we are ready to do everything possible to start considering these proposals as soon as possible. I am sure the European Parliament shares this determination. Your resolution on migration and refugees in Europe, adopted on 10 September, testifies to this. The policy of return and readmission is of prime importance and will be discussed in depth at the Justice and Home Affairs Council on 8-9 October, which will also look at strengthening Frontex's role in this area. At the international level, it is imperative to strengthen cooperation with third countries of origin and transit. The Valletta Summit, the conference on the migration challenges posed by the Western Balkans route and the pilot project in Niger are concrete initiatives that must continue to move quickly to achieve the desired results. In addition, we stressed that Turkey is a key partner with which we must strengthen our cooperation. Finally, the measures I have just listed must, of course, be accompanied by a large and appropriate budget and substantial human resources. Thank you, Mr. President.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, those of you who know Game of Thrones will know the expression ‘winter is coming’. It is meant quite literally and it is meant metaphorically. This expression can be applied to the situation the European Union is in now vis-à-vis the refugees. Winter is coming, quite literally. But winter might also be coming metaphorically for the European Union if we are incapable of action in the next couple of days and weeks. (Applause)  This issue, left unresolved, will undoubtedly lead to human suffering for the refugees, to political turmoil in our Member States, to strife between Member States and to tensions which Europe cannot afford to have. So we have a strong, strong responsibility – Parliament, Council and Commission – to make sure that what we did not achieve last Monday in the Council will be achieved without delay. Yes, a lot has been achieved so far. Yes, it is difficult to have far-reaching results within five days of the Commission making proposals, but we have no time to lose.  I want to salute this Parliament and its President for your courageous steps forward, in line with the Commission proposals. I want to express my gratitude to the President of Parliament for having organised a vote, which will send a clear signal to all Member States and all capitals that the Parliament that represents the peoples of Europe wants action – and it wants it now – and so does the Commission.  I want to add one more point, which to me is very important. The Commission is willing to build bridges between the different positions of Member States. We cannot afford the luxury of finger-pointing. We cannot afford the luxury of accusing one another of not wanting to reach a solution. There is no time for that. We have to have the skill, the openness and the willingness to build bridges to help countries come to a common solution which will express solidarity and responsibility.  My plea is also to all of you to please explain to your constituents, and to your people back home, that our proposals are not just about a distribution key to express solidarity with those states who are really suffering today. They are also about the European Union being able to better guard its external borders, the European Union being able to offer more support to those states which bear the brunt of this crisis – states like Jordan, Lebanon and Turkey – which deserve far more support from the European Union. The European Union is also about offering the perspective of a sustainable migration policy and refugee policy. We can deal with this if we are united, but we will fail if we are – and continue to be – divided.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, this debate is important. It is not just one more debate on reporting back from the Council: it is mostly about sending a strong political message ahead of the Council meeting on 22 September. You, Members of Parliament, have stressed that more action at European level is needed. This action is needed now, and the Council next week is the opportunity to make an important step forward all together. I therefore join my voice to what Frans Timmermans said before: I urge you to send the message of political urgency outside of this Chamber to your governments, to the media and to the European citizens. The debate on the refugee crisis is often linked to fake dangers and fears. This is something that we – all politicians – need to address.  Let me start from where we stand. The European Union’s agenda on migration represents a comprehensive approach which equally responds to all the issues of the migratory challenge, because, as we have stressed many times, solidarity goes hand-in-hand with responsibility. Safeguarding our citizens’ freedom of movement also requires ensuring their security by protecting our external borders. At the same time, we need to fulfil our humanitarian obligations and respect international law when it comes to asylum seekers. We also need to be pragmatic and accept that we have to respond together, united, to this crisis.  The second implementing package that we presented to you last week serves this goal: to respond to the emergency situation in our borders by enhancing both the responsibility and the solidarity aspects. This House warmly supported this package in its resolution last week. In the Council on Monday we made some progress as well. On most of the proposals there is broad consensus, there is no doubt about it. Member States are clearly in favour of returning persons who do not have the right to stay on our territory. The European Union’s action plan on return outlines the short and mid-term measures to be taken to enhance the effectiveness of the EU return system. The EU list of safe countries will alleviate the pressure on Member States’ national asylum systems. The Commission proposals in this respect were welcome and will be further discussed. We will also send more support to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees for Iraq, Jordan, Lebanon and Turkey to provide better conditions for the refugees.  The High Representative/Vice-President Mogherini attended the Council meeting this morning, showing that internal and external policies go hand in hand. Also, when it comes to the protection of our borders, all Member States agreed to use existing tools like the RABITs (Rapid Border Intervention Teams) mentioned before, as well as to enhance them by strengthening the mandate of Frontex.  The first hotspots are being set up and will become operational shortly. It is important to ensure that the most affected Member States will have our full support to register, fingerprint and manage the arrivals of thousands of persons every day.  On relocation, the Commission welcomes the decision to relocate 40 000 persons in clear need of international protection that was adopted on Monday and can now be implemented. I can assure you that we will work closely and with all Member States to have swift results. Hot spots will be bases to make this approach a success. The first relocation will start immediately, but for our proposal to relocate 120 000 additional persons from Italy, Greece and Hungary, we do not have the agreement we wanted. There was a willingness of the majority of Member States, but not all, to move forward towards an agreement on relocating another 120 000 persons.  I would like to thank the Luxembourg Presidency for their hard work to find a compromise. As you know, there will be another extraordinary Council meeting already next week. We cannot fail on this. It will be a crucial meeting and the Commission is ready to provide full support to enable decisions on the files. The objective of the Commission is to preserve the unity of Europe. We are in contact with all Member States and we are ready to work with them over the coming days so that all Member States will go the extra mile to find a European solution.  I would like to underline that the European Parliament is participating fully in this process for the framework, for the crisis and location mechanism, as well as for the list of safe countries of origin. You will be co-legislators. For the emergency relocation mechanism, your positive opinion sends a strong political signal, the same strong political signal that you sent today ahead of the extraordinary Justice and Home Affairs Council by deciding to adopt the opinion on the relocation of 120 000 persons in fast-track procedures. To finish, I will not hide from you that I felt disappointed and frustrated on Monday evening, even though progress was made. It was not enough: it is nothing compared to the magnitude of the crisis. It is nothing compared to the moral obligation of Europe to stand up to its values and to respond to this historical call to show solidarity towards people who are fleeing war and persecution. These people will not be stopped by any cold sea, any fence, any army. They will just risk and find ways to cross borders in order to find a safe shelter for them and their children. What I want to say is that the migratory pressure will not just go away if we pretend to ignore it. Our neighbourhood is on fire. This concerns us all. The only pragmatic and humanitarian response is an ambitious European one and a comprehensive one. There is no single solution to this crisis. We need to address all issues, to fight the root causes, to support and cooperate with the neighbouring countries, to better protect our borders, to fight smugglers with all the means we have, to increase the reception capacities in the countries most affected and to ensure solidarity when it comes to finding for them a safe refuge. It is time for each and every one to take their responsibilities. As I said yesterday – and I will repeat it on every occasion – if we fail, it will not be the institutions that fail: it will be Europe that will be failing, and we should not allow this to happen.

name: Esteban González Pons
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, there are at least 120 000 people in Europe suffering and waiting for us to stop talking and start acting. There are at least 120,000 people in Europe suffering and waiting for us to answer this question: do we really want to welcome those who are escaping the war in Syria? There are at least 120,000 people in Europe waiting for the Commission's proposal to be approved or rejected by this Parliament. And there are no extremist responses, which are cruel and also useless, of the type "no one must enter" or the type "we have to let everyone in". We support the Commission's proposal for four reasons: first, because it is a realistic proposal; secondly, because it is a proposal that guarantees the dignity and humanity of the treatment that those fleeing the War in Syria receive; thirdly, because it is a proposal that allows solidarity between all the Member States of the Union; and finally, because it is a proposal that helps us to continue to build Europe, to continue to build the world in which we believe. This is not a problem for today. As Mr Timmermans said, winter is coming, the worst is coming, there are more wars, there is more hunger, there are more diseases, there are more countries than Syria. We are facing the problem of the next twenty years. We need a comprehensive strategy, a common strategy of all countries and a cross-cutting strategy of all political parties, which contemplates the dignity of people, whether European or not, all dignity; to contemplate solidarity between countries; to look at security at external borders and to see that we want to combat war, disease and hunger, not people. Ladies and gentlemen, every time a wall is rebuilt in Europe, our ideals are beaten. The construction of Europe is to destroy the walls in Europe.

name: Gianni Pittella
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have just one word on behalf of the Group of the European People's Party (S&D) and I would like to say one word to the Council: we must move forward, forward without fear. This is the message that my group intends to send to the Council after monday's meeting revealed a large majority on the package presented by the European Commission. Now it's time to move on.  President Schulz was right to convene this plenary as an emergency, because that is what we are demonstrating, we are ready. The European Parliament is ready. Let the Council also be ready in the next few days to approve the measures that await the citizens of Europe, which are solidarity measures, but they are also security measures for our citizens!  Because we are thinking of the relocation of refugees, but we are also thinking of the defence of the external borders, we are also thinking of the creation of a permanent compulsory system for a common asylum policy in the European Union. Let us also think of a foreign policy which will stabilise the Mediterranean. Let us also consider helping in the work of repatriation. We also think about organizing hot spots.  So there is not only solidarity, but there is also responsibility and therefore a balanced position that should be supported by all the Member States. I continue to appeal to all The Member States, including those who are most recalcitrant: let us not delude anyone that through barbed wire, through walls, we can face such a great and important challenge.  We have been with some socialist and democratic colleagues on the Serbian-Hungarian border and seeing the barbed wire and seeing the refugee camps we have experienced great bitterness and great pain. We want Europe to redeem this image, to share this image and to rediscover itself. Europe to come back and make Europe again! Europe to become an agent of solidarity again! Europe to become an example again in the world for human rights! Europe that once again becomes a great gentle power and a great civil power! We know that the challenge is not easy, but those who give up without a fight do not even deserve to be a protagonist. We Socialists and Democrats will be at the forefront of this battle for civilisation.

name: Timothy Kirkhope
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the EU is made up of 28 countries, not just one or two. EU actions and decisions should therefore be taken in a spirit of consultation, not unilaterally declared by one or two leaders who then expect everyone else to follow. Those Member States who believe there is more than one solution are currently accused of being less European than others. It is simply not fair. By imposing emergency relocation schemes on countries that are – for many reasons – opposed, we are storing up trouble for any future proposals which offer the best long-term solutions. As First Vice-President Timmermans just said, no finger-pointing, but the reprimands and the ad hoc and rash decision-making that we are seeing are causing us to lose focus on strengthening our cooperation and vital actions to tackle the roots of the crisis.  Much of the Commission’s proposal is correct: improving reception centres, speeding up processing and returns, tackling human trafficking, and looking at how Europe can be a force for good in assisting those countries where 97% of the refugees are located. Countries that disagree or cannot accept a quota system should be asked what other contributions they could make to help lessen the pressure.  But I believe that resettling the most vulnerable refugees straight from the camps in their home regions is the most responsible thing all the Member States can do. So when the Council meets next week I hope we will see less finger-pointing and more of a willingness to act together in the long-term interests of all European countries, and, especially those who are truly eligible for refugee status.

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President,  we have to tell the truth to the public: the meeting of the ministers of the interior was a failure. We did not reach an agreement even though, in my opinion, it is in fact a topic that could be decided with a qualified majority, and I am very doubtful that on 22 September we are going to get a deal.  In my opinion, it is an issue that has to be tackled at the level of Heads of State or Government and no longer on the level of ministers of the interior alone. It is not an interior security issue alone. It is a refugee crisis – the biggest that we have ever faced – and I think it is for the prime ministers and heads of state to take the responsibility to come together and elaborate a comprehensive approach for this problem.  In that respect, we are now stuck in a debate between Visegrád prime ministers, who refuse common responsibility, and mostly Western politicians and prime ministers. We have to come out of this debate, and the only way to come out of this debate is not only to talk about this shared responsibility – that is one of the elements, and we are going to vote on this with Parliament – but it is to have a broad approach. We also have to tackle the other issues, such as that there is no economic migration policy in the European Union, and so economic migrants are abusing it because of the lack of a European Union economic migration policy. There is no common border agency. Frontex is not a common border agency, it is our people that we take from a number of Member States for Member States – Italy, Greece and so on – and they are doing the job, while it should be a mandatory system in which all 28 Member States participate. There is also, at the same time – let us be honest – no common policy to be engaged to try to tackle the sources of this refugee crisis, to be engaged to stop the Syrian war, to be engaged with more money to tackle the problems in different parts of Africa.  I think you can organise whatever meetings you want on 14 and 22 September, and then maybe a week later on 3 October, but I think it is time that the Heads of State or Government under the leadership of Mr Tusk and Mr Bettel, as the Prime Minister of Luxembourg, start with a real summit to tackle the whole issue and to have a comprehensive approach. Only then, Mr Asselborn, will you have a chance to convince the Visegrád countries: when they see it is part of a global approach, and not starting by saying that they have to take 20 000 or 25 000, and that is all. In my opinion, that may not be the right tactical move.  Finally, there are two urgent problems we have to face. The first is the funding of the different UN camps in Jordan, Lebanon and Turkey. They have no money for the moment: they have to reduce the allowance from USD 30 to USD 13, so there is going to be a huge flow to Europe again. My appeal to the Commission is that they fund the United Nations immediately, on an urgent basis, within the possibilities inside the budget, and that they hand over the money that is necessary in the coming days so that we can find a way to improve the conditions of these refugees in Lebanon and in Jordan, because there cannot be a new flow.  Finally, Marielle de Sarnez and Natalie Griesbeck, two of our colleagues, went to the Hungarian border, and I can confirm what Mr Pittella said: that what is happening there is a shame. It is shameful that it is happening in the European Union. The Commission also has a task and a control function on that, and you have to act on Hungary.

name: Barbara Spinelli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Council conclusions are indecent: 85% of refugees live in poor countries and the Member States decide to relocate only 32 000 by the year 17. A majority accepts the Commission's proposal to distribute one hundred and twenty thousand from Italy, Greece and Hungary, but is blocked by some states. Relocation is approved only in principle, it is neither binding nor permanent.  This Europe is talking about values, forgetting that asylum and European solidarity are rights and laws, not values. The only things he can decide are walls, military interventions in Libya that will increase refugees, fights against smugglers that exist because there are no legal escape routes and lists of safe countries to send refugees back, at the risk of discriminating against them according to the nations and violating international law.

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the current situation and the challenge posed by refugees from war and persecution are causing strong and contrasting emotions in our societies.  Yes, like all of you, I see, I hear fears. I hear and see the manifestations of fear, rejection and even hatred. My concern is when these reactions open the doors of the chanceries. When heads of state or government, instead of peddling the challenge we face, feed and flatter these fears. That is what leads to the blockage. It is this which has made finding a consensus solution in the Council so difficult. But what I also see in our societies is the manifestation of an outpouring of solidarity in a series of Member States: citizens who spontaneously help and welcome these refugees from war and persecution.  I would like to invite not only all of us but also the Heads of State or Government to draw on these reactions in order to find a common solution in Europe. Yes, this solution must include all the measures proposed by the Commission. It must certainly include a permanent distribution key. Finally, it must put an end to this Dublin system, which is ultimately the organisation of anti-solidarity in Europe. It must, in fact, - as Guy Verhofstadt has said - create legal paths to the European Union. This is the best way to put an end to the smugglers' business.  But I would like to call on the Commission to be as enthusiastic or even bold on the front of solidarity and social justice within the European Union, as when it is responding today to the challenge of migration. The two are linked because I understand the concerns of our fellow citizens about the additional burden that the reception of refugees will place, in the short term, on our social protection systems. Systems that themselves are under unprecedented strain due to rising unemployment, inequality, exclusion and poverty.  So I say one thing to you, Mr Timmermans, and pass the message to Mr Juncker: when the European social lift starts to rise again, it will be all the easier for our citizens and our societies to board those in need.

name: Laura Ferrara
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that yesterday the meeting between the interior ministers of the 28 Member States wrote one of the most shameful pages in the history of the European Union. We heard from Juncker last week in Strasbourg that the European Union lacks the Eu ropean Union and lacks Europe. Well, we add that there is also a lack of will to have union and Europe, or this will is probably found for other interests, such as economic interests.  Well, we are endeavouring, as a 5-star movement, to ensure that an alternative is possible, to ensure that there is another Europe, but unfortunately the facts force us to think that this conviction must become a utopia, a broken dream, an illusion. Well, do we often hear ourselves wondering what Europe is doing? So let us give this Europe a first and last name.  We are facing a humanitarian crisis and what are we doing? Germany suspends Schengen and reintroduces internal border controls, Hungary builds barbed-wire walls on the border with Serbia, Romania, Poland, the Czech Republic and Slovakia are opposed to the relocation of the 40 thousand migrants, which was already a derisory figure in itself and reduced the number to 32 250, and the United Kingdom has availed itself of the opt-aut clause and will not participate in the decision.  Well in conclusion, no to compulsion, no quotas, no to the relocation of asylum seekers from April, but since August 2015. So, since yesterday, since the last landings, no to 40 000 but to 32 000 asylum seekers to be relocated.  It's a disgrace! Each Member State must take responsibility for the decisions it takes. The European Commission must ensure that these countries are penalised and fined, otherwise, if we continue to move forward with the principle of the mors tua vita mea, this European Union is forced to implod in the short term, thank you.

name: Marine Le Pen
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, at the end of August, Angela Merkel opened Germany's borders widely to migrants and said she wanted to take in 800,000. Fifteen days later, the German Chancellor was up against the wall of reality, and she was forced to make an impressive head,-at-the-tail, suspending Schengen and sending police to her borders to stop the influx of illegal immigrants she had unleashed. Gentlemen Europeanists, you have unleashed a phenomenon of air calling that you do not control and which will overwhelm us! You will take responsibility for that in the face of history. This madness must stop immediately, with a firm and clear Australian-like policy, so that the flow dries up, while there is still time, and that chaos ceases! When you are wrong, you try to prevent me from speaking, but believe me, the peoples of Europe hear me! On Monday, the emergency meeting of interior ministers on the EU migration crisis led to a total disagreement between those who want to impose migrant quotas and those who refuse. Immediately, Germany, through its minister of the interior, threatened financial sanctions leaving the recalcitrants. This blackmail is absolutely indecent. It is now President Schulz, Socialist President, who is making an undemocratic and unbearable coup d'état, with the complicity of the PES and the EPP, by imposing an emergency vote. But France - because it is the one that interests me, sorry - has very big problems of assimilation, but also 7 million unemployed, 10 million poor, 1.5 million households waiting for social housing. She can't take in anyone anymore. It is therefore absolutely necessary to definitively stop the Schengen system, to let each country control its borders and each people to make its choices freely. Before you, Europe was peace! Today, it is the war of influence, the economic war, the antagonisms and the conflicts between European countries. Great success, indeed!

name: Presidente. –
text: I just want to inform the House that the decision to vote on this matter is linked to the procedure: the Council needed a vote of opinion from Parliament. So it's not a whim of political families or the president to open a debate, but it's compliance with the rules.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: – Interior ministers met to find a solution to the migrant crisis. It's not going to work. They're like the doctor who only prescribed more and more fever and painkillers to the worsening patient. There's no proper diagnosis. It is not that more refugees are arriving than in recent years. It's a migration of people, with chaotic scenes, sometimes we might even call it an invasion. Yes, there is a need for solidarity, there is a need for empathy for the fallen, but as a Hungarian Member, I must show solidarity with the Hungarian population. For those who believe that their aim is to keep Europe the europeans and Hungary to the Hungarians. To this end, a real, appropriate solution must be found, the first step of which is to close the EU's borders.

name: Eλισσάβετ Βόζεμπεργκ (PPE).
text: Madam President, 500,000 people have crossed into Europe this year and we learn that 2.5 million are waiting off the coast of Turkey to cross into Europe. We strongly support the Commission's proposal. The decision to relocate 120,000 refugees with a fair distribution to the Member States is imperative. But we believe that the mechanism must be permanent and binding. We all have a responsibility, a great responsibility on an equal footing, without exception. Unity, solidarity, justice, seriousness and conscience must inspire our decisions when it comes to protecting human rights. We're not dealing with numbers, we're dealing with the souls of desperate people who demand a decent living. In any case, we are all jointly responsible and the Member States that separate their position do not realise that the European Union is horizontally inspired by the same principles and that is why there should be compliance. Since we are talking about people, we must all be equally responsible to them: responsibility cannot be shared "but cart".

name: Birgit Sippel (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which It was not so long ago that an Iron Curtain fell in Europe and walls were torn down. It is shameful that we are witnessing new walls being raised these days. Europe must now prove itself, as a Union of common values and as a Union with shared responsibility and solidarity. The Member States must act now. We need greater support for the UNHCR, and we also need more effective development cooperation. Above all, however, we finally need shared responsibility for refugees in Europe. resettlement and resettlement, respect for the individual right to asylum, the implementation of asylum directives and, above all, support for all states that need financial or organisational support. The Council has a chance to send out a first positive signal next week. Finally tackle it!

name: Helga Stevens (ECR).
text: – Measures to combat the migration crisis should aim at protecting external borders, allow EU Member States to pursue a firm activation policy, and distribute the burden evenly across all countries. The borders of our continent are too porous. The Dutch government, of which the Socialists are part, recently came up with an interesting proposal, based on the Australian model: systematic return to safe countries, combined with a system of resettlement. An EU member state can then work with the UN refugee agency UNHCR to remove people from foreign camps. This gives everyone the opportunity to be helped, including people with disabilities and the poor. People smugglers and IS make no more money, no more deaths at sea.

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, my question to the Presidency is very simple: why do you allow an extremist group of minority Member States to block a proposal necessary to ease the pain and suffering of 120 000 persons? You should have voted and got a qualified majority on this. That would have been deliverance. Secondly, my message to you is equally simple: the EU does not at this point need unanimity. We need unity today in the European Union. We need action: we do not need any more ‘blah, blah, blah’. We need concrete action. There are people out there suffering in hundreds of thousands on our continent. We cannot support this anymore: it is now high time for the third of the three institutions to deliver.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, in the humanitarian crisis of the refugee wave a humanitarian European solution is needed. As a European citizen, I am ashamed of the failure of the Council of Ministers and I stress that it is time for the leaders, the Heads of State, to stop hiding behind their Ministers or we will hear fascist cries in here, like Mrs Le Pen's, trying to win votes on human lives, at a time when the Aegean and the Mediterranean are becoming a graveyard for thousands of young children and their families. It is unacceptable and inhumane for Europe to be absent, to postpone, to annul the Schengen Treaty, to erect walls because few governments on the right and the extreme right block the necessary decision. The European Parliament must take the lead now in order to find a solution or tomorrow it will be too late. My country, Greece, cannot stand all this pressure alone.  (Applause)

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF).
text: Madam President, under the internal regulations, I do not have to be called a fascist in this Chamber, especially not by someone who comes from a political movement that has 100 million deaths on its conscience.

name: President. –
text: I was trying to establish that the time for a personal statement or response is at the end of a debate, but you have made your response so I now move on to our next speaker. (Interjection from Mr Papadimoulis) I am sorry, Mr Papadimoulis.  (Heated exchange on the floor) Colleagues, can I just ask for some order please. We are debating a very sensitive subject. Clearly there are huge divisions in this House. You have used an expression in your speech. Ms Le Pen has responded. I would ask you to wait until the end of the debate if there are colleagues who wish to make a personal statement under Rule 164.  (Interjections from the floor) I fully respect your need for…  (in response to interjections: Colleagues, I am trying to keep order on a very lengthy and important debate) … but will you be repeating what you have just said? Then I feel I am giving you extra time.  (Mr Papadimoulis: ‘Twenty seconds’) The problem with giving you 20 seconds – and I will refer to the services – is that I then have to give another 20 seconds and then I give you 20 seconds… (Interjections) Please, I would ask you to respect the Chair. If you wish to come in at the end of the debate, then there is a possibility.  (Applause and further interjections) I thank you for your respect, colleagues, and I ask that you now allow the next speaker to speak for one minute. Ms Keller, please. (Continued interjections, some of them vociferous) … at the end of the debate. (Mr Papadimoulis: ‘Now!) Please, colleagues, I have got to ask for order in the House. With respect, this is a very sensitive debate. We are going to have these interruptions. I am being as fair as I possibly can to everybody. I would ask you to allow the speaker to speak. Please let the House settle. . (Interjection from Mr Papadimoulis: ‘We have spent more than one minute’) We have spent more than one minute. Mr Papadimoulis, thank you for this comment. I now ask Mrs Keller to take the floor for one minute.

name: Ska Keller (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I think we all agree that racism has no place in Europe. As a German, let me say that the work and the hard fight of those who resisted the Nazi regime deserve all our honour. (Applause) The Council meeting on Monday was a disgrace, I am afraid to say. It was certainly not the fault of the Presidency or a lack of work on their part. On Monday it was national egoisms that won out. European solidarity and the refugees themselves were on the losing side – people who are fleeing from war and terrorism who are currently being turned away at our borders. This is unacceptable if we want to uphold the Europe of freedom, solidarity and human rights. The Council needs to act now because what is at stake is our own credibility. It is our human rights, it is Europe and our idea of humanism and humanity.

name: Diane James (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, as a British MEP, I – also on behalf of my country – take real exception to the insults being flung in Parliament this afternoon and also to being told what to do with reference to this migrant crisis – not a refugee crisis. Not only is Germany the source of the problem, with its Siren-call to anyone and everyone coming to Europe, but now Germany seeks to offload the consequences of such an ill—judged, illiterate and incoherent policy by forcing Member States to take migrants, bear the costs involved and, fundamentally, dig Germany out of a self-created financial, social, humanitarian and political debacle. Not content with inflicting the migrant chaos on its own – in some cases, beleaguered – citizens, Germany is using bully-boy tactics to force this crisis on to its neighbours.  German domination might well mean that when Ms Merkel says jump, we all ask ‘How high?’, but I – on behalf of the United Kingdom and Britain – do not agree. Note that Germany has already made veiled threats about cutting finance to EU countries which have rejected these demands. It is threatening financial penalties on countries that will not cooperate and it has seemingly endorsed a EUR 780 million budget. Well, quite frankly, this is a serious matter and it is one for sovereign national parliament decision, not the Mickey-Mouse decisions in this Chamber.

name: Vicky Maeijer (ENF).
text: – The European Union, with Germany first, has called for an asylum tsunami over us. And now there is panic because a complete population movement has started and hundreds of thousands will follow, on their way to a free home and free care. But despite this asylum tsunami, despite the thousands of terrorists being let in, the European Union is sticking to its open borders fiction. As more and more people turn against mass immigration, Brussels is dictating that more asylum seekers should be taken in. First 40 000, then 120 000, and in view of the migration you have called on us, another 500 000 will be. Because that is democracy in Brussels: doing the opposite of what people want at home. It's time to start serving your own citizens instead of the boatloads of illegal fortune-seekers. Close the borders and send all asylum seekers back to where they came from.

name: Udo Voigt (NI).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioners, you are talking about a strong political message – where has this strong political message gone? They now want to resettle people against their will. First there were 40 000, now there are 120 000, tomorrow there will perhaps be half a million. One message would be to act now and finally close the bottle again. Mrs Merkel has pulled the cork out of the bottle, and you no longer know how to stop it. They are now only in the process of acting on the symptoms, but they are not fighting the causes in any way.  It would be right to suspend Schengen, to close the borders so as not to give millions of people hope for a better life in Europe, which we cannot guarantee them. Use the money you spend per asylum seeker, per migrant in Germany and Europe in your home countries so that you can give them a perspective there!

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE).
text: – I huwa l-ebda sigriet li jien ukoll kont diżappuntata bil-Kunsill tal-Ġustizzja u tal-Intern. Id-dinja kollha kienet qed tħares lejn l-Unjoni Ewropea imma fallejna. Lanqas l-istandards tagħna stess ma stajna nilħqu. Minflok smajna l-istess argument u l-istess skużi ripetuti minn xi Stati li jippretendu li jistgħu jeżoneraw ruħhom mir-responsabilità. Ejjew i ninsewx il-punt kritiku f'dan kollu; eluf ta' persuni, familji, tfal qegħdin jaħarbu minn orrur indeskrivibbli biex ifittxu l-kenn. L-Ewropa li naf jien i kinitx se tagħlaq il-bibien. Dan mhuwiex żmien biex jinbnew il-ħitan. Dan huwa żmien biex nuru b'mod konkret il-valuri li fuqhom inbniet l-Ewropa. Minflok ma nħallu l-kriżi tesponi l-fraġilitajiet tal-Unjoni tagħna, u anki thedded il-kredibilità taż-Żona Schengen, għandna nuru lid-dinja dak li aħna kapaħi nagħmlu. L-Ewropa għandha sservi ta' eżempju għall-bqija tad-dinja għaliex, iva, "we are in this together". Il-minister li se jerġgħu jiltaqgħu l-ġimgħa d-dieħla għandhom fuq spallejhom responsabilità storika. Jistgħu jagħmlu aħjar u għandhom jagħmlu aħjar. L-Unjon tagħna tiddependi fuq dan.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D).
text: Madam President, failure, fiasco, setbacks... there is no shortage of terms to comment on Monday's Council. Expectations were high for this meeting. It didn't work out. So it is the next one, the one on September 22, that may offer us a last-chance solution.  But I do not want to comment on the comments on a meeting because what is really at stake is whether the European Union can pass its crash test or whether it is on the verge of a sudden stop. This is a real hypothesis in the context of the current humanitarian crisis. Fractures are growing in Europe, misunderstandings are getting worse, decisions are becoming less common and increasingly one-sided. Too many Member States are turning away from the common asylum policy, when it exists and can be exercised, while deploring the lack of a common migration policy. It's totally incoherent. Meanwhile, displaced persons are on European territory and the protection system is not expressed with sufficient scale and speed. Two final points: we need to talk, at the international level, with the stakeholders involved. Federica Mogherini is convinced, and so are others. We have to help them. We have to anticipate before we even agree, if we can do it.  Member States must ensure that refugees have dignified and controlled conditions for reception and integration.

name: Jussi Halla-aho (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the Commission and Parliament are trying to resolve the migrant crisis by dividing migrants coming to Europe more evenly among the Member States. This approach is wrong because it attracts more and more people across the Mediterranean. Although the sea journey is dangerous, it is attractive because Europe cannot effectively return even living standards immigrants. What is the significance of the fact that we will be splitting 120 000 asylum seekers if the same number come to Germany alone every month. Nor is opening up legal routes a solution, because Europe cannot afford the millions of people who want to come here, socially or economically. Migratory pressure is not a temporary phenomenon. International migration and asylum shopping are also destroying the Schengen area. If we do not have the political courage to protect our common external borders, the Member States will, one after another, start closing their own national borders, as we have seen.

name: Alexander Graf Lambsdorff (ALDE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for The meeting of the interior ministers has failed abruptly. I think it is quite honest and good that the Commission, Mr Avramopoulos, is saying this so clearly. I also think it is good, Mr Asselborn, that you are not trying to gloss over things here. We know you as a passionate European. I can imagine how you felt. This was not just any meeting. This was a meeting that was about achieving something concrete for people in existential need. This is where the institutions have failed. It is the Council that has failed here. The Member States , as Mr Verhofstadt has just pointed out to the dispute – have not been able to reach agreement. This distribution key is necessary. It is not a panacea, but it is necessary to strengthen the sense of solidarity, of fairness in the European Union. And if you cannot agree on a binding key, why not form an avant-garde, why not Sweden, Italy, Luxembourg, Germany? Why not do what you did with Schengen, what you did with the euro? Why aren't some countries ahead? Others can then join later. I would also like to say one thing: we need legal channels of immigration. Finally, let me say one thing: for all the strife among democrats, please do not leave our Europe to the cronies of Madame Le Pen and her fellow intellectuals!

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the humanitarian crisis at Europe’s borders is mainly of Europe’s making. Obscene and needless military intervention in the Middle East and North Africa have ignited conflicts in the region, displacing millions. Whilst the vast majority of these people seek refuge in neighbouring nations, some seek to join their families and relocate to Europe. The failure of the Council meeting on migration to provide safe and legal access for refugees fleeing the harrowing impacts of conflicts is absolutely shameful. We need to ensure that all countries do their fair share in resolving this crisis. Ireland, as a nation, can accept thousands of refugees. We must ensure that these people become part of the fabric of our society and are not discarded in direct provision sites. We must activate the Temporary Protection Directive, enhance the Syria Vulnerable Persons Relocation Scheme, and suspend the Dublin Regulation, which forces refugees and asylum seekers to register in the country they land in.  The European focus on keeping them out rather than keeping them safe has resulted in in the drowning of thousands of people in the Mediterranean. This crisis is Europe’s sinking shame, and the so-called leaders of the EU Council on migration should hang their heads in shame.

name: Judith Sargentini (Verts/ALE).
text: – People are smarter than fences. Member States that think we can keep refugees out with barbed wire and border guards do not understand that a human being in need is a survivor. Fences, laws and paper barriers lead to degrading conditions on our borders and I think Hungary is the worst example at the moment. We expect the Council to act accordingly. This Parliament will once again show today, and tomorrow in the vote, that we want Member States to show solidarity with each other and with refugees. We expect action from the Council. We also expect the Council to keep its own colleagues on their toes. So: you behave or actions follow. I think it is now time for Member States to say to each other: Hungary, Viktor Orban, what you do, that has consequences.

name: Kristina Winberg (EFDD).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The EU has completely lost control of illegal migration. In order to show her solidarity with the refugees now coming to Europe, Mrs Merkel of Germany decided a few weeks ago that the country should abandon the Dublin Regulation and in principle open up to free immigration. Many mainstream politicians clapped their hands and praised Merkel for this decision.  After barely a week, it was time again. Merkel realized her mistake and suddenly Germany introduced border controls. However, we had time to get a glimpse of what will happen in a Europe of open borders. Migrants and refugees arrived in their thousands. Conflicts arise between different groups, and we may even see IS flags waving in our previously safe and stable Europe. Europe is now more than ever in danger of being shaken by new acts of terrorism as a result of this outrageous policy. At the same time, we are watching as people who remain in the conflict zones and in refugee camps are at risk of starvation and disease. Unhcr announced this week that they are being forced to reduce food distribution to refugees by 40%! Solidarity is helping as many people as possible.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, It seems to me that the approach so far is not entirely correct, because the things I would like to hear would also be those relating, for example, to how to deal with those situations in countries at war. No one here has uttered the magic word Islamic State, but what is happening in Syria, also because of Europe, should make us think: some action should also be taken, in Syria, in Libya. Think of Eritrea, where there has been a war for thirty years and it is hard to see why anyone has done anything so far, obviously did not care. Now it doesn't matter because nobody talks about it.  We must also be able to stop these countries at war, to ensure that there are no more refugees. After that, the thing I would also like to hear is that because there are certainly refugees fleeing war, but there are also people who take advantage of it and who maybe want to come here just to be in some social system that welcomes them quietly. Well, I would like to see, in addition to these people who do not have the rights, we should also start talking about the fact that we need to repatriate them and know by what means to repatriate them, which I unfortunately do not see and hear here. Thank you.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Firstly, we are not talking about refugees, because there are women and children among the refugees. These are just young men. Do they come to us to work? If that were the case, it would be half poverty – that would be even good. They come to us for benefits. Proof? They do not want to be in Turkey, Poland, Austria or Hungary. They go to Germany, because there the allowances are the highest. The Germans, of course, are committing madness by paying these benefits, but that is their problem, their money – they are wasting it, they are demorizing these people. But the Germans are now demanding Polish that we re-build German concentration camps in Poland and that we keep these people in Poland by force – whether we want or not we want to. They are fleeing from these camps. I am now asking Mrs Merkel: if they are fleeing, are they going to cross the Oder, or should we shoot them? What should we do to keep them in Poland afterwards? Of course, the only solution is not to abolish Schengen, but to abolish social benefits. Only the elimination of benefits will stop this wave of refugees. And the last thing. I want to talk about the terrible thing that Mr Schulz did, which he said he would force-to-force his solutions. This has caused a huge wave of nationalism across Europe! He plays for Marine Le Pen. He plays for Ms. Le Pen.  (The President received the speaker's vote.)

name: Monika Hohlmeier (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which First of all, I would like to say that Germany has made a commitment to help neighbouring countries that were completely overcrowded – including Austria and Hungary, which were no longer able to cope with the influx of refugees on their own – and has committed itself not to send the refugees back to Hungary or to Austria, because these countries alone would not have been able to cope with it. The nasty interpretations that are taking place here are simply completely out of place. The refugee problem can only be solved collectively. Mr Foreign Minister, I would like to make a big request: in the budget debate, we note that some financial officials, as well as ambassadors, still do not yet have the task of setting priorities for the field of migration, development aid, external aid, neighbourhood aid, but unfortunately the opposite. My great request would be for the Heads of Government and the Foreign Ministers, together with interior ministers and development ministers, to make it clear that the budgetary procedures must also be geared accordingly to the problems we face.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D).
text: – Madam President, a week ago, Mr Juncker said that we need more Europe in the Union and more union in Europe, and the Council has not taken this need into account. However, it is just what we need in the face of this challenge: a consistent response, a European response and a united response. Because otherwise, not only will we not solve the humanitarian crisis in the Union, but we will enter into a real crisis in the Union. And there is a majority in this Parliament ready to work with the Commission to pressure Member States on the next meeting of the interior ministers, for the next European Council, for the next African Union Summit and for the next international conference on humanitarian action. But now we need an urgent response and this is what this Parliament is debating and approving.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The asylum crisis will change Europe's foundations, apart from the real refugees. Asylum is not the answer to poverty in the world. This is what the German Minister of the Interior, Mr de Maiziére, has just said on 8 September. The German Chancellor has fuelled the already dramatic situation with her contributions in a way that will go down in history as the historic failure of a German chancellor, probably a European leader. Nor can there be any EU quotas for the distribution of refugees. Almost everyone wants to go to Germany. The real refugees and the poverty migrants, they will go, they will come. Germany cannot accept all of the world's civil war refugees. That is excluded. Those who see things differently do not have a big heart, but a small mind. The state is failing! We need to talk about replacing the state asylum law with a private one. Anyone who wants to welcome refugees should be allowed to do so and take care of them. The church is to grant church asylum. This is how welcome culture can work: private engagement. We must start rethinking the right to asylum!

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE).
text: Madam President, yes, Europe must take its full part in welcoming refugees so as not to leave the burden alone to Syria's neighbours. But this agreement must be organized. And I think we have two real emergencies in front of us. The first is to deploy reception and control centres at the union's external borders to identify and register those who arrive, to talk to them and to give them, or not, temporary admission to the European Union. The second emergency is reception capacity on the ground, particularly in transit countries. I was there a few days ago with my colleague Nathalie Griesbeck. The needs are immense: the need for hard structures, blankets, doctors, sanitary facilities, water, interpreters and lawyers. It is to these two issues - external borders and hospitality, particularly in the countries in transit - that we want, that we now demand concrete, rapid and effective answers in the hours and days ahead.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, it has taken the tragic images of children drowning in the Mediterranean to move the leaders of the Union. The Council failed to agree binding quotas for the relocation of refugees. Member States are closing borders and taking repressive measures to prevent refugees from entering. It turns out once again that the dominant circles of the Union are not cut off for human rights and for peace. On the contrary, they have serious responsibilities for the current humanitarian crisis: they support and participate in the interventions and wars that blood the people and create the massive waves of refugees. In order not to be hypocritical, the Union must reject xenophobic and racist policies. Our proposals are clear. The repressive forces must cease to be strengthened. Abolish Dublin II, support the host states, establish permanent mechanisms for the relocation of refugees and develop a common asylum system to ensure the free movement of recognised refugees throughout the Union.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, it is to be truly embarrassed. No permanent mechanism, no solidarity in relocation... I am no longer saying that you speak of the resettlement that UNHCR is asking us, nor of the legal avenues, or anything at all. The images continue today with riots chasing refugees across Europe. It's a real shame. We are concerned about the list of safe countries proposed by the Commission, because I would like to remind you that international law requires the individualised analysis of each of the requests. Discriminating on the basis of origin is from every point of view quite dubious, also from a legal point of view. You still do not say anything about those countries that are in breach of international asylum law, as is the case in Spain, which does not analyse some of the requests you receive on your own territory. Look, with the crisis in Greece, European solidarity was almost carried away— or practically carried away. Now this crisis is ahead of free movement and human rights. I, in the face of the crisis in the European Union, do not know when you intend to convene a summit, when you intend to bring us here the Dublin review, because this is really no longer a refugee crisis: it is a real crisis of the European Union.

name: President. –
text: I interrupt the speakers’ list to give the floor to Minister Asselborn, who needs to leave us now. He would like to respond to the debate.

name: Jean Asselborn
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Madam President, I have listened with great interest, a great deal of respect, sometimes a great deal of astonishment, and it has been a little comforting to see that the gap in appreciation in the European Parliament is ten times greater than in the Council. I do not agree with the results of the Justice and Home Affairs Council last Monday. That is why I have decided, on behalf of the Luxembourg Presidency, to take a new momentum. This must, in my opinion, be decisive. One MP asked why we did not vote last Monday. We could not vote because we respect the European Parliament and the treaties. To vote, you need the opinion of the European Parliament and this opinion, you will give it tomorrow, in a vote after 10 o'clock. I hope that on 22 September it will not be necessary to vote and that everything will be done - at least by the Presidency - to reach an agreement by consensus. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, respect for rights is enshrined in the charter of the European Union. Anyone who knocks on our door and is prosecuted has the right to the rules of the Geneva Convention. Despite all the problems in society, in France or elsewhere, I think that the European Union would lose all its credibility if it turned a blind eye. In the same vein, we must not criticize a country or politicians for their generosity.  I also think that the Commission - and I look at my friend Dim-tris Avram-poulos - its president and its commissioner have done a perfect job. The Commission has proposed something very palpable, I will not remind you of that. I just want us in the European Union in 2015 to show the same zeal to show our solidarity as in the Yugoslav crisis, where there was a great deal of solidarity between east and west, south and north. I would like to say that we obviously do not have the right to lose the Visegred Group states because we would then lose the historical challenge embodied by Europe. It is therefore necessary to do everything possible to change the approach of the Visegred group. The few hundred or even a few thousand refugees fleeing poverty and brutality in Syria are not elements that enter the society of these countries to break it down. That is certainly not true. It may be difficult to explain, but you have to be patient but also have a certain strength to talk to those responsible and perhaps also to the people of these countries. In any case, the Presidency will listen, work with the 28 Member States, by 22 September. Madam President, I do not entirely agree with those who believe that a European Council is the best way. I am not against a European Council. Of course, I have no right to be against it, but we must remember the month of June and we must also have in mind that, since the Lisbon Treaty, we must let the councils of ministers work. We have failed, I agree with you. On Monday, we will overcome this failure, at least in terms of the distribution of 120,000 refugees. As for the 40,000, you know we have found a solution. If we succeed, I believe that the European Council will have plenty of time to explain itself afterwards. Pressure must now be maintained on the Justice and Home Affairs Council next Tuesday. With regard to Mrs Hohlmeier's last question on the financial envelope, we will already have, through the Commission, next Tuesday, more concrete figures, whether to help Turkey or to help Greece. This is very important so that there can be reception facilities in Greece, because most of the people who are now asylum seekers in Europe, we do not know where they really come from, nor who they are; we have not received them with dignity and it has to change very quickly. That is why, after Greece's request to be helped by the Commission, EASO, UNHCR and the Member States as well, we have responded positively to this request. I think it is in the interest, not only of Greece, Dimitris Avramopoulos, but also of the whole of Europe. That is the direction in which we will really try to do everything within the framework of the Luxembourg Presidency in order to find a way out next Tuesday, at least with regard to the distribution of people proposed by the Commission and which we have a duty to deal with.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her In view of the current debate, I wonder how much chaos this European Union still wants to bring to our continent. What we are debating today has a history. People cheered here as the entire Arabian Peninsula was plunged into chaos: Mubarak in Egypt, Ben Ali in Tunisia, Gaddafi in Libya, and then Assad in Syria. We have seen here how chaos has been created throughout the Arabian Peninsula, and instead of accompanying this process as a community of states and ensuring that safe zones are created in the region and, if necessary, that first reception centres in the Arabian Peninsula are created for refugees themselves, we are now moving towards the whole of the Arabian Peninsula to bring these people to Europe. We are talking about millions of people who are to be brought to a continent with record unemployment, with record poverty, with record problems. That cannot be the solution! This creates chaos in a situation where stability is really needed. Nor do we want a quota system in Austria. We want to decide for ourselves again about our own policy in our own country. We, too, strongly reject what is being agreed here today.

name: Elmar Brok (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Nobody wants to bring them in. But if they are entitled to asylum, the right of asylum applies. The Chancellor did not make a general invitation, but gave shelter to people lying on the street on a conscious Friday. And I think that made me proud of my chancellor. Mrs von Storch, you always talk about Christianity and act unchristian. However, I do not want to go into internal issues now; Mrs Hohlmeier has already presented this. What we need to do is, in fact, to address the causes. This means that I hope that, within the framework of the United Nations, the United States and Russia will now join forces on this issue in order to bring together the polluters in this area, including those who are waging a proxy war, namely Saudi Arabia and Tehran, and also to clarify Ankara's role in this matter. Only if we isolate this ISIS/Da'esh can we succeed. This House must also think about a new Policy on Africa if we are to get this problem.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D).
text: – It was not just a disgraceful meeting of interior ministers, it is shameful what is happening in Hungary today. Closing borders, punishing are threats to all of us who believe in solidarity and humanity. We are 20 000 refugees, while more than 12 million Syrians are refugees. If our countries were immediately able to agree on burden-sharing, we would have the time and energy today to devote ourselves to implementing measures that would create stability and peace in war zones. By closing the route, refugees are looking for new opportunities. I would like to draw attention to the great danger: the minefields in Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina. I am pleased that in Slovenia more than 70% of people are opposed to the construction of a fence with Croatia, but I am concerned about the start of tightened control of Austria at the border with Slovenia and the latest announcement by the Slovenian Prime Minister of the introduction of temporary controls at the border with Hungary. The refugee crisis has become a new crisis of morality and ethics in Europe. Bad example and bad promise.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner Avramopulos said that the Commission's policy wants to be jointly and severally accountable. I understand this in this way, that solidarity is only a responsible policy and irresponsible policy is not in practice joint and several.  And it is necessary to distinguish between refugees – people who are fleeing from the risk of life, and economic emigration. Mr Brok replies that no one invited economic migrants, but I heard this in Sztrasburg from President Juncker. A wide-open door to economic immigration – this was not really responsible and the method chosen by the European Commission is also irresponsible. The European Commission should be the coordinator of the efforts of states, sovereign states. Everyone has their own experience, their own context.
