In the meantime, you want to impose mechanical solutions that will not serve this matter. The better is the enemy of the good. There is a need for moderation in this matter and the Commission should respect the Member States and reach a compromise.

name: Angelika Mlinar (ALDE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Listening to the debate in this way, I have to say that we are actually talking about the issue or that we are at least six months late. The Council, our Heads of Government and Ministers, are still discussing 32 000 or 40 000 or 120 000 refugees to be distributed, calling this an emergency measure. Apart from the fact that these ladies and gentlemen have not yet been able to reach agreement, this discussion has been overtaken by time. We have recently received similarly high numbers of people from Hungary almost every day in search of protection and help. We – that is, Austria in this case, although it must be said in a fair way that we have only moved the majority to Germany immediately. This Germany expects 800 000 refugees this year, and we are talking about a total distribution of 160 000. What should the citizens we represent think when they hear that? We need to get to reality as quickly as possible, look ahead and make real decisions. The European Parliament is ready for this. It is time for the Heads of Government to recognise the seriousness of the situation. There can only be a common solution, and no state will do so alone. Let us wake up and come together to a good solution!

name: Dennis de Jong (GUE/NGL).
text: – In the plans to deal with the refugee crisis, reception in the region always plays a crucial role. If the region can offer humane protection, that is also fine. But the UN refugee agency releases report after report showing that there is no humane reception at all. The latest report "Living in the shadows" describes the dramatic situation in Jordan. We knew all the dramas in Lebanon. UNHCR asks for 5.5 billion for 2015. So far, not even half of them have arrived. That means smaller food rations for the refugees, which means no financial support for many of the most vulnerable refugees outside the camps. If we are serious about reception in the region, it is no longer about millions but billions of euros. The same goes for resettlement. Respond to UNHCR's requests and resettle the most vulnerable refugees. I do not hear any figures, neither from the Commission nor from the European Union. We want to know how much money is available and how many places for resettlement.

name: Barbara Lochbihler (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her It has been clear for a long time, but not as clearly as it is today. The european refugee and asylum policy to date has failed. Thousands of people die at the external borders every year, the Schengen Agreement is suspended internally, and the interior ministers are awaiting later. However, there is agreement on measures that lead to further foreclosure. However, we must not respond to the failed policy of foreclosure with even more foreclosure, but rather a fundamental rethinking of refugee policy. We need more legal and safe access routes to the EU, more resettlement. We need intra-European solidarity and binding commitments on the distribution of refugees. And we need the protection of human rights as a compass at all levels, including in the name of frontex missions, and especially in cooperation with third countries, such as Eritrea or Egypt.

name: Michał Marusik (ENF).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab First of all, we must be careful that emotions do not deprive us of some elementary common sense. Let's call things by name as they are. This is not a spontaneous action, that suddenly so many people wanted to come to Europe. This is a very carefully organised process of flooding Europe with a migratory wave for a long time. Europe has been literally attacked by this migratory wave. If immigrants here were willing to be seen and expected, then the debate – this debate above all – would not be. And if it were to take place, everyone would demand that as many immigrants as possible be allocated. If it were joy and happiness for European countries, but it is neither joy nor happiness. We know that this is a tragedy, that this migratory wave is a misfortune for Europe and we are trying to defend against it. Every country has a natural right of defence. If there are now ideas that a country should be forced to accept quotas, it is just an idea of provoking conflicts within the European Union, which is completely unacceptable, because everyone has a natural right of defence and this right must be respected.

name: Mariya Gabriel (PPE).
text: Madam President, yes, it is time to stop moving the problem through space and time. Yes, it is now time to move institutional barriers, national selfishness and populist discourse. I will limit myself to three observations. Firstly, we must pay attention to the Mediterranean, but we must not lose sight of the land borders, especially those with Turkey. More sustained dialogue is needed and alternative-bilateral formats should be used. For this reason, I say "yes" to the ratification and implementation of the agreements already concluded, but I also say "yes" to innovation with partners such as the Gulf countries, the African Union and the United Nations. Second, let me be clear, now is the time for shared responsibility and for humanity. Yes, Bulgaria will not make its participation in the Schengen area a condition to participate in the relocation mechanism. But we must say that the Schengen area is our security for all of us. Let us defend our founding principles to the end. Thirdly, finally, it is high time that Member States gave greater importance to development policy. In countries of origin and transit, solutions will be brought as closely as possible to the problems.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D).
text: – The conclusions of the Council of Ministers in relation to migration have shown us, colleagues and colleagues, how little we have been able to actually do so far. Since the beginning of the year, when this exodus actually broke out on such scale as we have it, we have seen that we have limited legislation, limited powers, long-term solutions have been postponed until the situation has escalated into this form. I am therefore glad that the Council conclusions also talked about concrete solutions. About solutions to help deal not only with the refugees we currently have in the Member States of the European Union, but in general, how to look at a common European solution, because to this day, for example, we also have problems in implementing Poseidon and Triton. Finally, I would like to say how sorry I am that the most important and crucial issue in this situation has become the subject of quotas, or therefore compulsory reallocation. It is a great pity for the EU to focus on criticising states that do not agree with these issues, instead of looking for what unites us.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr Juncker's speech to Members of this House in Strasbourg last week has already been overwhelmed by reality. Schengen has been suspended several times since then, and even a planned quota system can only work with border controls. The German Chancellor has sent a fatal signal to the people who have made their way to us from the crisis regions of the world. And now it is raising its index finger moralisingly and calling on other countries in this Union to support the consequences of this decision. Mrs Merkel has said that in a few years Germany will change beyond recognition. It is intolerable that it imposes this single-handedness on our people without public debate. The fact that it expects approval of such changes from other states shows its complete loss of reality. However, we want to show a way to deal with this crisis. A European solution is desirable. However, given the large number of refugees, the solution must be found outside Europe's borders. We must make a joint effort to establish safe places and safe zones in the respective crisis areas.

name: Merja Kyllönen (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are discussing an acute crisis, but the crisis will easily become a permanent state, because climate refugees are still on their way. With our attitude and actions, we define what kind of Europe we are building. I am on the side of an open and human Europe. I do not want a Europe like that, nor my own country, Finland, which does not help those in need. If we pursue a selfish policy, what will remain of Europe and the EU? Nothing at all. Europe needs rapid decision-making – in acute need, people are not expected or allowed to die. The slowness of the authorities has triggered a wave of civil activism in which individuals and the third sector create a safety net for those in need. Europeans still have their hearts in place. While people, the third sector and businesses operate, the actions of politicians and authorities must also be taken. Human smugglers have turned this distress into a multibillion-dollar business. We must act to ensure that people receive proper help and that organised crime does not benefit from it.

name: Angelika Niebler (PPE).
text: Madam President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. I would like to make an appeal to all Member States today: finally act together – And I stress together – in order to get to grips with the refugee crisis! No Member State can cope with the refugee crisis on its own. All The Member States are called upon to do so. All I can say is that what happened on Monday in the Council of Home Affairs Ministers – I find it shameful, I find it a tragedy, I find it disappointing.  I come from Munich, ladies and gentlemen. Last weekend we saw 20 000 asylum seekers and refugees arriving in the city. The previous weekend there were also 20 000. Since 1 September, more than 75 000 people have come to our country. Two-thirds of them are now still housed in Bavaria. And I can tell you that if you then have to follow the discussion and you talk about it or you cannot even agree that 120 000 people will be distributed across 28 Member States, then that really is a great tragedy. I really ask the Member States to act. A sentence on Germany, Madam President, on Germany and the Chancellor, which have been mentioned so many times: Germany did not cause the situation in Iraq, did not cause the war in Syria, is not to blame for the situation in Afghanistan and in many Arab countries. We are trying to live up to our responsibilities, which we also have for humanitarian reasons.

name: Iliana Iotova (S&D).
text: Madam President, the Council has shown a total inability to cope with the challenge of migration flows. It has already been six months since the European Commission has been able to find the levers to get member states to implement the emergency measures it has proposed. This delay is already costing us too much.  Over the past two days, the European Union has found itself immobilized not only on its external points but also in its interior spaces. We are facing the most serious humanitarian crisis we have seen in 70 years. Last night, hundreds of migrants set out on foot from Istanbul towards the Bulgarian-Turkish border and we are just learning that Hungarians are using gas against refugees.  We want a permanent asylum mechanism that guarantees solidarity with those at risk and the safety of our citizens.  Let me tell you, Commissioner, that the relocation figures no longer matter because they are becoming less and less up-to-date as time goes by.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I support the relocation of 160 000 refugees, but this is not enough. Member States have to move from an emergency footing to a permanent crisis mechanism, and all Member States have to accept their shared responsibility. This biblical exodus is a common challenge that requires unity and a common response. There is no national solution. But it is also time for leadership in Europe. We have to move from this populist rhetoric to explanations, and mobilise our citizens to help people who are fleeing for their lives. That is what it is about.  We also have to show solidarity and help the Member States who cannot cope. I understand that some Member States, more than others, see this as difficult and new. We have the European Asylum Support Office, Frontex, the ‘hotspots’ and the Refugee Fund; let us use them to support Member States under pressure. We should welcome anybody who seeks asylum in Europe with humanity, but we cannot allow them all to stay. Border controls have to be installed on all the external borders of the European Union and refugees should be registered. UNHCR, WFP and UNICEF do not have enough money in the region. It is time for all Member States to respond fully to their appeal and help people on the spot, even if that is not enough.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I hope that the Council's misstep will not happen again next week. It is unspeakable, shameful, the conduct of some Member States with the new short-sightedness and deafness holding the Council hostage, slaves to electoral consent are insensitive to the appeals of the international community, they do not react to the recommendations of this House, they ignore the wave of solidarity of thousands of European citizens, including their own countries.  We rebel against the selfishness of the states they choose, which, by choosing the path of denial of the law, violate the human dignity of thousands of women, men and especially children. What will become of the more than 100 000 children who have arrived in the first six months of the year alone, and of all those who will arrive in the coming months? How can we deny them fundamental rights, how can we deprive them of their dignity and how can we steal their future? The time has really come to act, because the future of Europe also depends on how much we are able to share our European dreams, our values. No more minutes of silence, it is time to give a concrete response to the greatest humanitarian emergency in Europe, thank you.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen, before I give the floor to the next speaker, let me briefly comment on something that I have just read, namely that, on the border between Hungary and Serbia, Hungary is using tear gas against refugees trying to cross the border here. Let me – I hope, indeed on behalf of the whole House – make my criticism of it here! This is not a way of protecting Europe's borders. Refugees must have the right to seek asylum and must not be scareed away by tear gas. (Applause)

name: Jeroen Lenaers (PPE).
text: – On 3 October, it will be exactly two years since a boat disaster near Lampedusa that more than 300 refugees were killed. We've seen a lot in the last two years. We have seen proposals from the European Commission, we have seen Parliament's resolutions, we have seen council conclusions and time and time again we have stressed the urgency. We have stressed the need for solidarity. We have called for concrete action. But if we look back at what has really been done over the last two years, we have very little to be proud of, with the absolute low point being the Council conclusions of July and last Monday's. I would therefore like to leave it to the Member States in a simple call: step over your own shadow, step over your national egos and please show us next week that the 'U' of European Union also means something to you.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D).
text: – Madam President, while we have been sitting in the Chamber, the scenes at the Hungarian-Serbian border are truly shocking. The contrast between what we have been discussing, which is the inability for some Member States to relocate 120 000 refugees, and the fact that tens of thousands of refugees would have gone into Lebanon in the last three or four days, is truly extraordinary. What a contrast to see this. Everyone from all parts of the political spectrum in this Chamber should see what these images are saying about the European Union. Those like Angelika Niebler, who just now said that we should please act together, should understand that this is now about the European Union and the ability for us to follow the Commissioner and his plans and the Presidency, which is well organised. At 3 o’clock, even Parliament realised that it must vote tomorrow because the Member States in the minority were not acting. Everything is there for us to do, but we have not done it because of those Member States. We were not born yesterday: we know who is blocking this. Let us unblock it, do something and stop the shame of Europe and those who think they know better. They do not know better. We must act together and act quickly on this refugee crisis.

name: Artis Pabriks (PPE).
text: – Madam President, asylum rights and the right to life and to safety have always been highly regarded fundamental rights in the European Union. There is no doubt that there is a need to help those people whose lives are threatened, but at the same time no sane person either in Western or Eastern Europe will question this.  At the same time, we must note once more that this is not a migrant crisis, but a crisis produced by weak and delayed foreign security policies, including the inability to control our existing borders and to enforce the law. Being kind to refugees does not mean that we have to abolish laws, states and borders. I would also like to draw your attention to the fact that lately EU decisions have taken a serious turn. There are some politicians who would like to force, threaten and blackmail sovereign countries – smaller and weaker countries – to adopt a certain position. If this happens we will abolish the traditional right established already by John Locke in the European Union: we cannot enforce good by wrong means, nor by might. We have to remember that.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We have had weeks of disappointment and helplessness, because responsibility is constantly being shifted back and forth. Last Monday was another wasted opportunity and we won't have many chances. Perhaps next Monday is the last chance to do something sensible. It is a question of finally having a fair distribution mechanism in Europe based on solidarity, of having legal entry and not forcing people into the hands of smugglers across the sea. Thirdly, we need support in the countries of origin. There are countries, such as Iraq and Jordan, where food rations are being cut, and we need to fix that. And I believe that we urgently need money. Why is it not possible to set up EUR 1 billion immediately to resolve these issues?  Finally, there are currently more than 100 000 people on the Balkan route. Commissioner, I would ask you, I would ask you to do everything possible to help these people in this precarious situation.

name: Róża Gräfin von Thun und Hohenstein (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab It was reminded that winter was coming. I want to remind you that with winter Christmas is approaching. Many of us remember the story of this family who, in Bethlehem, two thousand years ago, circled from house to house and asked for a party. And many of us say that Christianity is one of the most important pillars connecting Europe. So let's take them seriously. The conversation about refugees is really a conversation about us – europeans. What kind of citizens are we and what would we like to be? What Kind of Poles, Czechs, French, Europeans do we want to be? What values do we want to build on in practice, not just in words, and on which we want to build the future? So I appeal – we don't block each other's quotas. I am watching demonstrations in Poland, including those in support of greater European solidarity. And with such a green stamp in the flap, the demonstrators say "the green light for political refugees." More people and institutions have reported their willingness to help than the proposed amounts would require. I am convinced, and this is heard in this House, that divisions are not only between states, but also between societies, and that we will certainly come up with a European solidarity solution.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D).
text: – Madam President, neither 40 000 nor 120 000 reflect the reality of the exodus we are facing. Commissioner, the European Union is sinking like refugee ships. But for the urgent we do not need any meeting of the Council of Ministers, nor of the European Council. We don't need any summit to do the urgent. Humanitarian action, humanitarian care for refugees are urgent; safe ways for them to reach Europe; humanitarian visas for pregnant women, the sick and the thousands and thousands of children transiting the European or neighbouring territory. Humanitarian action does not need the decision of the Justice and Home Affairs Council. We can make the decision now. The sooner we make the decision, the fewer people will suffer. Because that answer is what the people who are swinging at our doors are waiting for, and the answer they are getting is isolation, humiliation, beatings and, now, tear gas. For this emergency action we do not need the European Council, fortunately.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, if we want to tackle migration with a long-term approach, we must look beyond the Eu ropean Union's borders. It must be borne in the fore that 4 million Syrian refugees are currently in lebanon and Jordan. This shows that it is in their land that they wish to return. Many of them also belong to the Christian minority of the Churches of the East, the Europe of Christian roots, cannot remain impassive in the face of their tragedy, particularly of the Yazidi minorities, harassed and persecuted by Isis. We will therefore welcome a military operation under the aegis of the UN, combined with an increase in the resources made available to the UNHCR.  We need a common asylum policy, efficient reception centres in transit countries and, above all, we need to amend the Dublin Regulation. Policies for cooperation in economic development must be linked to policies to combat illegal immigration. In short, we must use the powers conferred on us by the Treaties, thank you.

name: Knut Fleckenstein (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Let us stop talking about a refugee crisis! Nor is there a migration crisis – there is a European crisis. One in four people living in Jordan is a refugee. And we should not be able to accommodate 500 000 refugees– with 500 million people in Europe? I believe that we can solve this so-called crisis. But we must now act calmly, together and quickly. This is not easy, because there is no plan, because until recently the Member States – including my own – insisted that these policies do not concern the EU. But we are concerned about it! We like to talk about our European values. We are particularly keen to use them when it comes to the policies of states outside the EU, but we must also live them here in Europe, in the EU, otherwise we will not be credible. Those who respond to hardship, misery and flight with rejection, walls, barbed wire and tear gas have nothing to do with our values. Such governments have different values. They want a different Union, and we will not have it.

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra (PPE).
text: – Madam President, we value, but little, very little, the commitments made by the Council on the 14th. We hope that the pitfall summed up in the word "mandatory" can be resolved unanimously or by a qualified majority at the next session on the 22nd. Our determination shows Parliament's commitment to urgently implement the relocation of 120 000 people in the terms proposed by the Commission. Existing discrepancies should not prevent the worthy reception, distribution and transport procedures of the first 40 000 refugees from being already and urgently concreted. And all the more so since the Member States are already organising themselves for reception, with the competition of public administrations, civil society, churches and trade unions. At the same time, we must implement support, financial and personnel measures for the neighbouring Member States most affected, supporting Frontex and RABIT operations, as well as hotspots, with guarantees, with many guarantees, for return and with the help of UNHCR, with the help of the United Nations.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are disappointed with Monday's outcome, but we are not going to reassure ourselves of a Europe that is incapable of dealing with its greatest crisis. That is why we will urge the Council to implement and try to implement the plan. Parliament is there and it is doing its part. Because it is the citizens who ask us this and when they tell us where Europe and what it does we cannot and do not want to be left without answers.  Europe cannot turn its head the other way or forget that when we were not 28, we took in political refugees, but we also welcomed economic migrants and precisely from countries that are pulling back today. Today, too, I have heard petty and unacceptable propaganda. How can we think that it was the far-sighted choice of leaders of Merkel, of Germany as a whole or of welcoming Italy and Greece that caused an historic exodus? How can we be so mean, demagogic, obtuse for a few more votes? So are many forces in my country that circumvent and deceive our citizens.  Commissioner, at a time when the new summit is on the horizon, as we work to ensure that the emergency of people trapped between borders is a success, today we also feel gassed, trapped between borders, in a vice that has no way out. Please resolve this issue!

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE).
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, once again the Council has failed. We need a European and solidarity solution, and several Member States look into each other, looking like hostages to radical and populist rhetoric. Faced with an emergency situation, they decide to continue debating after a month and only after the public scandal is an extraordinary meeting is called for next week. The Commission has responded well. She was brave and she was able to hear what reality demands and this Parliament has been asking for it for a long time. I have heard criticism of the reintroduction of German border controls. This is a respectable decision, of who is set an example, welcoming more refugees than anyone else. It should be remembered: reintroducing controls is not closing borders. Some reintroduce controls to improve the reception of refugees, and there are those who do so to hinder access, close borders and attack the free movement of Schengen. Schengen is not threatened by refugees. Schengen is being threatened by the political exploitation of some governments and the inaction of the Council. I repeat what we have been saying: Europe needs an answer to its responsibilities. Parliament and the European Commission agree. It is time for the Council to act and act well.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: – My country, Slovenia, has been increasingly mentioned recently as an actor in the refugee crisis, also because Hungary has shifted the flow, transiting refugees through Croatia and Slovenia to Germany and Austria. But the problems have also arisen in recent days as Germany closes its borders. Austria with Slovenia has also done the same today. Hungary is closing its borders, and Slovenia will do the same. Finally, croatia and Slovenia, which have relatively low absorption capacity, have been let down. I hope that's how you...? that the European Union, and the Council in particular, will act in a more coordinated and solidarity-based manner in the future, helping Slovenia and Croatia with the big wave we expect in the coming hours and days.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE).
text: "I regret that I have to use my precious one minute to reject what you just said about Hungary, because these are slides again. This news does not mention what you have announced here, that the 300 refugees who are currently struggling with the Hungarian police did not want to enter Hungary by accident through the entry points, at the designated points of entry, legally, but at all prices, trying to break through the fence and throw stones at the Hungarian police from the Serbian side. I ask which real refugee would rather get into a fight with the police than register at a designated entry point.  The problem is that we are hypocrites in admitting that the vast share of them are not genuine refugees, that they would not be entitled to refugee rights within the Union, and therefore want to avoid registration in any case. It is hypocritical to speak of solidarity without saying that the protection of the external borders is the most important thing. It is hypocritical to attack the fence if we cannot find a better way for people not to come on the green border, but at legal entry points.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: I was referring to news reports from news agencies that said Hungary was using tear gas against refugees. I do not think tear gas is by any means the right way to deal with refugees. If you say that they have no right to seek asylum, I think that the right to asylum is an individual right.

name: Frank Engel (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Yes, we need more political engagement in the Middle East. Yes, we need more development aid. But I remember that the President of the Commission rightly said here last week that there is no sea, there is no wall, and there is no fence that someone who sees his life threatened, who flees war, who seeks protection and who needs protection, does not want to overcome with his child on his back. These people will not be deterred by fences. Nor will they be deterred by tear gas. And the only way to confront them if we do not want to take them in would be with further violence. Australia has tried. Refugee boats have sunk. The sinking of refugee boats was deliberately accepted. And these refugee boats with sunken migrants, with dead migrants, these migrants squatting around on Pacific islands, are now one of the reasons Australia has changed its policy and sent the Prime Minister responsible for it into retirement. I hope that we will not even start with this policy on this continent where human rights originate!

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Madam President, let me explain to you what the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament are. As president, you cannot react politically and you cannot express your personal views. I ask that you respect the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament and do not repeat these errors. And if you only have information from the media, please don't say your information here. Have you been to Hungary? Did you see the border there? Did you meet these people there? That was my technical response, and now I would like to comment on what has been said here. I do not see Monday's Council as problematic and, unfortunately, I will not join those who say their sceptical views about how the Council has turned out. I think we have all declared that we are open to negotiations and that we need to start acting. If someone has a different opinion, we cannot threaten to stop european subsidies, but we need to sit down at the same table and have to discuss it more. This is a democratic Europe.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Mr Timmermans referred to ‘winter coming’. He could have added a Shakespearean observation: ‘a winter of our discontent’, if we do not get to grips with the migration problem. There is an onus on all of us to play our part, because the vast majority of European citizens are generous people who feel very much for the refugees.  There is an onus on all Member States to play their part as generously as possible. It is then up to the European Union to look at the external matters and see how we in the safe countries can help, particularly by providing assistance and dealing with the smugglers. If we all put our resources together we can have a winter that will not so full of discontent for the refugees or for the citizens of Europe.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the discussion on the Council of Ministers' meeting shows that we all have one common goal. This means addressing a situation that is becoming truly critical, and the events of today in Hungary only confirm this. We have different views on what approaches to take. I cannot agree with my colleague Verhofstadt, who said here that it should be decided by a vote. Does that mean overvoteing those who are in the minority on the Council of Ministers?  I consider it a good result that there was no re-vote. The European Union can only succeed if it is united and united if there is room for understanding even those countries that want to join in solidarity, but in solidarity. This will be all the more important, and I am convinced of this, even for countries that today have a different approach, such as the Czech Republic.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Madam President, (The principle of intervention is inaudible) that is the most repeated word in speeches this afternoon, whose goodness crashes again and again against the lousy state of a European Union which is neither shadow of what it said it was and promised us that it would be. Therefore, we are not only facing fraud against Europe, which is no longer Europe not only for refugees, but also for Europeans. Because we are facing not only a problem of non-compliance with political will, but also of non-compliance with international humanitarian law and the Treaties themselves in force. Therefore: action, action now, is what we have the right to expect from the Commission in the face of states facing the refugee crisis , as it has been called - with police tools and building walls and barriers; action by the Commission; action now is what European citizens have the right to expect; not only beautiful words, touching words, but above all action against Member States that fail to comply with European law.

name: Vicky Ford (ECR).
text: – Madam President, this is an unprecedented situation, because many millions of people are trying to escape horrific wars. But countries are helping in different ways: my Polish colleagues have talked to me about the hundreds of thousands of people who have escaped from Ukraine into Poland; my Croatian colleague has told me how her tiny country is trying to help thousands of people arriving there today; in the UK, we have sent over GBP 1 billion of aid to the region already and have, just today, offered to send a naval ship, HMS Richmond, to help in the combat against traffickers. I hope that the Commission will give a swift response to that offer.  Countries can help in different ways: we should respect this. I am concerned that the top—down quotas will build resentment. We need to work together to do more in the reception centres and more to help the millions of people in the region, but please let us stop the finger pointing because that is damaging. The quotas will build resentment and do not help.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, there are no possible borders in a globalised world: these are mobile. People are going to move if they're desperate, and the expensive comes cheap. The sooner we act, the sooner we put funds in place, the sooner we restore the 40% that has been cut from the World Food Programme in third countries, the sooner we will end despair. Because winter is coming. If we don't give security in Syria, and then all over the region, we'll all pay for it. Tomorrow they will tell us that in Hungary they were forced to carry tear gas. But I can assure you that if we do not accept our responsibility, this will become more and more serious every day; and there will be law or there will be no law, but people are going to pass; and there will be European citizens who, if there is no law, will support those who violate the law. Look, I wasn't going to tell you something that's absolutely personal: when my mother was a war refugee, my grandmother would dig on the beaches to look for clams and feed her, and she stole potatoes to feed her. Mothers who want to feed their children, who flee from the desperation of war, cannot be stopped.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, Mr Avramopoulos, you have stated that the European Union cannot accept those who have no right to stay. I would ask you not to remove rights from those who have, or should have, all rights, also to stay in Europe. I liked it better when you have recognized that no wall will stop those looking for a better future for their daughters and sons. If you really think about it, I encourage you to develop that idea and to do something effective already against those walls. And, with the same respect and identical conviction, I would say otherwise to Mr González Pons: he spoke here against the walls, so I encourage him to ask his Government to bring down his own in Ceuta and Melilla. Commissioner, you mentioned twice that the Union must protect its borders. Disturbing terminology, because it leads to the thought that it is a war that knocks on our doors, and it is not. They are people who seek, deserve and have every right to a better life, also here and now.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Article 80 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union: this article dictates a principle, the principle of solidarity and fair sharing of responsibility, applies to the common immigration policy, it applies to the common asylum and protection policy; It applies to our obligations under the Geneva Convention, but above all to the history and crimes committed in this century and in others.  Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in the council's scandalous decision, I saw neither a common policy nor a common policy, nor a fair solidarity. I have seen tolerance towards concrete walls and barbed wire, I have seen attachment to the usual hypocritical economic and electoral interests. I saw even more hypocrisy in shedding tears for a day in front of a photograph without doing anything on the field. The selfishness and indifference of a few States cannot kill the dignity of everyone, of the whole of Europe, otherwise it will be the winter not only of 2015 but of the European project. End of inadequate Dublin. Yes to legal means, yes to compulsory quotas, yes to sanctions for those who refuse. That is what we want on Monday. The European Parliament, he asks, the citizens of Europe want it. Law, justice and humanity demand it.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The European Union is facing an unprecedented influx of migrants. Any person following the situation in the Countries of the Middle East and North Africa and the data provided by Frontex could have foreseen such developments. We must make it clear that we are now being held to bear the consequences of our own omissions and mistakes of the past.  However, we cannot remain indifferent to the fate of refugees. We must look for wise solutions that aim not only at adopting them, but also at creating a comprehensive, long-term migration policy. Examples of cities such as Munich show that, despite great desire, technical restrictions on the number of refugees that can be accepted are necessary. Therefore, despite criticism from many partners, I believe that it is the government that is acting responsibly in favour of a mechanism that takes into account the actual capabilities of the Member States in order Polish to allocate refugees. No quotas may be imposed. Such a solution will prove inefficient in the long run.  In helping refugees, we must also remember our citizens, their fears and expectations. Therefore, additional measures are crucial to ensure peace and security in Europe, such as helping refugees in conflict areas, extinguishing conflicts in Middle Eastern countries and, in the future, adequately integrating newcomers into our society or returning them to their country of origin.

name: Soraya Post (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for It is with sadness and disappointment that I speak here today. I think of all the people knocking on our door, and we keep it closed. I am ashamed that the leadership shown by the Member States in the Council is a political disaster. It shows total inhumanity. When I think about this, I see the picture of three monkeys. You know the famous picture – you don't see anything, you don't hear and you don't say anything. It's going to be over. I think that Parliament and the Commission have shown that we see, that we hear and that we have spoken out. Now is the time for the Council and the Member States to assume their responsibilities, towards the citizens of Europe and, first and foremost, towards the people who suffer and die fleeing war on the way here. This is unacceptable. We can't stand this. We have a story to leave.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: – Since the beginning of the year, two hundred and sixty thousand refugees have entered Greece via Turkey. But what is the Council of Interior Ministers doing? He washes his hands as Pontius Pilate. We need a permanent key to the distribution of refugees in the European Union and not a temporary relocation mechanism. Apply a distribution key for all refugees and not just for a hundred and sixty thousand. To concern everyone and not those who have entered Greece and the European Union since 15 August. Not only Hungary but also Germany must accept this. But, ladies and gentlemen, what does Germany do? All miracles unfortunately last three days. The same is true of Mrs Merkel's so-called "hospitality" which, after inviting poor refugees from Syria to come to Germany, suspended Schengen after the photos and closed Germany's border with Austria. In fact, to send a message to the other refugees, he opened the former Nazi concentration camp in Buchenwald to accommodate some. This is unacceptable.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, during the war in Croatia I had the opportunity to help many displaced persons and refugees from Bosnia and Herzegovina and to feel what it means to be homeless, to lose everything. That is why today I support what the Commission is doing, the performances and attitudes we have and I condemn what happened on Monday. However, I want to warn you that the migrant crisis has practically shifted to Croatia. In the last 24 hours, refugees are entering Croatia and importantly, the Croatian government has shown seriousness at the moment, but Croatia cannot solve the problem on its own. And that is why it is important that the Commission immediately assists our country so that Croatia can cope with the refugee wave that is sure to follow. In addition, I must say, we have a great example from Kutina where young people even prepare a cultural program for refugees. Such people need support, but the Commission and the European Union must act and show solidarity in action.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, human rights are being violated in Hungary, as the rights of refugees are not being respected: terrible inhumanity. The President of Hungary, Mr Orbán, is a member of the European People's Party, as are many of you who today fill your mouths talking about solidarity; just like Mr. Juncker, that Mrs. Merkel or that Mr. Rajoy. Statements no longer serve, words no longer serve: only facts serve. Are you going to expel Mr Orbán from the European People's Party? Yes or no? Otherwise, if he's not expelled, he'll be being armed.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE).
text: – Madam President, while discussing the dramatic situation with the refugees, we should not lose sight of the Western Balkan region. As last night’s situation at the Hungarian-Serbian border showed, the current migration crisis extends beyond EU borders and is a hard test of feasibility for our Western Balkan partners.  Serbia and Macedonia are under heavy pressure with the flows of migrants in a similar way to Italy, Greece or Hungary. We should not forget this while distributing funds and should support these countries as well. The Western Balkan countries are our partners and cannot be left out of the discussion on a possible solution to this crisis. We need to find a common solution together with our Western Balkan partners.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D).
text: – It-Tnejn li għadda kulħadd kellu għajnejh fuq il-Ministers tal-Ġustizzja in l-Affarijiet Interni would be more potent if naraw lill-mexxejja tal-Unjoni Ewropea jieħdu deciżjoni concrete fuq din it-traġedja umana, iżda għal darba oħra, iè-äittadini tagħna baqgħu diżappuntati ħafna bil-falliment tal-ministri li ma jiħdux deäiżjonijiet iebsa biex tinstab soluzzjoni communes għall-kriżi tar-refuġjati. Kemm Il ngħidlu? Daqshekk paroli in issa rridu azzjoni: azzjoni kuraġġjuża bbażata fuq is-solidarjetà mill-Istati Membri kollha. Mhux azzjoni nitfgħu il-gass tad-dmugħ fuq ir-refuġjati, tafux? Kemm-il darba rridu ngħidu, mingħajr aktar dewmien, għandna bżonn nindirizzaw is-sitwazzjoni? Minflok, l-Istati Membri, f'daqqa waħda qed jerġgħu jintroduèu control fil-fruntieri, jheddu ż-Żona Schengen in jitfgħu dubji fuq wieħed mill-prinäpji ewlenin tal-Unjoni Ewropea: il-moviment liberu. Il-Parliament Ewropew iddeèieda. Issa huwa f'idejn l-Istati Membri biex tmexxija policy b'saħħitha, b'azzjonijiet concrete in miżuri speèifièi, tirrispondi għall-kriżi global tar-refuġjati. Niftakru din hija s-sintomu u mhux il-kawża.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Madam President, as we have this debate, the first hundred refugees are entering Croatia. Borders are being closed around our country, walls are being erected and railways blocked, so at the moment it is unclear whether anyone will want to accept surplus refugees to whom Croatia has no and cannot offer anything.  It is clear that fences, walls and blockades are not the solution, but they are not a mere product of one's folly either. Part of the responsibility lies certainly with Brussels, from which messages were sent that clearly do not have the support of all Member States.  Today, a large number of people in the refugee column have nothing to do with the war in Syria and Iraq. They come from countries that are not directly affected by the conflicts, and they come because European officials have told them that there is room for everyone in Europe.  There should be room in Europe for women, children, old people and those waiting for certain death if they stay in their homeland, and for economic migrants, this supposedly worried Europe should have had a common immigrant policy a long time ago.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, there is therefore nothing defined by the Council summit: the divisions between the countries of Eastern Europe and the rest of the continent remain strong. Only the first plan for the relocation of refugees has been given the green light: this Europe seems to be taking a step forward and two steps backwards. The Member States are still deeply divided on the second 120 000 relocations and on how to manage the flow of migrants arriving at the borders. This is at a time when some Eastern European countries are introducing more restrictive immigration rules and are continuing to build barbed-wire walls to repel migrants.  I hope, therefore, that the extraordinary Council convened for the 22nd will find a shared solution, Europe will be built with solidarity and not with tear gas at the borders. We need to discuss the reform of the Dublin Regulation and the right to European asylum, in short, a genuine integrated European policy on migration which has been binding on the Member States and which also provides for economic sanctions.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I strongly object to the proposal for mandatory quota distribution of immigrants within the territory of the Member States of the European Union. This would be a violation of the national sovereignty of each of the states to protect its national borders. The proposal made does not solve anything because it does not give an answer to how this invasion will be stopped. There is no way to keep in Bulgaria those who responded to Mrs Merkel's kind invitation. In this sense, it should be held accountable for its words and for the problems it created with the closure of borders after that invitation. It was part of creating the problems. Bulgaria cannot afford to accept a single person more for political, economic, demographic or value reasons and problems, and the stated intention of some of the Brussels bureaucracy to punish Member States that disagree with the decision makes the European Union very close to the Soviet Union. I therefore strongly object to the proposal made for the mandatory quota distribution of migrants and demand that it be rejected.

name: Mario Borghezio (ENF).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that it is established practice for catch the eye to be given the floor, especially as in this case where many Members have spoken, at least one Member per group. But for the Group of a Europe of Nations and Freedom Group, I made the request at the beginning of the proceedings and was not given the floor to either myself or any Member of Parliament. I ask to be allowed to speak for a minute.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Mr Borghezio, we have the practice here of those Members who actually took part in the debate and who were present. This was not the case with you and some others. That is why I have given the floor only to those who have actually followed the debate. I ask for your understanding.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, let me start by expressing my thanks to all Members of Parliament who have contributed in a very constructive way to this debate. As I said at the beginning, it is a very important debate.  I notice that we all agree that we are confronted with a multifaceted crisis. Yes, it is a crisis of refugees and migration, but it is also a crisis that has to do with the European Union and its institutions in general. It is a crisis that tests the values of the Union, the credibility of Europe and the validity of the principle of solidarity, but also the capacity of our institutions to react and act. I can assure you that in the Commission we are fully conscious of our duty and, from the very beginning of the life of this Commission, we have welcomed that. In a period of only seven months we delivered by presenting the European Agenda on Migration with the contribution and the approval of this House.  Let me also say that it is not about finger pointing. It is about finding a consensus. It is about keeping Europe united. It is true that it sometimes takes more effort, but our role, the role of the Commission and of the Presidency – as Mr Asselborn said – is to discuss, to explain and to overcome differences.  Many of you made special reference to Schengen. I want to tell you that the temporary reintroduction of border controls is explicitly foreseen in the legislation for exceptional situations and as a temporary measure. The Commission is closely following developments and is also informing Parliament at every stage. It is not the end of Schengen. Schengen is the most important, tangible achievement of Europe integration and we shall protect it.  Talking about Schengen and borders, I would also like to stress that guarding borders with violent means is not compatible with European values and principles. We are here to preserve and guarantee freedom of movement in Europe, but we also need to secure our external European borders. This is why the Commission’s comprehensive approach needs to be adopted and swiftly implemented.  Yes, I expressed my frustration at the outcome of the recent Council but, with your support and the excellent work done by the Luxembourg Presidency, we will all go this extra mile united. We are determined – as Frans Timmermans said – to build bridges and to prove that Europe is up to the challenge, that Europe is credible, and that Europe is determined to stay  united, resolved, solid and humane.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The wave of migrants entering Europe from conflict-stricken and poverty-stricken areas of Africa and the Middle East poses a real major challenge for EU Member States. Within the framework of its treaty capacity, the EU should launch emergency funding to support countries such as Italy, Greece and Hungary, which have reached the first wave of migrants. We must realise that migration from conflict areas has been going on for years. The countries of my region have already welcomed hundreds of thousands of immigrants from Ukraine and other eastern European and Caucasus countries, including culturally different Chechens, Ingus and Tatars, who came after successive Russian aggressions. We will continue to show such solidarity. However, I cannot imagine that representatives of other EU Member States will put pressure on my country. The mechanism for the forced relocation of immigrants is a non-treaty, unacceptable and counter-effective solution. Even if it is relaxed, I would consider it a total fiction after all the statements and pressures. The EU's borders need to be strengthened and the Member States that uphold these borders should be supported.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I very much regret the current situation in which borders are necessarily closed and Europe's society falls into the snare of populist xenophobia. Europe must now prove that the values of a Union based on shared responsibility and solidarity are not empty. Member States must act immediately and must do so together. Relocation and respect for the individual right to asylum and, above all, support for countries in need of financial and organisational support are expectations that should be discussed in the first place. Therefore, increasing the area of activity of THE EASO agency overseeing the asylum system is a priority.  It is also important to bear in mind the external borders of the European Union, which must be strengthened and jointly protected. The European Union has given its people the opportunity to travel without passport control on its territory, but our 'common home' must be protected from the outside, regardless of who wants to get there. It is therefore necessary to focus on frontex's activities in this regard.  I hope that the extraordinary Council meeting convened on 22 September will make it possible to find a common solution. It is necessary to discuss the reform of the Dublin Regulation and the aforementioned European asylum law. In short, we need a genuine integrated European migration policy that is binding on the Member States and allows us to obtain a social credit of trust in our actions.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. – According to the Commission, almost half a million refugees and migrants have arrived in Hungary, Italy and Greece so far this year, generating a crisis whose most dramatic side is precisely the high number of those who have stayed along the way, drowned in the Mediterranean. It is truly regrettable that Member States, in these circumstances, are unable to agree to take measures to allow the relocation of the large number of refugees who have arrived in the EU. We are playing our credibility and our image before the world. If the tragedy we are going through these days is not enough for the European Union to respond together, nothing will be. We will simply be a common market, but the ideal of a continent united by common values of solidarity and respect for human rights will be shattered. Let us hope that the Council will come to its senses at its meeting next week.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. The Justice and Home Affairs Council (JAI) was a failure, and that is all the better, since the Commission intended to impose a mandatory policy of relocation across Europe to the hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants who are now flocking to its doors. I want to denounce here the attitude of Mrs Merkel, who closes her borders after having promised the moon to 800,000 of these immigrants. However, it was not really necessary to be a great cleric to anticipate the consequences of the Chancellor's irresponsible remarks. I would like to think that German reception services are saturated. But this U-turn sounds like a new threat against Member States that do not want these immigrants. It is in addition to the very explicit one of cutting off European funds or the more veiled one of depriving their citizens of the right of free movement. This threat is that of blocking all these people at home, so that the binding, systematic, calculated and imposed quotas of Brussels, appear to be a lesser evil to the recalcitrant states. That this Parliament should add its small stone to this blackmail, by adopting an opinion on the text rejected by the Council as a matter of urgency and without changing it, is a scandal at the same time as an unacceptable coup de force.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D)
text: in writing. – The Commission must impose sanctions on Hungary and any Member State which refuses to take in refugees and prevents the opening of legal and safe routes for those who seek protection. How can the EPP keep, in its ranks, the Party of Orbán that attacks refugees, including with tear gas, bringing from the past the worst demons in Europe? Anyone who uses security as an excuse to violate human rights, international law and European laws and values is in fact playing the game for Islamic State terrorist criminals, who want civilization to go backwards. This is also a crisis of our security, because the EU has not acted to stop the war in Syria, Iraq, Libya and oppression in other countries, as it is failing to fight Islamic State terrorists - and so people are fleeing for protection in Europe.  It is not just the winter that is coming: desperate people - refugees and migrants - will continue to come, with or without barbed wire. The more walls you erect, the more surrounded Europe will feel. Disunity and inaction are recipes to collapse. We won't allow it. The Council must assume its responsibilities and NOW!

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. – A dramatic situation has developed in Hungary as a result of the influx of migrants. By early September, there had been almost 160,000 illegal border crossings Hungary southern border. The large number of migrants arriving in Hungary shows that the western Balkans migration route has been appreciated, and so is Hungary of the migrants. There is concern that immigration has a continuous, almost endless supply. It is therefore important to remember the weight of our words as politicians and to put an end to the irresponsible statements that we continue to use to encourage immigrants.  The current situation may have been because EU immigration policy cannot respond to the ever-increasing migratory pressures. All EU countries, like Hungary, should protect the EU's external borders. In the absence of a unified EU position, illegal immigrants will find alternative routes, either through Croatia or Romania. Hungary interested in joint European action, but will do its utmost to keep the process within the framework of EU law (Schengen, Dublin III) until it is reached. If the other Member States of the Union act differently, schengen, free movement, will be at risk. However, the quota system proposed by the Commission is not a solution, but merely symptomatic treatment, which would further complicate the situation with resettlement between inter-member countries. The solution must be sought outside Europe, more specifically in cooperation with countries of origin and transit.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (
text: alde), in writing. – Dear Colleagues, it is obvious that Europe needs a common migration policy. It is unfair that equal members of the European Union face completely different pressures. In the current situation, Europe needs to be more united than ever to be able to respond quickly and effectively to the roots of the problem – namely instability and neighbourhood wars. I therefore call on European leaders to take a strong, unified stance on a common approach to the migration situation – for the sake of peace and security in the Middle East, but also for the sake of our united Europe.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. – I believe that, according to principles of solidarity, it is necessary for the Commission to forge a mechanism and offer aid to countries in need. Thus, I salute the Commission’s initiative. However, I strongly suggest that an extensive, on-the-ground analysis of each individual Member State must be made before the redistribution attempt. Furthermore, I would like to note that it is dangerous to allow freedom of movement without considering the terrorist threat that is associated with the infiltration of radical activists amidst the refugees.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. – Tens of thousands of refugees from Syria have entered the European Union by land in recent weeks and have applied for asylum in various European countries. The large influx of refugees has led to massive border protection measures, especially in Hungary, with the aim of ensuring controlled entry into the Schengen area. Germany and Austria, on the other hand, have opened their borders to refugees, with the result that both the authorities and the national reception infrastructures are hopelessly overwhelmed. The decision of the Justice and Migration Council to distribute 120 000 migrants to all the Member States of the European Union through a quota system is further proof of this overburden and represents an absolute policy failure.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. - Border locks, barbed wire fences, police with dogs, soldiers, broken families, thousands of desperate people. This image welcomes us not in Turkey or in our remote neighbourhood, but in a Member State of the EU, Hungary of the European Union. On the Hungarian-Serbian border, I have personally seen that the Hungarian authorities are violating the principles of humanity and human rights by treating people who have walked hundreds and thousands of kilometres, including women and children. The Hungarian authorities are currently rejecting all asylum applications on the grounds that the refugees arrive on the territory of hungary via Serbia, which the Hungarian government Hungary safe. After the expulsion, the refugees will receive a decision in Hungarian on the basis of which they can appeal the decision. However, the decision will only be made in Hungarian and after deportation the refugees will not be able to appeal the judgment in the Szeged court.  What if it's not cruelty? Today, Hungary humanitarian catastrophe is taking place on its borders. The Hungarian Government exercises the politics of strength on the weak, and it cries out for European solidarity and responsibility only when it needs money. Barbed wire, inhuman treatment cannot be the answer to the refugee crisis, but the quota system is a solution. If the Hungarian Government continues to obstruct the development of a common refugee policy, it risks losing more EU funds. It is clear that the Hungarian Prime Minister is now not only harming refugees, but also endangering the interests of all Hungarian people.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. France now has more than 5 million unemployed and nearly 9 million people living below the poverty line. The unemployment rate explodes quarter after quarter. More than 200,000 immigrants enter the country each year, solely on the basis of legal immigration and taking into account only adults. The growth of my country has stalled, the ultraliberal dogma advocated by Brussels has led to deindustrialization and social breakdown in our country. The European directive on the secondment of workers has created totally unfair competition in our national labour market... And now the President of the Commission is asking us to take in tens of thousands of migrants and then, no doubt, hundreds of thousands and in the end how many millions? France cannot accommodate these illegal immigrants. The European Union, on the other part, does not seem to be concerned about the substantive issues raised by this sudden influx of migrants. Which states or organizations are behind these population displacements? Who funds this and for what purposes? It is these legitimate questions that the Union must now answer.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. – The Council of Heads of Government should be convened without delay, since the worst possible decision was taken at the Council meeting of the Interior Ministers rather than a compromise. The deed has placed in complete uncertainty the migrants already allowed in and the Member States concerned, as well as the transit countries and the refugees stranded there. It is a trauma that mandatory quotas have not been pushed through, but the fact that a number of Member States unilaterally closed the internal Schengen borders, one of the EU's most important achievements, on the same day, causing enormous chaos for commuters in the border area, has been noted with angelic calm by the relevant ministers. The development of the great achievement, the collection points – hotspots – is worthless until the Dublin Convention is amended so that unwanted refugees from northern Europe cannot be sent back to the country of first registration.  There is a realistic chance that barbed wire will also separate the individual Member States. The lack of solidarity lies not only with the V4 States, since the EU itself has put EUR 41 million into the Fund for The Assistance of Countries Affected by the Syrian Crisis (MADAD), awaiting further offers from the Member States, but so far only a further EUR 5 million has come from Germany and EUR 3 million from Italy. In my opinion, Member States should play their part in the commitments in proportion to their proportions.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D)
text: Writing. – Unfortunately, the Council meeting has had little success. Some narrow-minded national leaders have captured the entire European institutional system, effectively hampering effective and rapid crisis management. It is disappointing that this group is being voiced by the Prime Minister of my country, Viktor Orban. I was shocked to hear that the Hungarian Government had refused to Hungary front country. If so, why have they put in place an 'asylum emergency'? Why did they deploy the army to the border? Why are they pulling barbed wire fences all over the place?  I spent Monday and Tuesday of this week on the Hungarian-Serbian border. It is difficult to describe the vulnerability and uncertainty that refugees face. It is shameful how unprofessional and cynical the Hungarian Government is in its handling of the situation threatening humanitarian catastrophe. At the end of the procedure, which was shortened to a few hours, all asylum applications were rejected, saying that the applicant had arrived via Serbia, which was declared safe. Rejected people, including women and children, are stuck in no man's land between the fence and Serbia. Is this the Europe we represent? Is this the "solution" that European citizens expect us to do? It's time to act. Let's put aside partisan a point of reference and petty political tactics. Let us make it clear that the vast majority of Europe does not ask for a selfish and inhumane policy based on intrepensive nationalism, and that there are very serious consequences for a Member State violating the fundamental values of the European Union.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. – The meeting of the European Union's interior ministers was disappointing because no workable solution to the refugee crisis was found. The refugee crisis is exacerbating tensions between EU Member States and the lack of consensus on a humane solution to the refugee crisis is also starting to spill over into other areas of the EU. Only consensus in the EU will allow for the future with budgets, some of which will receive more and others will pay more, as well as security policy issues. With the reintroduction of border controls caused by the refugee crisis on some sections of the EU' internal border, pressure is also increasing on the Schengen system and on the free movement of persons. The division within the EU can be stopped by a swift agreement on solutions to the refugee crisis so that all Member States can feel the support of others in a difficult situation.

name: Ева Паунова (PPE)
text: in writing. – The Justice and Home Affairs Council conclusions are a good first step. However, the agreement reached between the parties is far from all Europeans' expectations of a single approach of measures to address migratory pressures that will restore trust in national authorities and in the EU. It is worrying to me that the conclusions do not take sufficient account of the possibility of the refugee flow changing its route. Today, there is already enough information that several thousand refugees are likely to try to cross the border between Turkey and Bulgaria, which is an external border of the EU. At this stage, however, it is not mentioned as a place that needs attention and reinforcement. The EU started the debate on the refugee crisis late and with a vague focus, so everything we do today must be decisive and correct enough. The huge flow of people is becoming an increasingly serious social problem that can also escalate politically. We don't have time to convince our societies that Europe can cope. This will benefit all political extremists in our own countries, trying to question the European project.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. - More than 100 000 people are waiting for our response whether we will approve or reject the Commission's proposal and receive them. I support the Commission's proposal because it is realistic and guarantees the dignity of all those fleeing the war in Syria. This is a proposal that will allow us to show solidarity together towards those in need and to build the Europe we believe in. I support the quota system, but I think it's just a temporary solution. The cause of these people leaving their countries needs to be addressed and see what the EU is doing to put the causes at its root, to stabilise the situation and to keep migration under control, as security reports suggest that there are also those among the refugees who have bought Syrian passports and who could potentially pose a security risk. We need a common comprehensive strategy that includes all countries and all parties, which will contribute to the protection of our external borders, but also to the protection of those fleeing war. This is not only a humanitarian issue, but also a security, economic and social issue, so we must be prepared to take these people into dignified care, while ensuring that EU citizens live in security and preserve our internal stability.

name: Емил Радев (PPE)
text: in writing. – The current migration crisis requires immediate and firm measures.  First, I call on the European Commission to draw up a list of transit countries that are on the path of the migration flow to Europe. On the one hand, these countries must be supported in the effective fight against trafficking in human beings; at the same time, however, we need to start immediate negotiations with them on the establishment of distribution centres to stop economic immigrants to Europe. Only in this way will we be able to reduce the migratory flow even before it reaches European shores. Strengthening the external borders is another important measure that will ensure European security, while at the same time stopping illegal immigration. The EU has mechanisms in place to allow those who want to enter the Member States legally to do so. Crossing the green border without a necessary visa or good reason, however, is not among them. Last but not least, Frontex's powers must be extended immediately so that the agency can arrange for the return of unsuccessful asylum seekers to their countries of origin. The Agency already has experience in such activity under the Attica project and common European actions in this regard will make return operations more effective.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. It is regrettable to see once again the Council's failure to agree here on the emergency relocation of 120,000 asylum seekers. It is also very worrying that only a few Member States have expressed their support for this proposal. Faced with the humanitarian emergency on our doorstep and within our own, the time for procrastination is over. We can no longer afford to multiply last-chance meetings. Member States reluctant to take in refugees are undermining our outside credibility and threatening to bring about the end of the Union. It is shameful to hold up the map of withdrawal when it comes to saving the lives of hundreds of thousands of children, women and men fleeing war and persecution. Beyond the worthy conditions of welcome and integration, the European Union and its Member States are also expected to strengthen development cooperation with countries such as Jordan, Lebanon and Turkey, which are hosting millions of refugees. The Union is not only a large market that would only serve to distribute wealth, it is also a common project with values to defend.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. – In the face of the refugee crisis, the Commission, among the European institutions, has prepared an urgent and substantive package of measures, which we have given the EP strong political support for, including the sharing of the burden of reception under an agreed mandatory quota system. This is natural, since the whole functioning of the Union and the sharing of the resulting burdens and benefits are governed by rules, if you will, on the basis of solidarity aspects, if you will, by 'quotas'. It is therefore intolerable that, in an urgent situation, putting aside both humane and practical aspects, our effective joint action seems to have failed again at Council level, because of the self-righteous domestic-tactical aspects of some Member States.  It is regrettable that the Hungarian Government provides the most extreme example of this, but as an aggravating fact, I also draw attention here to the peculiarity that the Orbans' actions, in addition to the exclusion and humiliation of refugees, are also in order to persecute and punish their own citizens who are trying to help them. It is time for the Union to create its own capacity and means to combat such inhumane, unscrupulous and uninhibited behaviour in the Member States, which also make joint European action impossible. It is not only at Council level, because it is precisely here, in the EP, that the European People's Party, which still tolerates Orban and fidesz, should be responsible – instead of legitimising this outrage by visiting Budapest and making concycilant statements there.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I do not recognize myself in this policy of European governments. In recent days, politicians have said they want to deprive refugees of certain rights or create special statutes for these migrants. I believe that these kinds of statements must be put to an end. It is out of the question to embark on this path, which would undermine our moral and legal duty to welcome these refugees who arrive at our country to escape the horror. In such a situation, the role of politics is not to stoke fears or to maintain fantasies, but to act according to the principles and values that underpin our rule of law. Europe must take its share of responsibility. People who fear for their lives should be allowed to apply for asylum in their country of origin, so that they do not put their lives at risk by crossing the Mediterranean in extremely dangerous conditions. In any case, there will be no viable solution without solidarity and without humanity. I will continue to fight for these values to be taken into account and respected!

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. Europe is still a long way from solidarity and the fair distribution of responsibilities among the Member States. The Council's decision, which envisages the voluntary relocation of 40 000 migrants arriving in Italy and Greece over the next two years, has to deal with the hostility of a group of EU countries: at present, the agreements reached allow just over 32 000 refugees to be relocated, that is, an insufficient number that does not cover the real need. This is for the time being the ineffective response to the failed structure of the Dublin Regulation and its failure to revise it. Without a compulsory and permanent relocation mechanism for all those Member States that are under exceptional migratory pressure and in the absence of a common international strategy to intervene in the causes of the flows, we will periodically witness the chaos caused by thousands of people fleeing to a Europe without union. We, the spokesman for the 5-Star Movement, will continue to fight for the change in the Dublin Regulation and for the affirmation of a fair, binding and mandatory distribution of migratory flows between all Member States.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Concerned about the scale of the discrepancies in the data provided by various media, including politicians, I suggest that information on migration processes, especially those concerning refugees, be verified fairly and quickly.  Information that there are more than 70% of young men fleeing war, data indicating a small percentage of full families, suggestions that one in ten men is a terrorist or a potential terrorist must be of concern. It is also important to define such nots as the aforementioned 'potential terrorist'. After all, in the current state of the interpretive scale, it can be anyone or rarely anyone. In my opinion, the importance of precise communication is crucial to the proper responses of individual communities.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the United Nations World Summit on Sustainable Development (25-27 September 2015) and on development aspects of the COP 21 climate change follow-up conference in Paris (2015/2745 (RSP)).

name: Nicolas Schmit
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Madam President, it would be easy to move on like this to another item on the agenda.
