But it turns out that this item on the agenda, which we are going to deal with now, is not unrelated to the one we have just discussed.  Of course, this debate has focused on refugees who are the victims of conflicts, terrible wars that are tearing a number of countries apart. But a number of MEPs have noticed that among these refugees, of course, there are also people who are described as refugees or economic migrants, as if poverty, as if the absolute deprivation they often face, is not a reason to seek a better life elsewhere.  What about those young people in Africa or elsewhere who have no prospect of finding a job, who have no prospect of having a decent life? In the end, are these young people not right to leave, to get started as well? Of course, we are talking about economic migrants, migrants who would have fewer rights. Yes, perhaps, they have no rights under the Geneva Convention, but is absolute poverty not a reason to leave and seek a slightly better life elsewhere? So I take a little bit of what President Juncker said last week: who are we Europeans to condemn those millions of people who want to go elsewhere? Not so long ago — because in history, a century or a century and a half is finally a relatively short period - millions of Europeans set out because they were poor, because they had no economic and social perspective in Europe, because they had nothing to offer their children. They went looking for a better life elsewhere and turned in particular to the new world that welcomed them. Therefore, you have to understand. It should be noted that one third of the Luxembourg population , I believe that there are other countries that are in similar situations - went to the United States because they could not survive in Luxembourg. Therefore, poverty concerns us. And the poverty elsewhere concerns us. This is the reality of a globalized world. Migration is part of this globalized world and especially in a globalized world where, finally, even those who live deep in Africa have information, ways to communicate, ways to get an idea of what his life could be like if he could live it elsewhere. This debate therefore affects us and, in a way, prolongs the previous debate because the answer, again, to these migrants called economics cannot be the construction of new walls, the construction of new barbed wire or the use of tear gas, at the moment, we do not know what will happen next.  The answer to this problem is development. It is a global economy that does not condemn millions, if not billions, of human beings in total destitution, not to mention climate refugees, refugees who are already victims of climate problems and global warming. It is for this reason that the adoption of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development is so important and must be a top priority for Europe, because, again, we are at the forefront if we fail to effectively combat poverty among our neighbours, among our African neighbours and others. Following the work of the Addis Ababa Conference on Development Financing, the Sustainable Development Summit in New York is the second major milestone of 2015, which I believe hopes are to be concluded by the adoption of a universal climate agreement in Paris in December at COP 21. The end result of the post-2015 process can be considered generally satisfactory. Indeed, the main objective of the European Union, that of adopting a sustainable development agenda that is ambitious, transformative and sustainable, has been achieved or almost achieved. We are still awaiting the final adoption by the summit at the end of this month in New York.  This agenda includes a set of objectives that integrate the three dimensions of sustainable development in a balanced way and pursues a primary objective: the eradication of poverty. In this context, we can congratulate ourselves that the action programme resulting from the Addis Ababa Conference on Financing for Development is the mainstay of the means of implementation of the 2030 Agenda and includes both financial and non-financial means to transpose the future development agenda.  I would like to acknowledge Parliament's role in this collective success and thank you for your support throughout the process of Negotiation. In this context, I would like to mention, in particular, Mr Stier's work on your November 2014 resolution on the overall post-2015 development framework and that of Mrs Theocharous on the role of local authorities in development cooperation. We must now take action, that is, the implementation of the 2030 agenda. To do that, we must first look at all the instruments we have and determine whether they are adequate. This programme represents a significant change from the Millennium Development Goals, in particular by its universal nature, which means that it will have to be implemented by all and at all levels of development. It is not just for developing countries, it is a sustainable development agenda. We find this idea that we all live on the same planet and that there is not, on the one hand, the haves and, on the other, those who unfortunately do not have the chance to be have the haves.  In this context, the Commission will have to examine all EU legislation in the various sectors concerned and present the appropriate legislative proposals to the European Parliament and the Council if necessary. For their part, Member States will also need to revise their sustainable development strategies and instruments in light of the 2030 agenda. The implementation and monitoring of the 2030 Agenda concerns not only governments and administrations but all actors, including civil society and the private sector. The programme incorporates a robust monitoring and monitoring mechanism that was one of the biggest challenges in the negotiations. We now have a framework that will allow us to assess progress and report back to citizens. In implementing the 2030 Agenda, we must also ensure that the balance between the three dimensions of sustainable development - economic, social and environmental - is maintained and I count on the support of Parliament. On the Council side, ministers from the development and environmental sectors will have the opportunity to discuss the further process and the coordination of the process on 26 October in Luxembourg. There are also strong links between the 2030 sustainable development agenda and the COP 21 conference, which will take place from 30 November to 11 December in Paris.  For the Luxembourg Presidency, it will be crucial to ensure that we build on the progress made in Addis Ababa and New York to ensure that the Paris conference is also a success. With regard to this Paris conference, reconciling development and climate action is possible, but it is not only possible, it is absolutely essential. That is why the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development has created a new goal: urgent action to combat climate change and its consequences. This goal calls for an ambitious and universal agreement in December at COP 21 in Paris. The preparation of COP 21 is one of the main priorities of our Presidency and, on Friday, the Ministers of the Environment and Finance will discuss the issue of climate finance at their meeting. The Environment Council will adopt conclusions as of this Friday, which will serve as a mandate for COP 21. The position of the European Union and its Member States is clear. The 2015 agreement should be, first, a universal and legally binding agreement to effectively combat climate change and contain the rise in the planet's average temperature, at least below two degrees below pre-industrial levels. Second, an agreement made to last, which offers a long-term vision of the necessary transformation to low-carbon resilient societies and economies that can withstand the effects of climate change. Third, a flexible agreement with the capacity to respond dynamically to the evolution of scientific and technological knowledge, responsibilities and capabilities and enable broad and effective participation. Finally, an agreement with mechanisms to measure progress and deepen its ambition. We need a strong regime, based on rules including rules on monitoring, emissions verification and clear compatibility of emissions applicable to all countries. The actions of the parties must be irreversible and progress towards low carbon emissions. An agreement with a long-term goal, which must send a strong signal to the transformation of countries' development trajectories so that they can are becoming low-carbon economies that are resistant to the effects of climate change.  I would add that financing will be an important element with, at the heart of the scheme, a public and private commitment of $100 billion per year by 2020 by developed countries for poor and vulnerable countries, and more broadly, a shift in investment towards low-carbon and economically viable technologies. This is a great prospect to revive our economies and make a real technological leap and support sustainable growth.  Finally, I would like to stress that we welcome the support, here too, of the European Parliament and its rapporteur, Mr Gilles Pargneaux, to help us reach an agreement in Paris soon.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I will make some specific comments on development—related elements for the Summit on Sustainable Development and COP 21, but before doing this, I want to make a more general remark.  It is almost a year ago that, in the course of the hearings in this Parliament, President Juncker decided to hand me responsibility for sustainable development in a broad sense to create coherence in our policies. I want to point to the fact that one of the factors that will determine whether we will be successful with these policies is whether we are able to create coherence between the different elements – and we lack coherence.  We lack coherence in my institution, we lack coherence in this institution, in the Council, in the Member States, in the international world. I think my first plea to you today would be, let us work together to create coherence between the actions of the DGs in the Commission, the different committees in the European Parliament. Let us face it, sometimes the policies that come out of different DGs and different committees have contradictions. That is a reality, so let us try and do away with contradictions. I am at your disposal, I say to the Members of this Parliament, to do better than we have done up till now.  I really want to make sure that we are coherent, because sustainable development has three main aspects: obviously environmental; but also economic, and social. These elements have a role inside the European Union, and obviously worldwide, and as long as we are not able to create coherence between these different dimensions our approach will not be successful enough and will, if it continues to be contradictory, also lead to a waste of financial resources, human resources, political resources.  The adoption of the 2030 Agenda for sustainable development is going to be a landmark achievement, I think, because it has an inclusive nature already. It is something the European Union has been advocating for a long time and I think this time, for once, citizens, parliaments, civil society, made the contributions, not just governments, and the way this Parliament was involved in the process testifies to that different approach. The European Union had an instrumental role in shaping the agenda; a lot will be expected of the European Union also in New York, and President Juncker has asked me to lead the delegation.  There are 17 Sustainable Development Goals which follow and expand on the MDGs. As I said, they would have to integrate economic, social and environmental dimensions, as well as human rights, gender equality, the rule of law, good governance and peaceful and inclusive societies. Let me come back to this point because I think it is crucial. A holistic approach is what we need, but there is always a big danger in a holistic approach. If you say you need to do everything you end up doing nothing. But if you only leave the different silos on their own you might achieve something in one silo, nothing in another, etc. So the challenge here is to be precise on the specific issues without ever forgetting that you need to integrate it with other policies.  Parliaments will have to have an important role to play in that, and governments as well, but civil society should never be forgotten, because integrating policies is actually better done mostly in civil society than at governmental level. We have agreed a global partnership, it is ambitious, and I think we are determined to change, to integrate our internal and external policies, to make sure that, also in the future of the Europe 2020 strategy and other areas, we are coherent with what we agree in New York.  Of course we need to look after the most vulnerable. If we do not look after the most vulnerable sooner or later they will draw the conclusion that they have no future where they are and will look for a future elsewhere, which will exacerbate the problems with migration we already have. In that context I think those countries which are now facing huge financial challenges because of the migration crisis, had they decided a long time ago to follow the UN’s guidance and go up to 0.7% of ODA, I think we would perhaps be looking at a different situation. So I would urge, through you, all the Member States finally to try and reach our objective, which is still in my view a modest one. It would inspire the rest of the world if Europe were also to lead in this area.  It is not just about aid and support. Huge parts of the world that used to depend on aid and support are now self-sustaining, are going through incredible growth cycles, incredible growth figures, but very often this growth is very unequally distributed. People migrate not because their country’s economy is shrinking or in trouble but because the wealth in their country is unevenly distributed, because they have no say, because democracy is thwarted, because their human rights are trampled upon. So there also we need to have an integrated approach involving all actors.  And we need a strong and inclusive follow-up and review mechanism. All too often we are good at coming to agreements, promising all sorts of things, but we are weak at following up, weak at presenting what we do and weak at being accountable for what we need to do, so we need to put up that strong and inclusive follow-up and review mechanism. On COP 21, very briefly, on development-related aspects, I have three remarks. First, we need to deliver the 20% of climate-relevant finance for our development budget, including the Development Cooperation Instrument and the European Development Fund, which will result in more than EUR 9 billion in climate finance between 2014 and 2020. This is more than double what was delivered during the previous period. We are making a significant effort to reach this target and have actively contributed to the climate finance report the OECD is preparing for the special World Bank and IMF meeting in Lima in October. Second, we are preparing to launch specific new climate-relevant initiatives, including a new phase of the Global Climate Change Alliance with a budget of at least EUR 350 million that will support adaptation to climate in vulnerable countries, notably least-developed countries and small island developing states. It will also provide support to accessible low-carbon energy through: bilateral and thematic programmes with around EUR 3.6 billion, including the new innovative Electrification Financing initiative, (ElectrFI), which will help mobilise private investment in this area; support to sustainable agriculture and food security, EUR 8.8 billion; and up to EUR 50 billion of investment through our blending facilities, with our Climate Change Windows being a key mobilising more climate finance from other public and private investors. This will include EU funding of at least EUR 2 billion in the period 2014-2020.  Finally, we plan a number of targeted side events in Paris to present these initiatives and raise awareness among our key partners in order to maximise their participation.

name: President. –
text: Now we will go to the speakers’ list. We will have a vote at 19.00. We will go speaker-by-speaker and will not use blue cards at all today.

name: Davor Ivo Stier
text: on behalf of the PPE Club. – Madam President, Minister Schmit, Vice-President Timmermans, a new 15-year global development framework will be adopted at the New York summit in less than two weeks. The European Parliament has already adopted a resolution, contributing to the definition of a new development framework after 2015. The European Union has also dedicated this whole year to promoting development policy, calling it the European Year of Development. As we observed in the previous debate, this year we could also call the European year of migration. And of course development policy is an important aspect in defining the response to the current refugee crisis and the long-term migration challenge. In this regard, I welcome the European Commission's announcement to create a €1.8 billion special fund for Africa in addition to the already existing Syria Fund. However, the allocation from the European budget or the European Development Fund is not sufficient, but requires a financial contribution from Member States to these funds. In terms of financing development cooperation, it is also necessary for Member States to reach the target of 0.7% of domestic income as soon as possible rather than waiting until the 2030 deadline. Year. At the same time, development policy must focus more on peace and security support projects, as well as promoting good rule, building effective impulsive institutions, combating corruption. The millennium development goals framework so far has not addressed these issues, but that would have to change in two weeks in New York. The new global framework is therefore much more demanding than the current one and focuses on the very causes of poverty and underdevelopment, not just the symptoms. Issues of peace and security, respect for human rights, an effective judiciary and the issue of migration are becoming part of a new framework that, unlike the Millennium Goals, will be universal, i.e. also mandatory for The Member States of the European Union.  The challenge and task now ahead is a credible implementation of the new development goals and it is therefore important to ensure in the coming period that the European Parliament effectively oversees the implementation of new objectives within the EU and in European development cooperation with other countries.

name: Linda McAvan
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, both speakers have made a link between the previous debate on migration and the debate on the Sustainable Development Goals. They are right to do so, because what we are doing in New York is talking about the right of everybody on this planet to live to live a decent life in the future. What I would like to see come out of New York is a commitment to finish the job that we started when we agreed the Millennium Development Goals: to put poverty eradication at the heart of our development policy and an agreement which recognises that ‘business as usual’ on the environment and climate change is simply not enough to guarantee a future with sustainable economic growth. The good news is that we have got a text. There will be no haggling at the last minute in New York. But I hope the easy agreement does not mean that some governments imagine that the text can be forgotten, put away in a cupboard and pulled out every now and then and that they can pick and choose which of the 17 goals and 169 targets to focus on. I am pleased, Commissioner Timmermans, that you have talked about how the EU will go ahead and implement that deal here inside the EU because there are two aspects, as you said. Firstly, how we make it relate to our development policy and our external action and, secondly, how it relates to our other environment and climate change objectives. So the first task is to get the right indicators and to get a common methodology, and I hope you will involve Parliament in those discussions in the future. Finally, a word on the COP agreement in Paris. As things stand today, the emissions cut pledges on the table do not add up to the 2°C target. In fact, they deliver us a 3°C rise in temperatures. This is simply not enough. I know from having been in Africa that people in the poorest countries are already living with climate change, and it is they who will pay the price if we do not act. So we have to get a proper commitment on the actual pledges on climate change. On the financing, as the minister said, it is not enough to say that we will commit. We have to see the money. I was in Turkey at the weekend, going to refugee camps, and I met the UN agencies. They are not getting the money that they have been pledged to help refugees now. We need to press on these points and deliver real money on the table.

name: Ian Duncan
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, if I may I will focus upon the COP discussions, where I think we have much to embrace and some challenges to meet.  Listening yesterday to Christiana Figueres, the UN negotiator, it was perfectly evident that her ambition of making the 2°C target is not going to be realised; 3°C was her best ambition. The reality is that that failure will be felt most keenly by those who can least afford to address the problems themselves. I had the pleasure, before the summer recess, of hosting here at Parliament two ambassadors, one from the Maldives and one from Vanuatu, and they were talking about the challenges that they face. For them, when people talk about 1°C, 2°C or 3°C, they are not thinking about it in terms of degrees; they are thinking about it in terms of feet and inches of water taking over their land, or indeed thinking of the Beaufort scale and the winds that sweep across some of those islands. Those are the challenges which we must be able to recognise. If we are not able to do so, the challenge will be very clear: migration will be a global problem and we will have to meet its challenges.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, 'Transforming our world', this is called the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development which, after two years of negotiations, we will approve on 25, 26 and 27 September in New York. The most important development with respect to the Millennium Goals is that the Sustainable Development Goals agenda does not create commitments that rich countries must meet in line with their foreign policies, but focuses on key sectors for countries. We went from having a development program to a much more holistic and effective approach. The great challenges we face right now, such as immigration and radical extremism, are rooted in a field paid for by poverty, inequality and corruption. We need to give shelter and an immediate humanitarian response to the thousands, the hundreds of thousands, the millions of refugees who are at the gates of our borders, but it is crucial to work on the origins of the problem. We have to go to the roots. And how? Demanding that the human rights clauses reflected in our trade agreements be respected; promoting good governance and transparency in those countries that need it most; promoting the participation of civil society in all democratic processes; ensuring that all of our policies pay special attention to those who have it most difficult, who are children and women; ensuring responsible and sustainable management of environmental resources; applying the principle of common but differentiated responsibilities; and, of course, giving priority to Article 208 of our Treaty, which is the principle of political coherence. All of the above is important, but we will only be credible if, as Democrats, we comply with the law and fulfill our own commitments, that is, with the right of asylum recognized and also with article 13 of the Declaration of Human Rights: the right to leave the country itself. Let us regain course, restore Europe of values and respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy and equality.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, let us not forget that we start from a failure. Fifteen years ago we set ourselves targets that we have not met. We fail because of the hypocrisy with which we implement our policies. In our trade relations with the Great South, human rights never prevail, even though they are on paper. Economic benefits always prevail. Fifteen years ago we were used to seeing hunger and misery in the southern countries. Unfortunately, that continues to happen, but inequality also increases in Europe. Austerity policies implemented from here have accentuated inequality and increased poverty. I will give only one fact: only 1% of the European population accumulates one third of the wealth. When we're in New York, let's not just hit each other in the chest. The new millennium goals are also for us. They must be a binding framework that guides all our policies, in and out. That is why I hope that the words of the Council and the Commission will not be wet paper. It's a matter of will. If you want, you can.

name: Maria Heubuch
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We Greens also welcome the adoption of the new 2030 Agenda, and we are, of course, pleased that the concept of sustainability has played a central role in this agenda. But in its implementation, this concept must not fall victim to growth orientation. And it is also very important that this agenda applies equally to developed and developing countries. I wonder: are we ready here in Europe? Yes, Mr Timmermans, policy coherence is crucial, and for the European Union and its Member States this means that they have to rethink and adapt their internal and external policies accordingly. I am thinking a little about our controversial trade strategies, about our agricultural policies, but also about the problem of tax evasion and illegal financial flows. And another point: progress must be measured. We very much hope that the UN Member States will be able to agree on a strong control system here that recognises, identifies and also proposes ways of improving.

name: Marco Affronte
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we too welcome the UN's commitment to replace the Millennium Goals with a new ambitious programme that will commit the international community to continue its fight against poverty and renew its commitment to sustainable development between now and 2030.  We are delighted that a working method has been chosen for the new agenda and its 17 points, involving broad participation: institutions, society and the world of science. We expect the Heads of State or Government to come forward with concrete and urgent commitments to begin to make this agenda a reality and in order to achieve the objectives we call on all governments to ensure adequate economic, human resources and full institutional support.  It is clear that one of the Sustainable Development Goals is the fight against climate change and all aspects related to it: the protection of the environment, ecosystems and biodiversity, sustainable use of marine resources. We can no longer talk about development without talking about climate change. That's why the New York summit is also intended to lay the groundwork for working for Paris as well.  An integrated approach between social, economic and environmental issues is needed in order to ensure the sustainability of development itself. There is a very strong link between climate change and human rights issues, because the former have serious consequences for the latter, poverty, quality of life, fundamental rights, climate migration, the real risks that Mr Duncan mentioned earlier. These are all things we are experiencing every day. That is why these issues will be discussed at COP21 21, where the principles of sustainable development will have to be integrated into the national policies and programmes of the countries and we hope that the will of the States to reach a binding agreement will be demonstrated.

name: Olaf Stuger
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – A government has only one way to get money in and that is through taxes. So the taxpayer is paying for the failures. The EU's failures are numerous, but I would mention three: refugee policy, climate policy and development aid. Now, in all its wisdom, the Commission has decided to combine these three problem cases, these three failures into an Über failure, and then it sticks to the picture of climate refugees. The taxpayers are fed up, they are done with the EU. They are no longer willing to pay for the cost of this naïve failure. I ask you: stop this nonsense, stop the waste and give the money back to the rightful owner. I want to end with a positive point, good news, because in the Netherlands it is possible to vote in a referendum. I hope to be able to announce soon in the name of GeenPeil that this referendum on the EU is going to take place.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The New York Summit will formally endorse the 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), which are an ambitious continuation of the Millennium Goals. Some of these assumptions have been achieved: the number of deaths from malaria or HIV has decreased, and already about eighty percent of children have access to education in Africa. However, the new targets aim to further encourage the fight against extreme poverty, the removal of social inequalities and action to reduce negative climate change. 2015 is also the European Year for Development, and the European Union has repeatedly reiterated its commitments to support development and provide adequate funding. It is all the more welcome that the Union and its Member States, as the largest donors of development aid in the world, set standards in this regard. I would also like to emphasise the important role played by innovative sources of development funding in the form of financial micro-statements, non-traditional taxes or public-private partnerships, which contribute effectively to achieving the Sustainable Development Goals after 2015. The current humanitarian crisis and the difficult international situation show even more that development aid is one of the key tools and a response to the challenges of the European Union's long-term strategy of overcoming the global development gap. In his last speech to the United Nations in September 1963, Kennedy, describing peace efforts, quoted Archimedes as saying, "Give me a point of support, and I will lift the Earth." Half a century after the then President of the United States delivered these words, our generation has a chance to decide on the shape of the future world. We must therefore ensure that the new development agenda, agreed by global leaders, is reflected in EU regulations and implemented in the form of common European policies.

name: Norbert Neuser (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very I think that the European Commission and also the European Parliament have done their homework in the run-up to the conference in New York. We have accompanied this for a number of years in the Committee on Development, and I think that, with the aim of sustainability, we have set a new accent on development policy. I would like to express my thanks to our Commissioner, Mimica, but also to his predecessor Piebalgs, who has accompanied this process for years. Whether we have ten goals or seventeen does not matter much. I believe that it is crucial that we develop a new spirit of solidarity between peoples, that we move away from the old way of thinking, that the rich north, the poor south, but we in the industrialised countries, in the European Union, are just as much called for. One final point: once we have done our homework, I also expect the Member States to do the same. This is a good thing to see the extent to which the Member States are actively involved financially in development cooperation.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Enthusiasts of the Paris Climate Summit believe that it will lead to a breakthrough on a global scale, as China has committed to something for the first time, although for now these are promises to reduce emissions in the future. Within ten to fifteen years, their emissions will increase. Other big emitters such as India, Brazil and Indonesia do not declare any restrictions. Developing countries account for nearly half of global emissions and are constantly increasing their emissions. China has quadrupled emissions, India has more than doubled. They justify, of course, the need to make up for civilisational retrials. Unfortunately, the principle of the Union's understanding of the need for developing countries to make up for civilisational delays is not applied to Member States of the European Union such as Poland, which is being forced to enter the path of decarbonisation, which affects economic development Polish and, above all, energy security Polish. Finally, the translation of the immigration crisis by climate change is the pinnacle of absurdity.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the millennium goals have not been achieved, and can be re-edited once and a thousand times, but if there are no changes in economic relations at the global level, they will never be achieved. It is absurd and illogical to seek to collaborate with the development of impoverished countries while being bleeded out of the collection of external debt, a debt incurred to try to escape the situation of poverty resulting from colonial exploitation; exploitation that, one way or another, still persists. For example, Sudan has an external debt of EUR 35 billion, receiving EUR 133 million per year of development aid; Mozambique, an external debt of 4.3 billion; development aid, 129 million. You are dedicated to patching your consciences, while en allow the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, on behalf of financial institutions, to continue to rob these countries of what is theirs. The best cooperation they could do is forgive the debt of these countries.

name: Bas Eickhout (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank Commissioner Timmermans for highlighting the point of coherence, because I very much agree that all the institutions can improve on coherence. In my previous term I was in the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development and the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety of this Parliament. It felt like two totally different worlds although we are the same Parliament. There is the problem, and I very much welcome seeing how we can address it. But since we are discussing coherence, is it also true for the Sustainable Development Goals? Many people are now talking as if this is only for developing countries, but these goals are also crucial for Europe. Sustainable access to water and reducing inequality are issues and challenges for us in Europe as well. I would also like to hear more concrete details from the Commission on what we are going to do to make sure that Europe achieves the Sustainable Development Goals.  Finally, to the Council: coherence is also about making Paris a success. How are we going to make sure that financing is delivered in Paris? Because, as Mary Robinson said, if Paris is going to fail we are going to fail on delivering on the Sustainable Development Goals. So financing is key, and where the Council really needs to deliver.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, it is unfortunate that the United Nations, as a body that began to protect and empower citizens of the world, has been reduced to a mere target-setter for member states. In next week’s conference in New York, heads of UN member states from all across the world will sign 17 development goals with 169 targets. Compare this to the eight millennium goals with 21 targets that they signed only 15 years ago. The goals were noble and meaningful, but not achieved. If we have been unable to achieve the eight, what makes anyone think that we can achieve the 17?  It is also unfortunate that the UN has decided to focus on the long term, rather than place its emphasis on what needs to be done right now. The camps in Lebanon, Jordan and Libya are full of Syrian refugees. They are weakly protected and there is a 59% funding gap in respect of what they need in order to house these people safely. There is no wonder, therefore, that refugees are forced into a double exodus, first fleeing Syria and then the camps themselves. If the UN are not looking after the refugees in the camps, is there any wonder the people are seeking a better life here in Europe?

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE).
text: – We do not seem to have any particular problems with defining ambitious targets. However, I would prefer that the common objectives were rather an expression of a common understanding of the problems and the will to solve them rather than the result of negotiations. A common diagnostic understanding is a necessary recognition that the world has turned in a conflicting direction over the last few years, undermining the achievement of the Millennium Goals. The issue of peace has come back to us because we have not achieved some of the key millennium goals. Our job is not just to set high goals. The key issue is how to ensure the political conditions for achieving the objectives at global, regional and national level. One of these conditions is the coherence of objectives, as the Vice-President, Mr Timmermans rightly pointed out. The second, and at least so important precondition, concerns Objective No 16, which is about working for peaceful and inclusive societies, which I would actually put first. The only way to make it happen is to live in peace and freedom, if they pay attention to everyone's dignity and to all identities, no matter how much. Only such companies can build a global partnership. We need entities that are sovereign and engaged promoters of the global development strategy. We don't just know poorly functioning countries today, we also know a lot of polarised and non-inclusion societies. I am grateful to our European representatives for stressing the importance of good governance in the process. The third premise is the integral concepts and integrated development strategies that follow the holistic understanding of the world.  I am very attentive to terminology and find that some of the keywords among the objectives are no longer found: freedom, democracy, dignity, identity are not explicitly mentioned, but are partly covered by other not terms.

name: Matthias Groote (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Frans Timmermans has just mentioned it: coherence. The spirit is willing, but the flesh is sometimes weak at the end of the day. We usually adopt very nice resolutions here in Parliament – including the COP conferences – and then, when the oath comes – and next year there will be an oath, namely the reform of the emissions trading system – then we must also, at the end of the day, jump over a higher stick. What you are seeing in Europe in particular, refugee flows – in total, almost 20 million people are on the run, half of them children. In Hungary, people with tear gas and water cannons are being prevented from coming to Europe to exercise their fundamental right to asylum on the border with Serbia. And if we are not careful, we will have up to 200 million climate refugees by 2050, according to a study by the University of Oxford. In this respect, let us act together, as the first Vice-President has just said. Coherent action, superior, and in terms of foreign policy, to make policy out of one piece, to let climate diplomacy prevail, to be able to do so in terms of development policy, in terms of environmental policy: then a shoe will come out of it.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I am a little surprised at the tones that are being struck here in part in the debate. On the left side of the house it sounds class-fighting. Then there is talk of a culture of colonial exploitation. Everything that is found in adversity and grievances and mismanagement in the Third World is projected onto evil capitalism. On the other side of the House, it is the case that aid for refugees is confused with development aid. And that's certainly a rough carver. It is really about development. And I think development is indeed something that we need to support, because the income gap in the world is still dramatic, and it is a challenge to the developed world. In this respect, it is good that the Western community in particular is still devoting itself to this objective. And if you set yourself more than one goal, if you set ten or seventeen goals, or a lot of sub-goals, so that you lose track completely, then that borders a little on absurdity, but does not change the good intention and the good cause. What is even more important, however, is that we reach agreement on the means. It is easy to formulate goals. But we must be able to take the right path. And I believe that we should not overestimate what we can achieve through state development aid. There are contributions that make sense to the development of countries, but the essential mechanism, as every empirical experience shows, is still that of free markets, that of competition, of self-driven innovation, which has led to considerable success, particularly in the Economies of South-East Asia, in large developing countries or in former developing countries, such as China or India or Indonesia. We must support these things. We must take note of the fact that, at the moment, it is much more than public capital that promotes development. That is why we must also create the appropriate framework conditions for this.

name: Elly Schlein (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in less than two weeks' time, the new agenda for sustainable development will be adopted in New York. It is important that in these negotiations, the European Union has been able to speak with one voice. Now we need to think about how we can turn the targets into reality, at a time when the dramatic situation of migrants is forcing us to reflect on the root causes, including climate change and a completely unsustainable level of global inequalities.  In order to achieve these objectives, governments need to invest much more resources in development policies and coherent policies. This is finally a universal agenda, which concerns us all and which requires us to rethink the way we live, produce and consume, because in terms of sustainable development all countries can be considered developing countries.  Profound changes in European and national policies will be needed to align with the new objectives on sustainability, inequality, education and gender equality. I would like to ask the Commissioner how the various Directorates-General are being coordinated for this purpose, and it will be crucial to set up appropriate monitoring and guardian systems, and I hope that Parliament will play a key role in this.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D).
text: Madam President, Mrs Presidents, this is quite a symbol: it is at the moment when we are redefining international development action that the most important international climate summit since Kyoto takes place. A few weeks before the New York conference on the post-2015 development goals and a few months before COP21 in Paris, we must make it clear: the objectives of the post-2015 agenda will be put at risk if we do not find a binding agreement in Paris. That is the meaning of what we are proposing in the report that you have been kind enough to point out, Minister, Mr President, earlier. In this European Parliament's report on COP21, we defend a legally binding agreement to limit the increase in temperature to two degrees, the establishment, as soon as possible, of an operational green fund of $100 billion each year to combat the effects of climate change and also the development of credible avenues to go beyond the simple contributions of development aid and thus feed the green fund with innovative financing. I therefore call on the countries negotiating the financial transaction tax to allocate part of this revenue to the fight against climate change.

name: Seb Dance (S&D).
text: – Madam President, tackling poverty and tackling climate change are of course two sides of the same coin. The UN’s sustainable development agenda cannot be considered in isolation from the wider conversation on COP 21. An essential component in tackling both the eradication of poverty and climate change is financing. I am hugely encouraged by the words of the First Vice-President today when he says that private finance can, and must, play a significant role in the financing of both development and climate. The huge disparity that exists in different countries’ ability to finance and muster financial resources means that we cannot rely solely on public sources of financing. We all have a role to play in both tackling climate change and tackling poverty. This is why we must ensure that all industries, regardless of the sector – whether they be private or public – play a role, and that they contribute to solving the problem and do not undermine it.

name: Pedro Silva Pereira (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the compromise reached in Ababa at the Conference on Financing for Development was an important step on the road to the post-2015 agenda, but it fell far short of the needs in terms of concrete financial commitments. The same is true of the response of the international community and the European Union to the tragedy of refugees, not only in humanitarian reception, but above all in responding to the causes of these desperate migration flows.  Too much talk, too much emotion, many minutes of silence, little solidarity, little development cooperation, little concrete action. If, in New York and Paris, in the conferences that will follow, this happens again, then these conferences will pass alongside the meeting with history and will be regrettably a missed opportunity. We need concrete, binding and verifiable commitments. I hope that the European Union can be one voice on the right side and up to its responsibilities.

name: Jo Leinen (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Vice-President Timmermans, there was once an EU sustainability strategy. It has disappeared, to my regret, in the sinking. Do you not think that we need to identify a new sustainability strategy in order to show how we are implementing the 17 objectives and to combine all facets of policy? The fact that if everyone were to operate in the same way as the EU, we would need 2.6 planets. So, our ecological footprint is far too high. We need not only decarbonisation, but also dematerialisation. So not only an energy transition, but also a material turnaround. And I hope that the circular economy package will also become very concrete, both in the timetables and in the objectives. We must have concrete targets for 2030. We have proposed 30% less material consumption. Mr President-in-Office of the Council, what are you doing to ensure that the Member States fulfil their commitments, namely to abolish subsidies that are harmful to the environment, and finally to meet the 0.7% of development aid that has long been promised?

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: –  A Uachtaráin, mar rapóirtéir ón gCoiste um Thionsclaíocht, um Thaighde agus um Fhuinneamh (ITRE) i dtaca le COP 21, caithfidh mé a rá gur chuir sé beagáinín déistine orm Feisirí a bheith ag rá nach féidir linn an t-athrú aeráide a choimeád faoi 2– C; daoine ag rá go mbeadh an sprioc suas le 3– C. Más mar sin a bheidh, is iad na tíortha bochta atá ag iarraidh forbairt a bheidh thíos leis.  Dar liom féin, caithfimid a bheith dóchasach; má chomhlíonfaimid ár ndualgais féin do 2020, 2030 agus 2050 is féidir linn brú a chur ar na tíortha móra – an tSín, Na Stáit Aontaithe agus an India – a ndualgais siúd a chomhlíonadh. Ba chóir go mbeadh muid in ann an t-athrú aeráide agus an t-ardú a choimeád faoi bhun 2– C. Ní féidir glacaint lena mhalairt.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D).
text: – Madam President, as this Parliament’s rapporteur on corporate responsibility, I would like to welcome SDG 12 and, in particular, Target 12.6 on sustainability reporting, and ask Commissioner Timmermans to defend and promote this text.  I have to say that this is less than the text of the 2002 World Summit, which called for intergovernmental initiatives, and the Rio+20 Summit, which called to build on existing initiatives. Indeed, it is less than the binding rules that Ban Ki-moon himself asked for last December, and for which we in Parliament voted in our committee opinion on the private sector and development earlier this year. Bloomberg found that three in four companies do no sustainability reporting. If governments were only encouraged to meet targets, surely that would not be good enough. Many in business agree and want to do more. I thank UN negotiator Amina Mohammed for allowing me to say this directly, even if the final text of the SDGs could go further. In Europe we can still showcase our own achievements on non-financial reporting – a directive – adopt the tracker developed by the GRI to encourage third country governments to implement this target, and maintain the holistic approach which businesses say they want in seeking to pursue the objectives of integrated reporting and of long-term investment.

name: Charles Goerens (ALDE).
text: Madam President, I would like to express some reservations about the optimism that has just been expressed by some of my colleagues. I do not share this optimism for the simple reason that we have serious problems with funding and compatibility with the commitments made within the framework of the European development consensus. I would like to remind you that we are far below the commitments made, in particular the 0.7% of public development aid in relation to the gross domestic product. We are falling far short of the commitments already announced in Monterey at the conference that preceded the Addis Ababa conference. In addition, new funds, including the Trust Fund, are still being announced, which ultimately means undressing Pierre to dress Paul. We are going to scrape the Commission's drawer funds and we are appealing to the Member States which, I said, are far below the commitments they have made. When are we going to stop this inconsistency and finally rely on the commitments we made, in the most solemn way, in 2005?

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, Mr Schmit, Mr Timmermans, empty speech, just a small amount of money to keep everything as it is, so that elites and rich countries continue to accumulate and for poor countries to remain poor. Putting solutions goes through proposals to distribute wealth, to allow the countries of the south and the periphery to own their resources—they have not spoken of this; it is also about reducing our level of consumption, nor have they said anything; it goes through the decline in the face of the growth of which they speak permanently. Emissions reduction: you have talked about the role of sustainable agriculture, but what you are doing is not sustainable agriculture. Sustainable agriculture is totally incompatible with the industrialization of production, with liberalization, with free trade agreements, with TTE, with fisheries agreements. Supporting small and medium-sized exploitation, agro-ecological production modes and short marketing circuits is a solution.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Combating climate change is one of the important sustainability objectives and also one of the very important objectives in the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. Europe is at the forefront of this. The binding commitment to reduce 40% CO2 by 2030 is a leading approach here. Other countries are not as binding. China is committed, but not binding. The US sets guidelines, but not bindingly. In total, only 26 countries have submitted national contributions to climate change reduction for COP 21. More than 140 countries have not yet submitted any contributions at all, including many developing countries and many countries, emerging countries, which have a very high pollution potential, such as Turkey, India, Brazil or even Indonesia.  If there is funding of USD 100 billion per year by 2020, would it not be coherent to say that the allocation of financial resources to the poorest countries in the field of climate change is linked to the fact that these countries also submit binding plans on how to eliminate climate change?

name: Νότης Mαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, poverty eradication is the central objective of the United Nations Summit on Sustainable Development. But how can poverty and hunger be eradicated when the overwhelming part of the countries' state budgets in Africa, Asia, Latin America and Europe go to servicing public debt? A debt not created to serve social needs, but to enrich international loan sharks. The only way to achieve the objective of eradicating poverty is through the process of writing off the shameful debt. The UN General Assembly voted a few days ago in favour of a resolution on the basic rules for restructuring public debt. Unfortunately, however, the European Union, but also states such as Greece, Ireland and Spain, instead of voting for the resolution abstained. However, the audit of the debt and the consequent write-off of the shameful debt is provided for within the euro area by Regulation No 136/66/EEC. 472/2013 and must finally be applied to Greece. So write off the shameful debt of all countries!

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I do apologise if my brief speech interrupts the chatter of Members coming into the Chamber.  First of all, I would like to thank Parliament for its support for the constructive cooperation over the years. We need to continue doing that. I think that is showing leadership and I am really grateful to Parliament.  Secondly, I want to pick up on the point that we need to be coherent. I heard a lot of support for that point, and indeed our internal coherence in the Union will have to be reflected, for instance, in the way we present our plans for a sustainable economy, that is, for the circular economy, in the way we develop the Energy Union, in the way we use the tremendous possibilities of the European Fund for Strategic Investment. If we are not coherent with these very important instruments, then we will lose the effect on the outside world, the effect we want to attain, so I fully agree with Mr Eickhout on that point. Sometimes we are shamed by the private sector. I have to say in some of these areas private companies, private investors, are more forward-looking than politicians and governments, because sometimes they take a longer view of the economic cycle than we as politicians do, and in some areas strong cooperation with the private sector could help us be better at creating a sustainable economy, and also in sustainable development.  I offer my cooperation to Parliament to jointly break down silos. We both have that problem still today. I leave it to the governments to take care of their own problems, but we as institutions should certainly cooperate in that field and I will be at your disposal to look for ways of improving that. Once again let us work together to make first New York a success and then, of course, COP 21 in Paris.

name: PUHEMIES. –
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. – The Socialists welcome the draft resolution on the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). This document shows the interest that UN Member States have in giving real political impetus to global development efforts. But only with intentions will we not be able to implement real policies for change. That is why the Socialists have asked the Member States of the European Union to lead a coherent position in the UNFPA (25-27 September) and in Paris (COP 21). We need global and coherent action in the face of current social, economic, human development, migration, displaced and climate change challenges; and ensure sufficient means, including 0.7% of GNI and other innovative sources, to meet the 17 targets and their 169 targets, as well as the $100 billion for the fight against climate change. We are all responsible for universal progress towards true human and sustainable development. That is why we Socialists are asking Member States to implement a roadmap for the implementation of the SDGs and the agreements on the reduction of C02 to leave Paris.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. – The Socialists welcome the draft resolution on the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). This document shows the interest that UN Member States have in giving real political impetus to global development efforts. But only with intentions will we not be able to implement real policies for change. That is why the Socialists have asked the Member States of the European Union to lead a coherent position in the UNFPA (25-27 September) and in Paris (COP 21). We need global and coherent action in the face of current social, economic, human development, migration, displaced and climate change challenges; and ensure sufficient means, including 0.7% of GNI and other innovative sources, to meet the 17 targets and their 169 targets, as well as the $100 billion for the fight against climate change. We are all responsible for universal progress towards true human and sustainable development. That is why we Socialists are asking Member States to implement a roadmap for the implementation of the SDGs and the agreements on the reduction of C02 to leave Paris.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. The next UN summit will have the important objective of adopting the new Sustainable Development Agenda 2015-2030, which is the first global pact for human development and the protection of the planet. The scope and ambition of the new agenda, which involves aligning all EU and Member State policies with the Sustainable Development Goals (SDOs), make it necessary to introduce participatory governance mechanisms that ensure civil society plays a strong role in the implementation, monitoring and review of the SDOs. Indeed, the new agenda must become an integral part of the contract between people, including civil society and responsible companies, and their governments, on the basis of the principles of transparency and participation. In order to successfully achieve the Sustainable Development Goals, the EU institutions will need to step up their efforts to create greater social coherence at a time of slow growth and high unemployment, leading to less solidarity between citizens. Only with a development model capable of producing positive effects not only in terms of profit, but also in social, cultural and environmental terms, can the Sustainable Development Goals be achieved.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. – The draft declaration of the UN General Assembly, to be discussed at its next meeting, sets ambitious targets for the sustainable development of humanity, such as eradicating poverty and hunger, protecting the natural environment and building peace in human societies. However, this text does not address the fundamental problem which defines everything else, namely the rapid growth of the human population on Earth, focusing on the countries of the so-called third world. With today's levels of technology and economic activity, we need two or more planets the size and natural resources of the Earth to survive its current population in the long run. If UN member states seriously mean their grandiose declarations of sustainable development, then it is necessary to limit births in the third world by emancising women, informing them of methods of precaution and facilitating access to them. Moreover, it is necessary for economically developed countries to finance the creation of basic social security systems in the poorest countries of the third world so that families there cease to see childbearing as a substitute for old-age insurance.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. – The stakes of this upcoming deal in Paris are environmental but not exclusively. We have to negotiate for very strong mitigation commitments; commitments that drive collective actions and send a clear signal to all stakeholders to move towards low-carbon economies and societies in the coming decades. However, at the same time, we must also talk about adaptation. Climate change can significantly enhance the competition for resources, such as food, water and grazing lands, and can become the biggest driver of population displacements. Therefore, adaptation to the adverse impacts of climate change is necessary for all countries to minimise negative effects and to make full use of the opportunities for climate resilient growth and sustainable development. Combating climate change contributes to combating poverty, inequalities and food security, and to fighting for development and peace. Therefore, the EU has an essential role to play in the Paris negotiations. We have the responsibility to ensure that the voices of the poorest, most vulnerable countries are heard. And we need to stand for more financial and technological support for them.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The so-called coherence of development policies requires, among other things: 1) the rejection of the mechanisms of sashes and domination, such as external debt and its service; 2) the rejection of the so-called structural adjustment programs of the IMF and the World Bank; 3) the rejection of policies of liberalisation and deregulation of world trade; 4) the rejection of the libertine movement of capital and its criminal points of support, such as tax havens; 5) and a strengthened and genuine development aid policy.  The degradation of nature and the change of a number of important natural balances, including climate change, as well as poverty, social exclusion, unemployment and economic recession and ruin, are different dimensions in which the profound crisis of capitalism is expressed as a dominant mode of economic and social organisation on a global scale. There is no possible sustainability in the framework of an intrinsically unfair, unequal, oppressive and predatory system of nature and its resources. It is from the radical rupture with this system that the solution to the hearty problems with which our planet is struggling will emerge.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. – Climate change and the environment: Climate change not only negatively affects the environment, but also negatively affects development and human rights, intensifies poverty and threatens people's livelihoods. In countries that are already vulnerable and prone to conflict, climate change is another factor complicating existing humanitarian, development and security challenges. The new Development Agenda 2015-2030 must respect the social, economic and environmental aspects of sustainable development, accentuate the eradication of poverty, ensure basic standards of decent life, democracy and the rule of law, with particular regard to women's empowerment and gender equality. A reliable framework for monitoring, accountability and evaluating the achievement of sustainable development objectives is an integral part of the post-2015 agenda. The main objective of COP21 is to adopt an international agreement on climate change that will make it possible to keep global warming below 2 °C and to arrive at a series of important decisions in the fight against climate change and the financing of activities to combat climate change.

name: Adam Gierek (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I dedicate these words to the participants of COP 21 in Paris. Climate change leads to extreme events – violent floods and catastrophic droughts. The great resources currently being spent on reducing greenhouse gas emissions are not able to reverse these trends. The climate discussion has been dominated by the issue of emissions of these gases, while the issue of adaptation to climate change is becoming pressing, and it is – and it is a pity – being pushed back to the fore. If it is true that it is greenhouse gas emissions that have led to adverse climate change (this thesis has not been proven by the IPCC), then the issue of reducing them, but also ways to increase the absorption capacity of our world, should be discussed at the planned conference. The recent drought in Europe and later flooding is a clear alarm signal. This is an indication of the need to revalue the EU's climate policy, which should focus more on adaptation methods, including afforestation, climate change mitigation and on this, and not just on reducing CO2 emissions, the main financial resources should be channelled. In the case Polish, this means a return to ambitious concepts known as the unfortunately unrealized "Vistula Programme". This programme was mainly aimed at alleviating the tendency to make large areas of Polish, to protect drinking water for future generations of Poles and to protect the country from floods.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I believe that in the ongoing discussions, including in the European Parliament, about the Millennium Development Goals or the following Sustainable Development Goals, each of us has seen these objectives mainly through the prism of a human sense of the need to help those most in need. The migration crisis that is currently affecting Europe shows clearly how much the modern world is based on interdependence. If we do not seek to combat poverty effectively, and if we do not support peace processes, we can suffer the serious consequences of the absence of such action. That is why I consider it particularly important to commit – not only politically but also financially – to achieving the new SDGs. In this context, I consider it highly risky for the Council to reduce commitments and payments in the draft budget for 2016 under Heading IV entitled 'Global Europe'.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. - The UN Sustainable Development Summit in New York must answer why the fight against poverty and climate change is unsuccessful. The results are poor and the achievement of the Millennium Goals has remained only an unfulfathing dream of great ambitions. COP 21 will be crucial for the future of countries that rightly expect our assistance and partnership. The European Union should also think about targeted assistance to countries that are often a source of crises such as the migrant crisis at the moment. As this crisis is expected to persist significantly, targeted investments are gaining even more prominance.

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. – 2015 offers an unusual opportunity: a number of key UN summits coincide, including the Development Finance Summit, the 2030 Sustainable Development Agenda and the Summit setting out the Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) and the 21st Meeting of the Parties to the Framework Convention on Climate Change in Paris (COP21). The main objective of the latter is to keep the increase in average earth temperatures within 2°C in order to avoid irreversible changes and disasters resulting from climate change, while SDG's aim is, inter alia, to eradicate poverty by 2030.  These objectives, and more broadly, the issues of climate change, development and sustainable development cannot be separated – it is enough to think of climate refugees leaving their homes due to drought, food shortages and natural disasters. As stressed by the High Level Advisory Board within the UN, in order not to weaken each other, one coherent framework focusing on human dignity and human rights should be considered, with ambitious, binding and mutually reinforcing objectives, transparent implementation frameworks, milestones and feedback opportunities.  This is also the direction the EU must consistently represent and take decisive steps to achieve a sustainable, flexible and climate-resilient world economy that goes beyond conventional energy sources. Local actors (including indigenous peoples living in the most vulnerable areas) should be involved in the transformation, building on their knowledge and adaptability. Proportionate funding, technology transfer and capacity building are also essential.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. – The Socialists welcome the draft resolution on the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). This document shows the interest that UN Member States have in giving real political impetus to global development efforts. But only with intentions will we not be able to implement real policies for change. That is why the Socialists have asked the Member States of the European Union to lead a coherent position in the UNFPA (25-27 September) and in Paris (COP 21). We need global and coherent action in the face of current social, economic, human development, migration, displaced and climate change challenges; and ensure sufficient means, including 0.7% of GNI and other innovative sources, to meet the 17 targets and their 169 targets, as well as the $100 billion for the fight against climate change. We are all responsible for universal progress towards true human and sustainable development. That is why we Socialists are asking Member States to implement a roadmap for the implementation of the SDGs and the agreements on the reduction of C02 to leave Paris.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. – As the situation in the Mediterranean has deteriorated dramatically, I think that the UN and the new Sustainable Development Goals should adopt a strong stand to reflect the enormity of the migration crisis. This crisis is no longer a single-country problem, indeed it is no longer a uniquely European problem, it is an international problem affecting everyone both inside and outside the Union.  Migration is a symptom not the cause and in the long run Europe and the UN need to address the cause at its origin. Europe and the UN need to combine efforts to ascertain that all those people have a future in their own country, by ensuring that the millions of euros pumped into economies – like those in African countries – are used for the benefit of their citizens to build sustainable economies, health services, and educational facilities and create jobs. We need a global response to address the situation and focus on solving the root cause of migration, tackling the violence in Libya, Syria, the Middle East and sub-Saharan Africa and solving the causes that are forcing people to flee their homes, otherwise we would set ourselves up for even greater problems in the future.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. – In the European year of development, we faced numerous difficulties brought to us by our race for better technological capabilities, strong industry and strong economic parameters. Only after we left some of the financial difficulties behind us did problems of a primarily social and moral character come to light. The objectives to be adopted next week during the UN summit are aligned with the objectives of the European Union. I emphasise the need for an agenda such as the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development so that as a group of globally interdethical political actors we have clearly set priorities and objectives that we must work on to end poverty in all its forms. But apart from the clear and visible guidance we need to have on problems on the social and economic fronts, there are a number of different, perhaps European countries of unknown problems, that we are likely to face in the future. Therefore, and in the hope that all Member States of the conference to be held from 25 to 27 September are equally dedicated to addressing all the difficulties that the future brings us, it is extremely important to follow the guidelines of the Meeting in New York, as they represent the same values that the European Union represents.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – 2015 will go down in history as the year of the definition of the 17 Sustainable Development Goals, set at a UN summit in New York (USA), held from 25 to 27 September. This is the new agenda for action until 2030, which is based on the progress and lessons learned from the 8 Millennium Development Goals between 2000 and 2015, many of which have been unfulfilled.  This agenda, the result of the joint work of governments and citizens around the world to create a new global model to end poverty, promote prosperity and the well-being of all, protect the environment and combat climate change, is now confronted with a failed economic system that has already become part of the problem and not the solution. As long as the economic power of multinational enterprises is overdue with the political sovereignty of peoples and nations, all pious intentions will run into the interests of high finance that does not hesitate to resort to war to ensure its dominance and survival. Until the people get up.

name: El Presidente. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the basis of the Commission Declaration on the Decision adopted on 15 July 2015 on the summer energy package (2015/2736(RSP)).

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, first I would like to thank you for the invitation to address you today. I know that my colleague, Commissioner Arias Cañete, was here in July, when he presented the summer package, and that Parliament held an in-depth discussion with him in both the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE) and the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI). I will therefore try to avoid technicalities and explain what makes the summer package such an important milestone in the Energy Union’s roadmap. In fact, the summer package illustrates the Commission’s determination to decarbonise our economy and to give consumers and our citizens a central role in Europe’s energy transition. As Members will know, in the past months I have been visiting our Member States in the framework of the Energy Union tour. I have had a lot of meetings with national and local governments, market stakeholders, civil society organisations and citizens.  I can report back to Parliament that, having already visited almost half of the EU Member States, many concerns and ideas which have come up are very similar, regardless of geography. These concerns include the citizens’ and companies’ interest in having the possibility of producing their own energy without insurmountable bureaucratic hurdles, and also using this to lower the price of their energy bills at the same time. I also heard the clear call from industries for regulatory stability and predictability in the investment climate. I think that we all agree on the need to boost innovation in the market and address the drop in carbon prices. Therefore, I am very glad to say that the four elements of the summer package directly address these concerns. The new electricity market design will provide a truly European dimension to security of supply. It will offer clear price signals, facilitating investment and better integration of renewables. It will promote regional cooperation on energy policies and support schemes to renewables. Our upcoming proposals will also take into account the ongoing competition sector inquiry on capacity mechanisms. The new deal for consumers will make sure that lower wholesale prices are really rolled over to consumers’ bills, empowering them to know more, choose more and, above all, produce more energy by themselves. Knowing more also means an up-to-date system of energy efficiency labelling. Finally, the revision of the EU Emissions Trading System (EU ETS) for post-2020 reflects our deep commitment to decarbonisation and to the COP 21 Conference in Paris. This is in line with President Juncker’s priorities and with Parliament’s priorities in the area of climate policy and attaining our climate goals. It is very important to know that carbon leakage provisions will also continue for the post-2020 period and that the free allocation will be provided at adequate levels. However, we also have to underline that the number of free allowances available under the EU ETS is limited and will continue to decrease. Therefore, we must use free allowances in a smart way and in such a way as to ensure a healthy and innovative industry in the European Union. We will also continue supporting the development of low carbon innovation through an Innovation Fund and will modernise our energy industry in lower—income Member States through the new Modernisation Fund. This package is the first of an ambitious list of legislative proposals which we presented on the energy union roadmap. By the end of next year we will deliver 90% of these actions because we want to make sure we have enough time to work on the proposals with Parliament and with the Council, to turn them into actual legislation before the end of the Commission’s mandate.  The summer package was therefore presented just two months ago. This week we adopted the Strategic Energy Technology (SET) Plan, which was very much anticipated, especially by the research community. The SET Plan is, however, only the first step towards a comprehensive research and innovation strategy, including energy, but also transport and industrial policy. Let me conclude by saying that, in order to keep up this pace and to maintain our ambitious plan, we need to continue strengthening the dialogue we have between Parliament and the Commission. For all these reasons, I would be happy to pursue this exchange of views in November, following the adoption of the State of the Energy Union report. As a reminder, this will be the first edition of an annual report on our overall assessment of how we are coping with all five dimensions of the Energy Union.  I know that Members are working hard on Parliament’s Energy Union report. We have already had quite a few very fruitful exchanges in the preparation of this report and I am very much looking forward to continuing this contact before – and especially, after – the adoption of the report.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the – Mr President, Commissioner, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent work. There are people who say that the whole policy is a circus. What do we see in the circus?
