If this were circus grass, there would be a rope stretched from one side of the hall to the other, and one could walk on that rope, trying not to fall to the right or to the left—somehow to get ahead. In fact, what we colleagues need to do with this creation of an energy union - and thank you to the Commission for the concrete first four proposals that have now emerged - we must walk along this rope without falling to the right or to the left. In this case, the 'right, left' would mean that, on the one hand, we need to balance the need to promote the competitiveness of the European Union: prices, energy prices and so on, and, on the other hand, we need to think about reducing CO2 emissions. We can't enter one ditch and fall or the other ditch and fall off because, friends beloved, we don't know if this network is underneath us. So with all due respect to the Commission, that at last these concrete proposals are.  Colleagues, this is a big challenge for us, but there are not only, as they say, these internal considerations here: competitiveness, CO2 emissions, but also external considerations. So what happens to our energy security? In the European Union, we know that we are very dependent on imports. And what makes me apprehensive is that my group is apprehensive, and the news recently emerged that Gazprom has entered into an agreement with several large European union energy companies on the expansion of the so-called Nord Stream 2, which would actually expand, deepen Europe's dependence on a single supplier. So I also call on the European Commission to raise the issue of this aspect and to consider whether this is not in the interests of European consumers.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – In these uncertain times, it is important that we can show that the European Union has added value. I do not want to make too many connections between the dramatic humanitarian crisis we are facing and the energy union, but there are. First of all, because energy is the theme on which we must prove during this parliamentary term that Europe has added value. But also because this energy union is a holistic approach to climate, energy security and also social aspects, such as the price that people pay. In this way, we can ensure that people see a future in that European project again and also make a link with the climate. I think that is extremely important. I think it is very important that we have a Commission that does what it promises. Commissioner Šefčovič, together with his colleagues, promised at the beginning of the parliamentary term that the Commission would work on the Energy Union. That concept is now in place, and at the moment we in Parliament are discussing it at length in order to strengthen it. But the Commissioner has also said that I am systematically coming up with packages to actually implement the energy union, and since June the first package has been in place. That is not an insignificant package. There are some technical files in there, but that is important to propping up the whole. In the introduction, you did not happen to pay much attention to the emissions trading system. This is also an extremely important dossier for this Parliament and for my group, and I am glad that it is there. We are going to discuss it at length in Parliament, but it has ambition and it is important that it is there now, in the run-up to COP 21. In so doing, we in the European Union are proving that we are in favour of adapting our own legislation in such a way that it becomes more efficient. This also applies, of course, to the other dossiers in the summer package, such as the energy labelling directive, which focuses on consumers and which aims to lead them to the right choices. That has nothing to do with regulation, that has to do with the right vision. The same applies to the "new deal" for consumers or the new market design. This is a somewhat technical but no less important dossier, and for our group, energy efficiency and renewable energy are again at the heart of the discussion. I would like to thank the Commissioner and I wish us a lot of intensive work over the coming months to prove to the outside world that we are also pursuing a really strong policy with the Energy Union.

name: Marek Józef Gróbarczyk
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The Commission's proposal for the Summer Energy Package aims to build a common energy policy. This is essential in the light of the agreed Energy Union, which aims to ensure equal treatment, solidarity and security between Member States in terms of energy supply. However, we were surprised to hear of the construction of a new northern gas pipeline "Nord Stream 2" connecting Russia and Germany, which will supply another fifty-five billion cubic meters of Russian gas. It is astonishing that the largest companies in the European Union are involved in the project. The biggest surprise, however, is due to the fact that this investment was financed through Deutsche Bank, Germany. This action completely undermines the diversification of gas supply and completely undermines the idea of an Energy Union. The question is, is this the building of the Energy Union?

name: Fredrick Federley
text: On the other: – Mr President, Commissioner Šefčovič, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his excellent We have a great many important acts now relating to the Energy Union. I think it is so clear how good we have been in the European Union to create a common market for everything that is physical products. For everything we can put in a box, put on a truck and drive to another country, we have a well-functioning market. But when it comes to, for example, more intangible things or energy, we have not succeeded at all. This means that in some parts of the European Union we have a surplus of energy that we cannot sell to our neighbours. It means that we have energy losses. This means that we have financial losses and we also have environmental losses. In the North Pole area, which concerns Scandinavia and now also the Baltic states, we have come much further on the road. We have now also got a cable in place for Mr Kariņš in Lithuania. It will work and be operational from December 15. This means that we create greater energy security. This means that we create greater incentives in Sweden to continue to produce more green energy that we can sell to our friends in Lithuania. It also creates a better economy throughout the North Pole region. While we are creating the common market, I think it is important that we do not get too messy in the details. It will look very different in different parts of the European Union in terms of the type of energy mix and we must continue to be a national competence. What we have to do, however, is to deal with the general rules. Make sure the interconnectivity works. That we get functioning market systems. But also that the control system that is so important for the climate in ets works better. Here we can see how, as Mr Van Brempt mentioned, we worked hard with the MSR to get it in place and get a better order. I think we need to do more here. The system needs to be simpler. It needs to be more market-oriented, but there must also be a mechanism in the system that means that when we have large surpluses, allowances disappear from the market so that we steer in the direction that we need going forward.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, Mr Eef-Soviet, the energy union, which you intend to reduce European external dependence, really only means a change of suppliers, but not a model. Let us not deceive ourselves, you continue to bet on optimizing the so-called emissions exchange system, which commodies and enshrines the right to pollute massively, and, in parallel, devote hundreds of billions to building pharaonic works of gas and oil infrastructure. Its proposal is an ultra-pollution, hypercentralised model, concentrator of concessions around a small number of large construction companies and conducive to geostrategic tensions and conflicts that cause humanitarian disasters, such as those we are seeing these days. If you really want a safe, sustainable, democratic and socially acceptable energy union, bet on a distributed energy model, based on renewable energy, that allows us to effectively tackle the scourge of energy poverty affecting more than eleven million Europeans and Europeans.

name: Claude Turmes
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner, the Energy Union can only work if every country does not fight to the last millimetre for its national energy mix. That is why I welcome the fact that you are personally committed to regional cooperation – and we have just strengthened your back here in Parliament by voting in this direction. It is also important – and rightly so – that the focus should be on renewable energies and energy efficiency, on the one hand now through the Labelling Directive and, on the other, in market design. Your paper is also very much inspired by what is currently being discussed in Germany. And we need to organise a flexible electricity market around renewableenergy, wind and solar energy.  What is still missing from your proposals are two things: one is a fair market. Where is the Commission's position on provisions for nuclear power stations? It cannot be the case that, even in a country such as Germany, at some point 30, 40, 50 billion will have to be raised by the taxpayer and that the operators of nuclear power stations will not pay and have an unfair advantage in an internal market that is supposed to be fair.  And the second thing that is missing – and that united us with our colleagues from Eastern Europe: this proposal to double Nord Stream is a provocation! This is an unacceptable provocation and I would like to see clear words from you, Commissioner. This project cannot be carried out at this stage and you must help to stop it!

name: David Coburn
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the ETS has been in place for 10 years and has totally failed to deliver the intended price signals in the market. Despite repeated tweaking – back—loading and the market stability reserve – along with other green measures it has forced up energy prices, undermined competitiveness and driven energy—intensive industries out of the EU altogether. Often these go to jurisdictions with lower environmental standards, and that arguably drives up emissions.  We have a policy that undermines our economy, costs jobs and closes plants, and yet which may add to atmospheric CO2. We have been obliged to offer derogations to energy—intensive industries to mitigate the effects of carbon leakage, but this negates a large part of the ETS system and leaves small and medium-sized businesses carrying the burden.  Why is it that we in this House, and other EU institutions, seem to be incapable of facing reality and admitting we were wrong? Here we are yet again tweaking a failed ETS system. Why do we not have the courage to say, sorry guys, we meant well, but the ETS has comprehensively failed. We will scrap it and go back to the drawing board. Just for once, let us recognise reality and apply some common sense, which is something very rare in this Parliament. It is high time we did it.

name: Barbara Kappel
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner, I would like to stress that I strongly support your tour of the Member States. The fact that you have spoken not only with the national parliaments, but with the stakeholders in the countries, is positive, because it gives you a better view of what is actually needed in the Member States. Whether this summer package will be a milestone for the implementation of the Energy Union, as you said today, I would like to wait for legislative implementation. Let me explain this by referring to the four key elements of this summer package. Reorganization of energy labeling. Yes, it is good if consumers have easier access, if this is simplified. But please bear in mind that there will be more and much more administrative burdens for retailers and producers if all this has to be done anew. This is not better regulation. A positive point is the new deal for consumers. The second point of the package is that if energy becomes cheaper and when people use less energy, this is a positive thing. If you take action here, with more information, that is a good thing. The third point is rather critical. New energy market design – yes, we need this for a reorganisation of the electricity market. But what it will look like – you are now saying public consultation – will be shown by the implementation. So first the consultation and then the implementation. And ETS – as has been mentioned – is really very, very bad and will lead to a huge loss of jobs in Europe if it is implemented as it stands now. In Austria alone, in my own country, we have studies which assume that 60 000 jobs will be lost in the energy-intensive industry. And that is not what we want!

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Summer this year was cool for the first three weeks. I had about fifty meetings on the coast. I met about ten thousand people, and when I said it was cold because the Union is fighting global warming, everyone was roaring with laughter. It doesn't come to anyone's mind that two trillion swept away, have anything to do with temperature. And they're right.  The question is why these two trillions were thrown down the drain. The first concept is that gazprom agents are here, because the strange thing about the atom is bad, coal is bad and shale gas is bad, and what Gazprom delivers, which is oil and gas, is good.  The second concept – it seems two trillion euros, ten percent goes to the one who makes the order. They are simply bribes. If there is a European public prosecutor's office – we are demanding a European prosecutor's office – we will report it to the public prosecutor's office to see if there is bribery here.  The third, only possible common policy is that everyone buys what is cheapest. And that is the only proper common policy.

name: Peter Liese (PPE).
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to congratulate the Commission on the summer package it has presented. I believe that the proposal on emissions trading in particular is ambitious and it was important that it came before the summer recess. Climate change must still be at the top of our agenda. In view of the dramatic refugee crisis that we are experiencing, John Kerry, the US Secretary of State, has said that we must take active action against climate change, otherwise we will see even greater refugee movements in the future as a result of climate change. But how we do it, we have to discuss exactly. We want at least 40% CO2 reduction. And the Commission is already putting a very heavy burden on some sectors with its proposal. When I think of the fact that, for example, steel and cement, the reduction potential is very limited, even physically, and they still have to bring a 43% reduction in the package – ETS must bring more than non-ETS – we have to see if we can find other shoulders that can support it. I still believe that we need to do more in air transport. Nor does what happens to the International Civil Aviation Organisation really help us. It cannot be the case that steel and cement bring minus 43% and air transport is virtually nothing. Take a look at this and then improve! Finally, a sentence on labeling. Here, too, I welcome the European Commission's proposals. A labeling measure will enter into force next week on the basis of the old legal basis. In the case of heating equipment, what happens next week alone will save us as much energy as 47 nuclear power plants produce. So, energy efficiency has huge potential. And then we can save money. We can then put the money into our industry and our craftsmen who make energy efficiency, and we do not need to send it to Putin or to the oil sheikhs, who, unfortunately, are also financing things that cause us great problems. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: the blue card. – Dear colleague, I would like to ask you this question. By 2020, countries are set targets to achieve a certain level of renewable energy, and already today a number of countries have reached that level and are complacent and are not doing anything else. How do you think it is appropriate to give new tasks now and not wait for 2020?

name: Peter Liese (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I hope I understood the question correctly because the interpretation was somewhat delayed. So I believe that we are still on a relatively good path in terms of renewable energy for the period up to 2020. But the Commission, as guardian of the Treaties, must keep looking at this. There are problems in some Member States and the existing law must be respected. Personally, I believe that we also need a policy beyond 2020. I am not yet so convinced that the new approach that the Commission is discussing is better than what we have had so far. There is room for improvement. But we really need to have a legal system that gives the parties planning certainty.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D).
text: – Mr President, what we are discussing today is decisively the first step towards achieving the Energy Union Strategy and also a very important pillar of the EU’s pledge for COP 21 in Paris. In my opinion, we have a set of policy tools that can help enshrine into law the EU’s target of a reduction of at least 40% of greenhouse gas emissions by 2030, whilst putting households and business consumers at the heart of the European energy transition. Having said that, the ETS as a main pillar of EU climate policy needs to be a very reliable instrument which can help us reduce emissions and fight climate change. For this to happen, however, we need a reformed ETS which sets a price on carbon that encourages polluters to clean up their act.  Under the current Phase 3 Trading Period, free allowances are allocated too generously and in an inflexible manner. Handing out free emission allowances that exempt industries from reducing emissions is definitely not a solution. Free allocations alone cannot solve the challenges the ETS poses for industry, and this is an issue that we need to pay attention to in the upcoming discussions.  For climate change mitigation up to 2030, ETS is definitely important, but energy efficiency for household appliances is extremely important too. We need all the tools available to make sure that the EU will reach its 2030 energy and climate targets without ignoring industrial sector concerns, while sending a strong message to our global partners ahead of the Paris Climate Conference showing that the EU is an unquestionable leader in ambition and responsibility.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I hope you will forgive me for focusing upon only one part of the summer package, the Emissions Trading Scheme. It is a great pleasure to take forward this particular dossier and I look forward to working with colleagues across the Chamber to try and deliver upon that.  I do not think that I am revealing any secrets when I say that there will be challenges ahead but, like navigating through a quagmire, we must make haste slowly, step by step, one step at a time. The UN negotiations will set the framework for our discussion so I would not propose putting pen to paper before then: we must let them be our guide through that particular quagmire. But we should use the time right now to learn more, to talk more, and to reach out to those who will be affected, for good or ill, by whatever proposals emerge from our discussions. Let me finish by saying that, together in this House, I believe that we can make significant progress. My late mother had an ability to cut a cake and convince all her children that they each had the biggest part. I think that will be my challenge going forward as I try to reach out to all in this particular Chamber.

name: Kaja Kallas (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I echo other colleagues’ welcoming of the summer energy package, and I am particularly happy to see that the Commission sees the importance of empowering energy consumers, as consumers remain the driving force for competition in any market. It is very important that consumers be informed, because if they are informed they make the right choices not only about prices, but also about protecting the environment and ensuring energy security.  However, consumers need to get that information about prices and about suppliers, and also about the possibilities of switching between suppliers. Therefore, I believe that data-driven technologies such as data hubs should play a big role in empowering consumers. Data hubs get the DSOs to share information publicly about the different suppliers and their possibilities, and also about the way that consumers can switch between them.  I therefore believe that the redesigning of the electricity market to integrate more renewables and introduce more flexibility in the market should go hand in hand with data-driven technologies, by creating new opportunities for consumers to decide how, what and from whom they want to consume their energy.

name: Peter Eriksson (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I was going to speak Swedish. My native language. I think the Energy Union is an extremely important step. I am pleased that it has become a centre for the Commission and a central work there. Energy and security go hand in hand. Unfortunately, I find it regrettable to see how both Finland, through its investment in Russian nuclear power and Germany, is now undermining common security by not supporting development in which we invest in independent and renewable energy sources, through its investment in Russian nuclear power. Emission rights are a system that has not worked for a very long time. We need strong action. We need politicians who dare to do something to make these work. I am also very pleased that the Commission is making proposals in this direction now. I hope that Parliament and the Council will also dare to strengthen this further. Because if we continue with this approach of letting the systems not work, it will greatly affect the possibilities of changing the system and meeting the climate targets.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we agree with many of the proposals in the energy package: updating labelling, promoting renewable self-handling, self-consumption, reducing network charges; more guarantees for those who invest in renewables and so on. We hope that this will be the premise of a genuine New Deal for the benefit of the citizens and for energy democratisation, but we cannot fail to denounce another New Deal inaugurated today in the Committee on Energy, where next week the groups are being expected to report and deliver their own opinions on the Energy Summer Package.  This morning, at the coordinators' meeting, behind closed doors and with a stroke of the hand, despite the contrary opinion of all the other PPE and S&D Groups, the rules for allocating dossiers changed quickly, without justification and without proper discussion. In any constitutional democracy, the basic rules are not changed overnight, when they no longer correspond to the interests of a party, even if they are majority. Today, however, a form of democracy has been imposed which has degenerated in this Parliament. The bullied dictatorship of the majority which transforms europe's only elected institution into a non-revolting free market in cows between just two political groups, so that every parliamentary act, any fantastic New Deal that you will prepare, is part of a progressive loss of a lowest common ethical denominator. Fortuna wants a majority not to be given forever.  So much so that a well-known historical figure, you should know him, stated that the last will be the first. Those who sit in here today and who have suffered totalitarian regimes and political persecution should remember this well. Today, some of them have become actively or oblivious to this coup d'état. Fortuna wants majorities in Europe to change faster than they already are, thanks to your unholy and short-seen actions. This is the only historical merit that we will recognize.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as you can see, I do not have Merkel's face and today I am 100% original. As far as energy is concerned, I will speak in Italian tonight because there was the one who spoke Swedish first. In the 1970s there was an Israeli oil pipeline that gave Iran the opportunity to sell oil, this is a very clear example to make it clear that when people's interests can be done, one must not look anyone in the face.  What is Europe doing? To spite Russia or Azerbaijan, try in every way to change strategy. But do you think it is more important to do the interests of the people or to do the interests of multinationals? Is it more important to be in the interests of the United States, or is it more important to be in the interests of Europeans, who would pay much less for gas and oil? These are two facts that make it clear that Europe is in fact succubus of American power and condescending on so many policies that ultimately prove to be demented, thank you.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: – The Union's climate policy objectives must be achieved at national level, as the energy mix is a national competence and it should be noted that there are countries that wish to ensure this by using nuclear energy.  In the preparation for the Paris climate meeting, the commission set more ambitious targets. I quote the written material: greenhouse gas emission reductions by 2030: 50% reduction, share of renewable energy by 2030: 45%. These objectives are unrealistic and unjustified. It is unrealistic because it does not take into account the cost impact that will occur in the consumer price, and it is unjustified because the Union is responsible for 9% of emissions and the US and China are responsible for 35, so the most important thing in Paris will be whether we can get these issuers to make a commitment. (The speaker agrees to answer a blue card question under Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. – I would like to ask the Member whether, although he has given very nice words to national competences, what is the point of calling for the expansion of the Paks nuclear power plant, which is the most expensive or at least one of the most expensive sources of energy in the world, which serves only Russian interests and Russian financial interests?

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Blue card answer. – Since Mr Szanyi failed in the Hungarian Parliament on this subject to find sufficient arguments for preserving the capacity of the existing Hungarian nuclear power plant, which was originally Russian technology, and therefore, on favourable terms, enlargement is also being made in such an investment, I can say that if you again make unrealistic facts here at the level of the European Parliament, these are as untrue as in the Hungarian Parliament.

name: Ivo Belet (PPE).
text: I would like to refer to what Mrs Figueres of the United Nations said here yesterday in the Committee on the Environment. She said that Europe is today at the forefront of the climate issue on the way to Paris. We must not, of course, give up that role. She stressed that we can never commit enough to innovation and technology transfer. That reasoning applies more than ever a fortiori in the ETS file. This is not easy for our energy-intensive industry, but at the same time it is also a very big opportunity provided that it is done in a balanced way. That is why, more than ever, we must commit to this Innovation Fund to use all the R&D resources available to us in the Union to ensure that the competitiveness of heavy industry is not put under pressure. Carbon leakage is and remains a very important concern. I therefore respect the Commission's choice to use free allowances on those energy sectors that are really exposed to international competition. One final note: as with the climate agreement that we hope to conclude in Paris in December and which will hopefully become binding, we will also have to complete the fourth phase of ETS in a dynamic way and review and evaluate it from time to time.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there is no doubt that last July's package strengthens the European Union's energy strategy and its credibility with its international partners in the run-up to the Paris climate conference. I believe that the strengths of this package relate above all to the fact that the review of the ETS trading system allows us to hold together in the way that two fundamental objectives are formulated: the first, very ambitious, concerns environmental objectives and industrial sustainability criteria, that of reducing emissions to at least 40% by 2030; the second is that all this is taking place as part of a battle to safeguard the international competitiveness of the industrial sectors most exposed - many of them have mentioned this - to the risk of relocation of production outside the European Union.  What I want to say is that, in concluding my speech, together with the Commission's commitment to a simplified energy labelling system and the principle of consumer centrality, which is another very important thing, I believe that there is a risk that everything that has been put in place could be undermined if the proposals that make up the Energy Union do not follow the ordinary legislative procedure. Parliament must be an all-round institutional actor, through a binding legal framework and a system of indicative national targets, because without democratic control the achievement of the objectives is also jeopardised.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the Commission’s summer Energy Package contains some sensible suggestions that will help the internal market for energy. I was pleased to see the opening of a public consultation on a new market design for the European electricity system and I look forward to its conclusions. I also welcome the Commission’s decision to revert back to the A to G system for energy efficiency labelling. This system is well recognised by consumers and saves them energy and money. I do wonder why it was changed in the first place. It is, though, important that the EU be consistent in its approach to energy efficiency. The recent European Court of Justice ruling against the United Kingdom’s preferential tax rate for energy-efficient materials runs counter to the Commission’s drive to reduce emissions. Member States should be free to impose lower taxes on energy-efficient products, so I would urge the Commissioner to amend the VAT Directive to allow this to continue.

name: Jerzy Buzek (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Thank you very much for the summer package presented. We were waiting for him. We are now waiting for legislation. Consumers are the most important point of this package and it should be. Our citizens should know why we are creating an Energy Union, how important it is to them, how it can increase their confidence that there will be no shortage of energy supply. But prosumers are also important, and it is good that the European Commission has drawn attention to this, because prosumers can provide both energy supply, all over the European Union, as well as, very importantly, atmospheric protection, climate protection and environmental protection.  It is therefore important to design our common energy market well, because this gives our consumers an opportunity: the flexibility of this market, the carousel flows that need to be eliminated, the direct and indirect prices of CO2 elimination.  All this is very important, but work is also important for consumers. They want to have a job and the ECJ must be designed so that heavy industry does not leave the European Union, because that really threatens us, up to thirty percent. Finally, a Community approach is needed to ensure gas supplies to the European Union. This is part of the Energy Union and this new idea to increase Nord Stream, and in such a significant way, could put security at risk.  I wanted to ask whether the European Commission is examining the impact of nord stream enlargement on the security situation and on the energy package that we have before us?

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D).
text: – Mr President, within Parliament, the S&D Group has a position paper defining our priorities on the Energy Union, which are now becoming legislation with the summer package. As a Group, we came up with several messages. First, the Energy Union needs to facilitate the transition to a sustainable decarbonised economy, based on energy efficiency, renewable energy and smart infrastructure. The Energy Union will need to ensure security of supply, enhance the creation of high—quality jobs and develop new export markets through further investment in research and innovation. Finally, we want the Energy Union to guarantee secure, stable and affordable energy for European industries and citizens, with a particular emphasis on job creation and – an issue close to my heart – tackling energy poverty among our most vulnerable citizens. In Europe, recent studies showed that only 12% of the most vulnerable consumers are put on the lowest energy tariffs. In its communication on the summer package entitled ‘Delivering a New Deal for Energy Consumers’, the Commission highlights the need for targeted, effective assistance, reflecting best practices in the energy field, as well as for EU-wide data collection and monitoring of energy poverty. Commissioner, no one in 2015 should have to choose between heating, cooling and eating.

name: Dawid Bohdan Jackiewicz (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Unfortunately, the proposals for changes contained in the summer energy package are proof of the lack of a forward-looking view of the health of the eu economy as a whole. The proposed solutions put Europe's coal power industry bankrupt. The Energy Union is to mean energy based only on renewable sources. The investment fund's resources will in no way compensate for the losses incurred by countries whose economies are based on coal. This is the situation that awaits my country, Poland, among others, and I am here to oppose it.  The adoption of the rules proposed by the Commission will only deepen the differences in the civilisational development of individual European countries. The solutions imposed to eliminate coal are in front of fundamental EU principles on freedom of financial flow and on persons and goods. I do not agree with the current shape of the Energy Union, and I say this for the sake of the state of the economy of many European countries. If we are a European community, let us respect the principles of equal treatment and respect also for countries with a weaker position in that community.

name: Pilar del Castillo Vera (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to welcome the Commission for this summer, summer energy package. I'm going to choose one of the angles, the consumer-oriented angle. I believe that a consumer-oriented energy policy is absolutely necessary. I would like to congratulate the Commission on putting that emphasis on the consumer. It is essential that the consumer participates, because other words energy efficiency and energy savings will be impossible. One of the areas where there are the most gaps is precisely that related to consumers. And I will point out two aspects: energy efficiency technologies allow to reduce bills, but the consumer will only take those measures if they actually reduce invoices, and today we find many designs of national markets in which they do not have an effective impact on the consumer invoice. At the same time, the interoperability of the equipment is essential, as well as the possibility to compare the offers of the different operators. We must continue on this path, permanently putting the consumer at the heart of the energy policy orientation. (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: "blue card" question. "Lady of the Castle, you have chosen the angle of the consumer," she says. I would like to know how you value the Spanish Government's decision to tax precisely the consumption of renewable energy.

name: Pilar del Castillo Vera (PPE)
text: "blue card" response. – Let us see, as you know very well, because it belongs to the same country as me and has the same history as me in the knowledge of renewable energy, renewable energies have simply had extraordinarily high premiums, which have generated a huge deficit by decision of previous governments, and what the Government of Spain has done right now , the Government of the People's Party, has been trying to rationalize in order to balance the deficit in the field of renewable energy. Nothing more than that.

name: Martina Werner (S&D).
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for his work I would like to comment on only part of the summer package, namely the revision of the Energy Label Directive, because of the short time available. I think this is a really very important step, especially with regard to COP 21 in Paris. And the energy label is also a European model of success that makes it easier for consumers to buy the most energy-efficient products. It is available in every household and is actually known to most consumers in the EU. Surveys have also shown that more than 80% of EU citizens know the energy label. Therefore, particular attention must also be paid to consumer protection when revising the energy label. The energy labels for the various product groups are above all misleading today and no longer do their job as a consumer-friendly tool for saving energy. For example, A+ is the best classification for some product groups and the worst efficiency class for others. And in addition, the product groups almost all have completely different scales – from A+++ to A+, G, in short, there is actually a mess in the market. The Commission's proposal is a good one. It still needs to be improved in some places. The roles and obligations of manufacturers and distributors are not yet clearly separated. The treatment of sensitive product data, I am thinking of trade secrets in the proposed online database, is not described in detail. The responsibility for checking data fed into the database is not clear. And these are just a few examples.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the creation of an Energy Union is clearly a step in the right direction. The creation of a flexible European energy system based on clean modern technologies does not pose a threat to our competitiveness. On the contrary, it is a unique opportunity for our industry, consumers and research. I therefore also unequivocally welcome this package. Above all, strengthening the role of consumers, whether households or businesses, is the key to a new way of using and producing energy. However, unfortunately, some proposals are not ambitious enough to actually contribute to our objective of moving to a low-carbon economy by 2050. It is not possible to achieve this without a significant increase in investment in new technologies and in the modernisation of European industry. These are hundreds of billions of euros that should be brought in by both private entities and public resources that will need to be spent in the coming years. The sale of emission allowances must be one of them. I therefore consider the Commission's proposed revision of this system in this area to be insufficient, because in this form the impact on the modernisation of the European economy will be much smaller than I would expect.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE). –
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking The rapid accession of the European Commission to the work on the creation of an Energy Union should be appreciated. The package contains regulations that will improve the situation of consumers in the energy market. Unfortunately, I have concern about the Commission's proposals to reform the EU emissions trading market. Withdrawing some of the allowances from the market in order to raise their prices may in the long term prove to be a mistake that weakens the potential of our economy. I appreciate that the Commission wants to protect sectors and businesses that are particularly vulnerable to fleeing Europe, but I do not think that this will have the desired effect.  The problem that we should solve is to make Europe alone in the fight against climate change. All the big emitters, including the United States, China and Russia, are not sufficiently involved, as evidenced best by the negotiations before the Paris climate summit. By imposing an additional burden on the industry, we will not rebuild it, and that should be our primary objective at the moment. Without industrial development, we will not improve the labour market situation.  There is also concern about the recent announcement of the construction of a second Nord Stream strand, which will make Europe even more dependent on Russian gas. This idea shows that some have not learned any lessons from what is happening in the east of the continent.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, one of the objectives of the summer energy package is to strengthen energy consumers. But the key issue for consumers is energy poverty. In my own country, Greece in particular, the Troika's policies have led to the increase in the phenomenon of energy poverty. The contraction in incomes, while increasing energy prices, has been a double burden on Greeks. But energy is a social essential commodity, which is why electricity and heating oil must have zero VAT and their consumption taxes reduced to a minimum. At the same time, the SYRIZA-ANEL mnemonic co-government together with New Democracy - PASOK and Potami, with the third memorandum, and under the Damocles saber of the Troika proceeded to sell off the country's energy silverware and are already launching the privatisation of ADMIE and the sale of public shares in GREEK OILS. These privatisations will lead to an additional increase in energy prices and a worsening of energy poverty in Greece and that is why they must stop.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, I would like to express my firm stance and support for the European Union's single energy market, because I think that the Single Energy Market really has no alternative. Based on stable legislation and security of supply, but also free consumer choice, I think it's something that's a big advantage that we can give our fellow citizens at the moment. But what I would like, Mr. Šefčoovich, to emphasize and repeat once again in my speech is to draw your attention to the energy sources that exist in the Western Balkans, from the plan to build LNG terminals in Croatia and Albania, but also renewable energy sources, especially hydropower, in the countries of Southeast Europe and those that are not members of the EU from where refugees even come from. So maybe we can have a win-win combination where we have renewables and help countries develop economically and stop the refugee wave from those countries.

name: Maria Spyraki (PPE).
text: Mr Vice-President of the Commission, the energy package is indeed an opportunity to redesign the electricity market, to upgrade energy efficiency in Europe and to revise the emissions trading system in order to strengthen the balance between industrial production and the reduction of greenhouse gases. However, I would like to make two comments. The first is that the Commission must monitor very closely the harmonisation of countries in the single energy market. And this concerns first and foremost my country, Greece, which must on Monday, after the elections of 20 September, proceed immediately to the liberalisation of the energy market so that prices fall and consumers have cheaper electricity. Stop past practices that prevented individuals from entering the energy market and produce electricity. The other point, Mr President, concerns the competitiveness of European industry. Let us pay attention to the parameters of the pollutant trading system, we may have the opposite of the desired result.

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank all Members of this Parliament for their support and their very encouraging words concerning our summer package. I can assure them that I will be very happy to bring that message back to the Commission in the Berlaymont, and to make sure that things continue at the same pace and with the same ambition for all subsequent proposals, which we promised we would deliver – and we will deliver them on time. The autumn will be devoted to the very important conference Members referred to in several of their interventions – COP 21. It is very important that the EU remains the leader in these efforts and that it makes sure that in Paris we get an ambitious, legally—binding agreement which would clearly put the world on a healthier and more sustainable path than in the past. Therefore, we accept these diplomatic activities, which we will be taking part in together – the Member States and the Commission. The French presidency wants to reconfirm our ambition in those efforts by working on additional legislative proposals. We have been discussing with several Honourable Members the importance of a cooling and heating strategy. I am very glad to inform the House that we are working hard on that, to deliver it on time. In the spring we want to present to Parliament another important package, which is strongly linked to the issue of energy security highlighted by several speakers. We want to present a new gas package, in which we want to tackle the issue of energy security through a new or revised directive on the security of gas supply, including the transparency of commercial contracts and the new proposals for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on intergovernmental agreements, to make sure that once such agreements are signed they are fully compatible with European law. Then, of course, summer will come. In the summer we would like to deliver two very important packages linked with what I hope will be good results from Paris – with how things would work in the non-ETS sector, with our transport, our buildings and our agriculture, and how we would make sure that we deliver on what we have already promised in the summer package in the ambitious proposals on the redesign of the electricity market. I think that there we can reflect some of the concerns which have been presented here concerning the fairness of the system, clear billing and energy poverty issues, better integration of renewables and, of course, underlining the principle of energy efficiency first. Therefore, I would like to assure Members that citizens facing poverty in the area of energy are a top priority and very much on our mind when we are preparing these legislative proposals. Concerning the ETS, Mr Duncan referred to his mother who could divide the cake in such a way that everybody thought that they had got the biggest piece. I think we have to learn from that wisdom and make sure that the system is fair for everybody, that we respect different starting positions and that we see it as a collective effort, which will be good for Europe, for the planet, for our citizens and for our industries. We have a very solid proposal on the table and we are very much looking forward to working with Members on this very ambitious proposal for the future. Several Members referred to the issue of Nord Stream 2. As I am sure they have noticed, since the beginning of the year we have heard several declarations on different ‘Streams’. The Nord Stream proposal is another project which raises a lot of questions. It raises the question of why we need additional huge capacity to be built when the current transport capacity for Russian gas to Europe is used at only 50%. Why do we need such big capacity if we want to preserve the transit route through Ukraine? Here I am very glad that not only the Commission, but also the Foreign Affairs Council, declared very clearly that preserving and maintaining the gas transit route through Ukraine is of strategic importance for the energy security of Europe. We have to say very loudly and clearly that it is very important for us that any attempts to shut down this transit route through Ukraine would have very negative consequences for the energy security of the European Union and for gas balance, especially in Central and Eastern Europe. It would have devastating consequences for Ukraine, in terms of the possibility of getting gas from different sources through reverse flows and, of course, in terms of the very important loss of revenue from transit fees. Therefore, it is absolutely clear that we have to get more details on this project, assess it very carefully and make sure that European law, especially the third package, would be fully applied to this project as well and that in the future it will be important for the European Union – for our Member States, but also for European companies – to make sure that, when we are looking for projects in the field of energy security, we look for the solutions which offer comprehensive security for all Member States, for all European countries and not just for a few.  Allow me to conclude by talking about my experience yesterday. I was in Bulgaria, where we had a huge conference which was also attended by the energy community of the Western Balkan countries. They are also looking with great hope to our Energy Union project. They told me that it seems that they will probably join the Energy Union before they join the European Union. I welcomed them. This is exactly what we want to do, because we believe in cross-border cooperation. We believe in the integration of our energy systems and we are ready to look for solutions which would be beneficial and positive for the whole of Europe and all European countries.  Thank you very much once again for giving me the opportunity to present the summer package. I would like to thank Members for their support and to assure them that we will be working according to our ambitious timetable. I am very much looking forward to discussing these topics with you. I believe that the next big occasion will be when we present you with the first Energy Union report, which we would like to turn into an annual event so that the issues of energy, climate change, transport, energy poverty – all subjects which are so close to the hearts of our citizens – will be permanently on the table of the European Union.

name: El Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Article 162 of the Regulation)

name: Algirdas Saudargas (PPE)
text: Writing. – I would like to congratulate the Commission on presenting a new energy package. This is an important step towards the implementation of the European Energy Union. I would like to draw particular attention to the Commission communication on consultation of the new energy market model. I fully agree on the need to reform and organise the European energy system so that we can effectively implement the transition to sustainable and consumer-oriented energy. The Commission document perfectly reflects the new challenges and areas where change is needed, but I am missing the links and synergies with the European Digital Market Strategy. In the electricity system and markets, information and communication technologies play an increasingly important role in both energy production and transmission networks and the use of smart meters in households. I therefore call on the Commission to pay greater attention to the measures and actions needed to ensure the security of energy systems, the assessment, prevention and fight of cyber threats.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE)
text: in writing. – Any European energy programme must be reviewed in the context of new observable trends in energy resources. Falling crude oil prices below $50 a barrel has changed the overall outlook on investment, production and consumption of fossil fuels, as well as renewable energy. Many of the investments in renewable energy have become unprofitable outside of subsidies from public budgets or additional payments made by direct energy consumers. Consequently, all the targets proposed for this year's Paris Conference on reducing the action of climate change causes impacting people's lives and the environment must also be reviewed.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Security of energy supply, including at affordable prices for consumers and without harming the environment, should be given priority by the European Union. However, I am concerned to see that the Member States of the European Union often have an inconsistent energy policy, which consists primarily of solutions that do not reduce Europe's dependence on supply from one eastern direction. At the same time, a very rigorous climate policy is being pursued in the Union, which not only undermines our energy security, but consequently also undermines the competitiveness of the European economy. One of the adverse effects is the 'push' of some of the most energy-intensive sectors into non-European areas of the world, where there are virtually no emission reductions. This threatens to be counterproductive, namely the lack of climate improvement, the competitiveness of the economy, increased unemployment, increased social stratification and even an increase in poverty in Europe.  I believe that all Community economic and social objectives, including environmental objectives, are important and absolutely implemented, but that the dynamics of these actions should be rationally adapted to the capabilities of all, not just individual Member States, and appropriately integrated into the global process.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. – The Energy Union Strategy is one step closer to its implementation by the adoption by the European Commission of a necessary package of measures. What I am pleased about is that the measures are primarily aimed at energy consumers of all levels, from individual households to commercial and industrial consumers. Finally, we have taken the logic of providing benefits to European consumers by reorganising the European electricity market, updating the energy efficiency labelling system and revising the Union Emissions Trading Scheme. The measures are undoubtedly ambitious, but they strengthen the position of energy consumers in Europe and, at the same time, send a signal to global partners ahead of the long-awaited Paris Conference. The proposal to revise the EU Emissions Trading Scheme aims to create new business opportunities and open up new markets for innovation through the need to use low-carbon technologists. However, we will have to ensure that the industrial sectors in the Union with intensive energy consumption and a high risk of relocation will remain competitive globally despite the high costs.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. – The Energy Union and the Digital Union are the key economic and political drivers for the European Union to improve its geopolitical position, increase the competitiveness of the economy, strengthen territorial cohesion and contribute to a more people-centred globalisation and more respectful of the sustainability of the planet. The European Commission's summer energy union package lays the right foundations for the success of the agenda, including the reform of the emissions trading market, the revision of the efficiency labelling system, the provision to consumers of self-production arrangements and the new configuration of the single energy market.  In this area, the European Council's position on the governance of the Energy Union makes it possible to foresee a concerted planning model, with the initiative of the Member States in the framework of action plans with quantification of targets and subject to evaluation and monitoring by the European Commission. The European Union has made its main progress in responding to political and economic crises. The Energy Union, like the Digital Union, cannot expect the European Union to understand migration, because they are themselves part of the solution to this central issue.

name: El Presidente. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the basis of the Declarations of the Council and the Commission on the current crisis in the agricultural sector (2015/2837(RSP)).

name: Fernand Etgen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, Mr Vice-President, honourable Members, at a time when this sector is going through a difficult period, I would like to reaffirm from the outset that agriculture is a fundamental sector for the European economy in terms of employment, social cohesion and sustainable development. The farmers, those who were at the gates of the Council on 7 September, those whom I met several times in preparing this Council and on the margins of the informal meeting in Luxembourg yesterday, those who report their difficulties in many Member States, are waiting for concrete answers, answers that go beyond simple technical measures and ensure the viability of the sector. That is why, after an initial discussion in July on the evolution of the main agricultural markets and on avenues of action in response to unfavourable developments, we convened this Council in September to examine the package of measures drawn up by the Commission. We continued our discussions yesterday at the informal meeting of agriculture ministers in Luxembourg, in which the chairman of your Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development participated. It also seems to me essential that Parliament contribute to this reflection and I am aware, in particular, of the recent contributions of its Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development on the dairy sector. As you know, since July, the market situation has worsened. The year 2015 will have seen unfavourable weather conditions, in particular one of the worst droughts since 2003, which affected almost half of the Member States, the presence of health risks, such as those related to swine fever, the extension of the Russian embargo and insufficient demand in view of current supply. All this contributes to a particularly depressed price level in Europe, particularly in the dairy, pork and fruit and vegetable sectors, and also affects other sectors, such as beef. Various initiatives, in the short and medium term, can be suggested to respond in solidarity to this situation. These responses must come from the national level as well as from the European level and must be able to use all available means on the two pillars of the CAP. As far as the European level is concerned, the measures presented by the Commission, to which President Juncker referred to you in his State of the Union address, amount to EUR 500 million, mainly to the benefit of the dairy sector. They are based on three axes. First, respond to farmers' cash flow difficulties; second, stabilizing markets; and, third, to improve the functioning of the supply chain. I think it is important to look at the method before deciding on these measures. Firstly, the financial envelopes made available to Member States aim to provide a fair, targeted and effective distribution with particular attention to Member States and farmers who have been most affected by market developments. Secondly, even if, given the diversity of situations and to avoid micro-management from Brussels, it is desirable to give the Member States a great deal of leeway, it is important that this aid does not call into question the market orientation taken by the new CAP, particularly with regard to the dairy sector since the end of quotas. Finally, in this first year of the implementation of the new regulatory framework, I would like to stress that the task of national administrations is already daunting. It is therefore desirable that they have some flexibility. I am thinking in particular of the possibility of anticipating the payment of certain essential payments for the short-term cash flow of farmers. In the same spirit - and our two institutions have committed to it - the CAP simplification programme, if properly conducted, with adequate priorities, can lead to a reduction in costs for farmers. The critical financial situation of many farmers naturally leads to an emphasis on the short-term financial side of the measures. However, I believe that we must also think about the implementation of actions such as those that involve the conquest of new export markets, the enhancement of products covered by geographical indications and other value-added products, the removal of non-tariff barriers, particularly those related to health risks, or even a more systematic use of the opportunities offered by producer organisations. , for example, to access the funding provided by the Regulation on the European Fund for Strategic Investments.  With regard to the short term and the package of measures drawn up by the Commission, I am pleased to be able to inform you, at the end of the informal meeting of agriculture ministers yesterday in Luxembourg, of the broad support that this package has received, at least as a first response. But beyond short-term measures and even if medium-term forecasts seem more encouraging, the fact remains that a reflection on more structural elements is needed. I am thinking in particular of ways to ensure a more balanced functioning of the food supply chain, for the benefit of producers, a quicker assessment of the milk package put in place in response to the 2009 crisis, since, under the current circumstances, we cannot wait until 2018 for a new assessment to be carried out , or the development of financial instruments in response to increased price volatility in agricultural markets. Finally, I will conclude by underlining our determination to put in place a solid package of measures and to continue to reflect with Parliament, in particular on measures that contribute to the sustainability of the sector in the medium term.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am very happy to be here this evening with the President of the Council of Agriculture Ministers, Fernand Etgen, and to outline the Commission’s response to the difficulties currently facing European farmers. As the public representatives of the European Union’s 507 million citizens, Members are only too well aware of the challenges facing not only farmers, but the wider challenges facing the Union. Just last week, President Juncker made his State of the Union address to this House and, inevitably, much of that address was focused on the refugee crisis. To deal with this crisis, the President said that we ‘require a strong effort for European solidarity’. The European Union has shown solidarity in its response to many crises and our response to the situation in the agricultural markets is a demonstration of solidarity with European farmers and particularly with those most affected by market developments over the past year. The Commission has proposed a comprehensive support package for all 28 Member States, which is worth EUR 500 million, and which is described by President Juncker as ‘a EUR 500 million solidarity package for farmers’. The Commission’s response reflects our commitment to support European farmers and European food production. I welcome the support for the package by the Council yesterday and I hope that I can count on similar support from this House. In response to some concerns about the source of the funding for the package, I am happy to confirm that the money comes from within the existing margins of the agricultural budget and will not require recourse to the Crisis Reserve.  For those who question the adequacy of the package as an effective response, I would say there are always some for whom any amount is never enough, whether it is EUR 500 million or EUR 1 billion, but now that we have this package announced, my focus is on delivering it. This is about what the Commission can do for farmers and getting that done quickly, particularly to address the immediate cashflow challenges of the sector. The Commission’s response must also be seen against the other budgetary pressures, particularly arising from the refugee crisis. Indeed, an element of the Commission’s package is to make available EUR 30 million to ensure that EU milk will be available for the nutritional needs of refugees. We have been dealing for over a year now with the effects of the Russian ban, which it is acknowledged has had repercussions on the farming sector. In addition to the continuing impact of that ban, we also have weakening demand in a number of key existing and prospective markets, notably China; we have a global oversupply of milk, to which all producing regions are contributing; and we have an impact of drought in certain Member States. These issues have had a wide impact on farmers, particularly dairy farmers, who number about 700 000 right across the Union.  The Commission’s package is an appropriate mix to meet the challenges being faced by different sectors and farmers in Member States, and rather than focusing on individual measures I would urge Members to look at the package as a whole. It is a package that is designed to address the cash-flow difficulties faced by farmers, on the one hand, through EUR 420 million in direct targeted aid for all 28 Member States, and on the other, by allowing Member States to advance 70% of direct payments and up to 85% of area-based rural development payments from 16 October without the need for on-the-spot checks.  The package will stabilise the market, through a new and very generously—resourced private storage scheme for skimmed milk powder and cheese as well as a new private storage scheme for pigmeat. Additional funding will also be provided for the promotion of dairy products and pigmeat. The package will reinforce the work on improvements for better outcomes at all layers of the food supply chain – production, processing and retail – by promoting full use of the milk package, for example through exchange of best practices, including on unfair trading practices, as well as by thoroughly reporting on all aspects of the milk package already in 2016 and through a new dedicated High-Level Group that will look at specific measures such as risk hedging instruments for agricultural products and credit for farmers The package will also respond to societal challenges, like completing our work on the School Milk Scheme programme and the additional funding for refugees. These measures are taken in addition to the EUR 820 million that is being allocated in Member States – 17 Member States in all – through Voluntary Coupled Support for the dairy sector. I am confident that the necessary resources to cover all measures are available to ensure that it is an effective response, which will deliver on its objectives. The allocation of EUR 420 million in Member State envelopes has generated some inevitable reaction, but I want to emphasise that the distribution key that was used ensures that the envelopes are fair, and in a spirit of solidarity it provides a top-up for those Member States that are most greatly affected by the negative circumstances, including the fall in pigmeat prices, the summer drought and the ongoing impact of the Russian ban.  Last week, President Juncker said that without farmers Europe would not survive, and he gave a commitment that he would not leave farmers out in the cold. The Commission’s package delivers on that commitment. It is a robust and decisive response.  I want to emphasise the imperative need for rapid action and appeal to Members for assistance in ensuring that this package is delivered quickly for the benefit of our farmers. The Commission is already publishing the draft legal instruments, the delegated and implementing acts, and I encourage them to support these measures, particularly in relation to targeted aid, to ensure that the available funding can be provided quickly to those who need it. I do not believe that farmers should be left waiting for the urgent help that they need and which we can supply today, and I ask the House to support me in this approach.

name: Albert Deß
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner Phil Hogan, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. Many thanks to all those involved who have made it possible for today's debate on the current situation of agriculture in the European Union to take place. On behalf of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, we have written to you, Commissioner, about the difficult situation in the field of milk, as well as in the case of pigmeat, fruit and vegetables. I am grateful to Mrs Esther Herranz Garcia for the initiative she took during the summer recess. One of the reasons for the market situation, as you mentioned, is the Russian embargo imposed on EU agricultural products. The Baltic, Finnish and Polish farmers were immediately and most affected. Very quickly, however, it has had an impact on the whole of European agriculture. Falling demand from China and drought in certain areas exacerbate the situation. That is why the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats has written that the Commission should react and take appropriate market action. A specific demand is that the EUR 900 million from the sub-levy be used for market measures in the agricultural sector and, as a matter of priority, to stabilise the milk market. On the subject of the intervention prize, there are different opinions in my group and even in my party. Personally, I think very little of this and I am grateful to you, Commissioner, for agreeing with it. A system in which the Commission can withdraw ad hoc quantities from the market at a certain price would be more effective. It would be an efficient instrument for unsettling the retail chains and thereby limiting market power. For example, if a large retail chain tries to reduce the price of butter by 80 cents per kilo, and the Commission decides overnight to withdraw 50 000 tonnes of butter from the market, the price reduction is likely to be in the sand. We must respond to the new challenges with new instruments. With the intervention instrument of the last century, we cannot cope with the current situation. Thank you, Commissioner, for your reaction. I hope that further measures will follow. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. I do not wish to argue with your main claims, but rather to ask your opinion on a particular issue, namely, decades ago and now, we are spending millions, hundreds of millions, billions of euros to support agriculture, market interventions. On the other side, some governments put up to 27% VAT on food. Could this whole problem not be solved by exempting basic foodstuffs, or even all foodstuffs, as they do in many Member States?

name: Albert Deß (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I do not know whether I have understood the question correctly. We have very different VAT rates. We have only a very low tax rate on food, and in the UK it is close to zero. VAT is a national issue.  I would like to see Europe-wide harmonisation, particularly in the case of food. This would certainly improve the situation, in the interests of consumers in those countries where such high VAT rates are levied on food.

name: Paolo De Castro
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the package of measures announced is certainly a step in the right direction. A first response to farmers who are facing deep crises, not least because of the Russian embargo, not only in the milk sector, but also, for example, in the pigmeat sector and in the fruit and vegetable sector.  Among the measures proposed, we welcome the increase in the promotion budget to help our producers find new markets, while we see that as far as private cheese storage is concerned, it would be more logical and rational to distribute resources between countries according to production, only of hard cheeses, because they are the only ones interested in this measure. Finally, let us remember that the Commission has the power to adopt these measures in the coming weeks, without ordinary procedure, but only through delegated and executive acts, but we hope Commissioner will take into account the will and demands of this Parliament in order to avoid institutional conflicts in the future too.

name: James Nicholson
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, can I first of all say there is no doubt that EUR 500 million is a lot of money. The problem arises with that amount of money when it gets down to individual Member States, and then when it gets down to the regions of those Member States, and indeed when it gets to those regions and to particular farms in those Member States. That is the point at which farmers are facing pain.  In my own constituency of Northern Ireland, we have an exacerbated situation because of the weakness of the euro against the pound sterling and the lack of any move on the intervention price. I fear that by refusing to review the price of intervention, the measures rolled out by the Commission could prove insufficient. How many of our farmers will be out of business, and how long will it be before these long-term measures take effect?  There are a number of areas I would like you, Commissioner, to maybe elaborate on. Is there any role for money from the super levy? Is that part of this package? Is it coming in to pay for the package? On aid to private storage, how long do you estimate it will take from withdrawal of the product before it has an impact on the market? Can I say I also welcome the new PSA scheme for cheese, and that unused allocations can be redistributed within three months. It may not be possible, but why not make that two months and make it even speedier? State aid, in my opinion, is something of a misnomer and I fear that all it will do is uneven the playing field – bad enough as it is at the moment within agriculture – and bring more inefficiency into the sector. Advance payments can be a poisoned chalice. What happens if the inspections are inadequate? Will they be given a bye ball? The payment agencies need to know. In Europe, too often the attitude is ‘if in doubt appoint a high-level group’, but again, whatever the merits of the long-term solution, it is a long-term solution like the MMO and other ideas, when what we have is a short-term problem.  Can I finish by commending the Commission proposal on the EUR 30 million which will be used to take advantage of displaced refugees in European countries neighbouring war zones. I congratulate the Commission on that particular proposal. Times are hard on the farm and we all have to work together to find a solution.

name: Jan Huitema
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Many agricultural sectors across Europe are struggling, not just dairy farming. In response, some Member States immediately choose to go back to the past by demanding market intervention. I am pleased that the Commissioner has kept his back straight and has not immediately referred the market-oriented agricultural policy to the bin by, for example, raising the intervention price. However, the Commission has one leg in the past and the other in the future. More Brussels support is not a structural solution, but a wipe against bleeding. Farmers need a better competitive position and the space to do business, innovate and compete on the world market. You can achieve this through fewer rules, simple rules and a level playing field, also with third countries. The best solution is therefore free of charge: to simplify agricultural policy. It doesn't cost anything. I therefore think it is a missed opportunity that the European Commission has not taken up this gauntlet. In addition, the nitrate directive must also keep up with its time. Farmers need to dispose of manure while supplying fertilizer, while there are innovations that allow farmers to turn animal manure into high-quality fertilizer substitutes. However, now that the Commission has opted for a support package, it is important that the Commission maintains a level playing field. The preconditions of the aid package are too unclear. I am opposed to the aid package being used as direct income support in some Member States. This leads to unfair competition. The Commission must stand its ground, maintain a level playing field and prevent additional national contributions from being added to the aid package. This will only widen the differences between Member States. Let us opt for structural solutions by giving farmers space in what they do best, namely entrepreneurship and innovation.

name: Matt Carthy
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, this challenging period was also an opportunity. It was an opportunity for you, Commissioner, to show farmers across Europe that you understood the crisis that many of them are facing. It was an opportunity to show that this Commission is capable of proposing measures that would make a real difference to farmers, not just during this period, but measures that would actually tackle the huge price volatility that is fast becoming the hallmark of European agriculture. Commissioner, this package represents an opportunity wasted: a one-off aid package that represents, for instance, EUR 13.7 million for Ireland, most of which, if you remember, will actually come from fines imposed on farmers in the first place; advance payments of monies that farmers were already entitled to; limited state aid measures. None of this represents solidarity or the radical action that was required not just to resolve this crisis, but to provide the certainty that is necessary for farmers to manage their livelihoods into the future.  I fear that, because of this wasted opportunity, in the coming years we are going to return to this place. We are going to witness one crisis after another in one sector after another. I also fear, I am sorry to say, that many will be questioning their future in farming unless an urgent rethink is forthcoming from you and the Commission. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8)).
