name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: the question raised by raising the blue card. I am pleased that you are paying attention to the fact that there is a crisis in agriculture and that you understand the need to support agriculture. Do you also understand the need to equalise subsidies for farmers so that they are at the same level in all EU Countries? I would remind you that in Poland farmers receive much lower subsidies than in France or Germany.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: blue-card answer. – In terms of the different aid packages and how they are reflected in real euros in each Member State, I would say that what we need to ensure is that the network of family farms – that is the hallmark, that is the very basis of European agriculture, it is what makes us different – needs to be protected not just for the farmers themselves, but for the communities from which they come. Many of the regions that depend on agriculture depend on it as the only thing, or the nearest thing, they have to an actual industry to keep young people in their communities and to keep thriving domestic economies going. Unless we ensure that this network of family farms is maintained, we are not only damaging European agriculture, we are actually damaging many of the regions that we represent.

name: José Bové
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, Commissioner for Agriculture, the aid that is being proposed today, namely EUR 420 million for milk, represents less than 3 cents per litre of milk, while the decline for producers is between 20 and 30% in each country. To offer storage today is to return to the policies of the 70s with piles of butter and piles of meat in the fridges. Finally, to want to export while exporting to countries where production costs are even lower is irresponsible. In fact, these countries have already reduced their imports. Therefore, I want to tell you today that this measure does not answer anything.  Producers now want prices that cover their production costs. Producers now want production control tools to regulate supply and demand. We must also now get out of this irresponsible logic, which is to believe that open markets will be a solution.  So today I'm ashamed! I am ashamed of the agriculture ministers who signed this agreement! I am ashamed of the European Commission which continues to justify this policy and I find it unacceptable that farmers are treated in this way when today it is the sector where there are the greatest number of suicides. Today, I find this unacceptable and I therefore tear up this irresponsible document!

name: John Stuart Agnew
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, well, I am not going to be tearing anything up just at the moment. I would like to tear up your speech though, if I could read it, José. All actions have consequences, and if you encourage people to have hopes that cannot be fulfilled then you will invite resentment and hostility. The European Union does this all the time. The EU unsettled the citizens of Ukraine and Russia retaliated with a ban on Western food imports. Who pays the price for this? Not the well-paid EU officials but farmers across Europe, who have lost a significant market, have found themselves in a situation of oversupply, and experience the inevitable crash in income. For – make no mistake – as Russia bulldozes illegal ham and cheese into the ground, the EU must appreciate that this is the consequence of its own actions. Severe punishment, of course, will be meted out by the Russians to those of its own citizens who facilitated the sanctions-busting – and God knows what they are going through at the moment – but again the EU officials will not feel the pain. The recently announced rescue package to agriculture to compensate farmers for their losses will do no such thing.  There is one glaring contradiction in the proposals. The Commission has promised farmers access to financial and risk-hedging instruments as part of the package. Farmers have always had these in the form of futures markets. However, the EU is, at this very minute, making participation in futures markets much more difficult in its MiFID II legislation. I have to say to you José – and Martin Häusling over there – that you have campaigned in the last six years for the abolition of futures markets in agriculture, and yet these help us enormously. Exemptions for farmers are essential if the tools are to benefit at all. So please do not promise what you cannot deliver. The EU has long pursued a policy of market intervention, generating hopes and expectations, which it can no longer afford. Responsible supply chain management is now required, and not handouts.  The failure to understand basic economics leads me to the new face in British politics. Until this month, Jeremy Corbyn made Herman Van Rompuy look high profile. And what is Mr Corbyn’s first action on food and farming? Well, he appoints a vegan – that is somebody who does not eat meat, milk or eggs – as the spokesman. I very much hope that the new Labour spokesman, Kerry McCarthy, comes to Brussels to brief Paolo de Castro and the Socialist comrades into her way of thinking. I would love to be a fly on the wall in that conversation. I hope the EU’s protesting farmers will, in turn, let her know theirs.

name: Laurenţiu Rebega
text: on behalf of the ENF group. – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I appreciate first of all the solidarity that the European Commission shows us and farmers, but I would like to think that this is not only a hypocritical act, but it is also an understanding that you, Commissioner, have the responsibility to explain to Mr Juncker. It's a tough time for us, for everyone who works in agriculture. I think we are all sorry about the crisis we are in now, and at the last show of farmers in Brussels a strong signal has been given that this situation must stop. In several new halves, MEPs, we have asked the European Commission to take into account the new situation in the milk sector, following the end of the quotas. It has been five months and we are still talking about the negative impact that the embargo has on Russia. Before the Commission, in Brussels, German, French, Belgian farmers, favoured by the nearby court, were able to participate and demonstrate against the crisis situation that the milk sector is going through, as well as that of pig and beef and cereals, due to the drought.  Not all European farmers were able to do this. From Romania only a few representatives could be present but, under no circumstances, could they bring a tractor, they could not afford it. So even publicly expressing his opinion has started to become a luxury. You have to be financially in, but that's not what this is about. Although this also influences the situation the imbalance between European countries in the agricultural field. We are all in crisis, but now I ask you one thing: let us not support differentiated, depending on the power of manifestation. If we have a common market, let it be common. In conclusion, I ask for your support in finding sales outside the Community, otherwise we will kill each other in an oversaturated market of products. I want to go to the supermarket and buy milk from local production. If we have extra milk, let's find a third-party market. We need to adopt those regulations so that hypermarkets reduce margins and taxes. During the last strike by farmers in Brussels in front of Parliament, young farmers informed citizens about the situation in the milk sector and give you a simple example: the cost of production 0.40 cent per litre, the price per farmer 0.25, and in the supermarket, for citizens, 0.50. If this continues, we will helplessly witness the bankruptcy of the most important agricultural sectors, at least in Eastern Europe. Thank.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as the recent demonstrations by farmers across Europe clearly show us, farming is a major issue that should concern us all. Given the Union's participation in the international economic and trade system, we condemn farmers to poverty and make the economies of the states fragile. Serving the large international capital, food imports from third countries are assisted at such prices that European producers cannot compete. At the same time, excessive sanctions against Russia hinder any export activity. This situation is expected to deteriorate even further if and when TTIP is signed. The failed quota system has also contributed to the decline in agricultural production. The imposition of wild taxation and high VAT on Greek farmers, as required by the third most onerous memorandum imposed on my country, gives the primary sector of Greece a free shot. The only solution is the immediate abolition of quotas, farmers producing what european peoples really need and the immediate imposition of high tariffs on all imported agricultural products from third countries.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by It is worth asking ourselves: why do we take action, interventions only after such large demonstrations? Couldn't we have done it before? Are we missing information, analysis?  Delayed intervention always costs much more. We simply need to allocate more money. The truth is that we have not put in place adequate instruments to safeguard the agricultural market when implementing the reform. I am referring to the so-called safety net. Here, too, we , as the Commission, as Parliament, have stepped down, and I think that was also our oversight. Agricultural production depends on many factors. For this reason, it is subject to certain fluctuations. Overcapacity must be removed from the market. There is difficult self-regulation. Even the financial markets were unable to regulate themselves, as the crisis after 2008 showed.  We say that the remedy is to improve competitiveness. There is a lot of truth in this, but competitiveness leads to concentration, concentration to industrialisation, and this is no longer the model of European agriculture.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I am afraid that the measures you are proposing in your package will not solve the fundamental problem faced by farmers, who are not asking for aid but for prices to enable them to make a living from their work. I was hoping that you would propose in the short term the increase in the intervention price for milk and the unblocking of the Russian health embargo on pigs, but none of this has been proposed. Storage, flexibility and promotion measures will be insufficient, even inefficient and costly, for European taxpayers as agricultural prices will continue to fall and nothing will be settled, either in the short term or in the long term. It is time, Commissioner, for the Commission to get out of its liberal ideology and realis that without a common public agricultural policy and without regulation of agricultural markets, tomorrow there is a great risk that there will be no more peasants in our territories to feed the 500 million Europeans.

name: Janusz Wojciechowski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The amounts of aid that are proposed after agreement with the Council of Ministers for Agriculture, that is, not just a drop in the sea – it is a drop in the ocean of needs.  Only in Poland do we have millions of hectares of sun-scorched land, losses due to drought going into hundreds of millions of euros, and perhaps even billions, and the eur 28 million envisaged is completely inadequate to these losses. In medicine there is a saying "primum non nocere" – first of all, do no harm. And I would like to recall this saying – first of all, do not harm the penalties for milk quotas.  In the face of this great drought disaster that has hit Poland, the payment by farmers of penalties that exceed eur 200 million leads to the bankruptcy of many farms. The abolition of those penalties which do not serve any purpose would constitute real aid, because the quotas have, after all, been abolished. In the name of what values do farmers have this harasser, these terrible penalties to pay? They should be abolished. Then we would feel that this is help.

name: Ulrike Müller (ALDE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the way in which I am particularly pleased that Commissioner Hogan is able to take part in the debate today and to have it with us. We recognise your efforts to accommodate us, and I believe that we all agree here in this House that the situation on the agricultural markets requires a package of measures. The peasant protests were justified.  Have I understood correctly that, in order to bring forward direct payments up to 70%, there is no need for on-the-spot checks to be finalised? And what concrete measures will you take now?  I can welcome the spontaneous purchase sily actions of my colleague Mr Des. Opening up new markets – yes, but this also includes standardising export requirements in the veterinary sector. I welcome a moderate increase in the EU intervention price. However, I cannot support a relapse into small-scale statehood and the mutual closure of borders.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the crisis in small and medium-sized holdings, in all production sectors and especially in recent days, in the dairy sector, is a reality. In my country, in Galicia, after two months of mobilization, today there are five days of milk strike. And now it comes to us here, Commissioner, with the same proposals that they have been making for thirty years. Thirty years have been talking about competing, looking for outings in the foreign market, and it turns out that in my country, in Galicia, in twenty-five years, 80,000 farms disappeared in the dairy sector alone. Really, this proposal is useless. I appeal to the Commission, the Council, the Majority Groups of this House, the People's Party, Socialists and Democrats, to address this crisis with public policies, to regulate production, to guide, to prioritise the domestic market, to propose instruments that guarantee the price and allow us to live off our production, and to support sustainable modes of real production.

name: Martin Häusling (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner, you have still not talked about crisis today. You have talked about difficulties, which is a trivialisation. We have a real crisis, and this with an announcement, because the policy of market liberalisation, the orientation of the world market, of more production has now finally come to the fore. What is the Commission's response? Open up more new markets, Vietnam, Colombia, Mexico. That is insane! In this way, we are exacerbating the crisis if we now think that we simply need to look for other markets. And the farmers are comforted with 20 euros per cow, so that they can stand still. What you and the Agriculture Ministers have put forward in terms of instruments is out of the moth box. That is really sixties, when we say: warehousing. Perhaps in the end, export promotion. And now a new high-level group. This is really nothing more than a total failure by the Commission, but also by the Member States in response to the crisis. All I can say is that we need to coordinate supply and demand in Europe. And the farmers who have demonstrated are prepared to do so. They do not want a few handouts, they want exactly this market policy. And you refuse to do that. All I can say is that less is more, and quality is better than mass production. And you are still not on the trail, but you still want a world market. That's wrong!

name: Mario Borghezio (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it will be difficult to make it clear to farmers that, by driving their tractor, more than a thousand kilometres have come from my piedmont and other regions of Europe to defend their work. So are the wine producers, and so are the other pig farmers, all in crisis, all in the face of prices that are a long way from being able to allow an honest remuneration for their work. We have given thousands of billions to the banks and we reject those measures that the agricultural world is humbly, courageously and decisively, but also forcefully demanding of us.  I imagine the Commission's embarrassment at having to speed up the process of a cap reform that has just been approved and has already changed. I imagine the embarrassment of the European institutions justifying to farms the real reasons for Russia's embargo on food products from half of Europe, which sacrificed a very important commercial outlet that represented an important prospect for thousands of European companies. Perhaps we also need to think about a new Europe in agriculture: this 40 % of the European budget that is used for agricultural policy must be better used, more honestly, towards those who sweat and work on the land, who are the best of this Europe, which cares a great deal about those who make immigrant assistants professional and fuck themselves with our farmers!

name: Esther Herranz García (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to congratulate you tonight on taking up much of the requests made by the European dairy sector and also supported by this Parliament, but I must ask you, once again, not to rule out the idea of increasing the intervention price of milk, if these aid envisaged is not sufficient to stop the collapse of prices. The members of the European People's Party already stated in the letter to which Mr Dea was speaking, in that letter we sent him, that many of us believe that the possibility of raising the price of the intervention on a temporary basis should not be forgotten, if such measures are not sufficient. Because twenty-one cents doesn't even cover production costs. I would remind you that months ago there was an exercise in reflection on the dairy sector after the quotas. However, despite the obvious signs of alarm, the Commission considered it unnecessary to introduce innovative measures, beyond the dairy package which was approved at the time to improve the chain's relations. I hope that the crisis in this sector is currently at least to help the Commission change the idea of this approach a little bit.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I am pleased with your recovery. I have to tell you, as other Members have already said, that the last few months have been very difficult for different agricultural productions, especially for the dairy sector, but also for other agricultural productions, because of the Russian veto. I mean, we've had serious problems. This situation has not been taken into account until the farmers have collapsed the city of Brussels, that is, until 7 September. Just over two months have been fighting for Spanish farmers to defend a fair price for the production of their milk. You have now agreed, together with the Council, on a package of measures , welcome - but this will not solve the problem. The problem is that there is a structural problem in European agriculture , understand this – and they know it. Supply management mechanisms need to be improved and it is taken seriously that protective measures should be taken for producers in the food chain. As long as this isn't resolved, we're putting Band-Aids in a big wound.

name: Richard Ashworth (ECR).
text: – Mr President, agricultural commodity prices always track global energy prices. So at a time when we have experienced falling gas and oil prices farmers have also suffered from over-supplied global commodity markets, the Russian trade ban, exchange rate issues, and in some commodities exceptional factors such as the end of the milk quota. So this is not a normal cyclical downturn. These are exceptional times and exceptional circumstances, and farming is caught up in a perfect storm.  So I make two points. First, I am happy that the Commissioner recognises the very tough times our farmers are facing and I compliment him on the aid package, which I think is both appropriate and welcome. Second, while the storm will pass, I urge both the Commission and the farming industry to learn the lessons of this crisis, and in so doing to turn it into an opportunity to build a more competitive and more resilient food sector for the future.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. Chairman, the respected Commissioner of the European Commission, the crisis has been going on for a long time. And the crisis is very deep. I have no doubt that you are aware of this, I have had the opportunity to speak to you and I have become familiar with your good intentions.  Here we can also read your good intentions in these measures, but we must realistically see if we will actually succeed because I fear that the crisis is not only too long, but also too deep as I said, and such a crisis will need probably more radical reforms to succeed in eventually getting the whole sector up. We all want to help you do that. Base on family farms, on authentic quality European products. Reform is definitely needed, as are probably the very radical measures we expect from you in the coming months.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I cannot thank you either for being here today, nor for that last injection of aid that is coming to Spain and which, as you say, is to alleviate the consequences of the economic crisis. And I'm not going to give them to you because they've condemned our dairy sector, and that doesn't deserve forgiveness or forgetfulness. They will not be able to buy our silence for many million-dollar aids that come, which are not at the root of the problem. The dairy crisis is structural and represents the vivid image of the Europe to which you want to advocate us, a Europe of elites and without the peoples. We are with our ranchers and we will be during the entire political cycle of change that we are experiencing. The ability to have resources to feed people is something that should never be for sale. Fortunately, the course of history is set by the people and I assure you, ladies and gentlemen, that our people will have a memory.

name: Maria Heubuch (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Six months ago, we were made palatable by the great opportunity of the free market, the liberal market. Demand and growth of 2% per annum were forecasts. And what do we have today? Today we are talking about a crisis and we are looking for culprits – some of the culprits have already been identified here. But I say this crisis is homemade! We have been working towards this!  They talk about liquidity problems and want to solve the problem with cheap loans and early payments. But the loans are even more indebted to the companies. And if you prefer the payments, what do you prefer if the crisis persists longer? And it looks like it.  We create liquidity at a good price. And we create a good price with functioning markets. We do not have the power to manage demand, but we have it in our hands to control supply. We can use the lever here, quickly and very purposefully.  With this aggressive world market policy, you are letting our farms down. They are even driving the companies that have only now invested in order to be sustainable.

name: Herbert Dorfmann (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the A crisis in agriculture, as we are currently experiencing, is affecting many thousands of farming families in Europe. That is why it is undoubtedly right and necessary for us to seek ways out of this situation, especially with regard to the milk market. I therefore welcome the Commissioner's decisions to step up market measures such as private storage and, above all, the promotion of advertising. In my opinion, they are also more promising than direct payments of a few hundred million euros. That sounds like a lot of money, but if you convert that to milk, it's 0.2-0.3 cents per litre of milk. That will not make the big difference. However, this crisis also affects in particular those farmers who have to work under difficult conditions in less-favoured areas and mountain areas. They already have a weak income, which is now completely broken away. That is why, Commissioner, we should start to think about how we can really help these companies. And this Parliament adopted a report more than two years ago which set out solutions which include, in particular, direct support for processors in mountain areas. Commissioner, we should take up these considerations again.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the milk and pork crisis is causing strong disputes in Europe, and the package proposed by the European Commission is a response to the difficulties in the sector, but not enough for the support farmers expect from us. For example, for Romania, the amount of EUR 11.1 million is small for the 1 150 000 applicants for direct payments, as well as for producers affected by the Russian embargo, on the one hand, and drought, on the other.  Today we are talking about a crisis, a crisis that persists, and that is why I believe that, in addition to the financial package proposed by the Commission, in addition to the measures related to the flexibility given to the Member States to direct aid to appropriate measures, private storage aid, targeted or state aid, it must be borne in mind that there is also the crisis reserve for the crisis. In addition, all these measures want to resolve the situation at the moment, but what is needed is to find medium- and long-term solutions that give an adequate response. Thanks.

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I am astonded to note the Commission's proposal to divide eur 400 million between the various EU countries in view of the agricultural crisis. For Polish, only EUR 29 million is foreseen when our agriculture is affected by a catastrophic drought that has resulted in plant production losses of more than EUR 1 billion for the time being. Over the next few months, due to the lack of roughage, producers of beef cattle and dairy cows will also suffer serious losses, which will only dramatically increase the loss balance.  In a situation where profitability in Polish agriculture is among the lowest of all european Union countries, when Polish milk producers pay penalties for milk overproduction for the second year in a row – this year it is about one hundred and eighty million euros – the Commission's proposal to support Polish farmers with only EUR 29 million is unacceptable. A real aid to Polish farmers would be for the Commission not to collect penalties for exceeding milk quotas.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, the agricultural sector has suffered a great deal recently, especially in Finland and the Baltic states. We've been touched by the Russian boycott. It can be said that, throughout Finland's membership of the European Union, farmers have been the group of people who have suffered most economically from EU membership. And unfortunately still suffers. However, I would like to take this opportunity to thank the Commission, which, with the Luxembourg Presidency, made a great effort in obtaining EUR 500 million for the sector on a fast schedule. Although that amount of money is small compared to the losses that have been made to the agricultural sector, it is still a significant symbolic aid. As regards the criteria for the share of the national envelope, comparing the price of milk with the EU average price was peculiar, as it does not take account of price changes. A reduction in the price, measured in cents, would have been fairer. In the future, it will be important that market support measures are made available alongside direct payments. I also hope that the Commission will speed up the launch of a high-level group on price-led futures markets. These can provide the Commission with important information on future price developments and reduce volatility.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the situation in agriculture is disastrous and predictable. By giving up all public regulatory instruments, the successive revisions of the CAP, with special emphasis on the last of 2013, generated this hell that threatens the survival of an entire sector. The replacement of these public instruments with derivative financial products only increased volatility and served to further fatten financial groups.  The recent farmers' demonstration in Brussels, which follows so many others across Europe, is the most eloquent proof of the complete failure of a new CAP geared towards the complete liberalisation of markets.  The European Commission's response is clearly insufficient. There is an urgent need to intervene in the markets to stop the collapse of prices, but it is no less urgent to start working on a complete review of the whole common agricultural policy, in defence of our traditional model, which is the only one capable of ensuring sustainable and safe agriculture.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE).
text: – On the one hand, I am pleased that we are finally calling today's situation a crisis. This was also clearly demonstrated to us by the farmers who protested in Brussels a week ago. In Lithuania, the deepest crisis has covered the dairy sector and the farming of pigs due to plague. I am grateful to the institutions of the European Union for their understanding. Unfortunately, the support granted covers not a third of the loss suffered. I would like to ask the Commission, the Council and everyone who is here, are we sure that this is the way Europe wants to go? Don't we need milk anymore? Because water is already more expensive than milk. I think it is enough to speak blankly, it is time to act and introduce market regulation mechanisms, to establish a system of fair settlement market players, especially in the dairy sector. Let us step up our support for cooperation, because otherwise the European Union's investment from taxpayers, both past and present and future, is meaningless.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE).
text: Mr President, Mr President of the Council, Commissioner, we are pleased to have you, Commissioner, visibly in good shape, with us this evening. I know this is not a very pleasant time for you and your team, but it is nothing compared to the disarray that milk producers, pork producers and beef producers are experiencing right now. Everyone has their share of responsibility. With regard to the intervention price, let us remind the Council that it demanded that it be set itself during the reform of the CAP. So we are now waiting for action since, in fact, the price of milk has fallen to levels where it no longer pays. And I would remind you that the reform of the CAP allows you to take into account not only the market price but also the level of charges. You, Commissioner, have an article at your disposal, which is Article 219. Obviously, that is the one you will use to put in place the 500 million aid that you have just provided. But that $500 million, it will probably be three months before they are in the pockets of the operators and how many will have fallen by then? We also need to act at the FAO level to bring to life what the G20 has committed to regulating commodity price volatility. You have to get involved in this project.

name: Marju Lauristin (S&D).
text: – Mr President, The Commission and, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Van Rompuy, for his excellent work. This is good news that agricultural support has nevertheless been allocated to producers in Estonia and the Baltic countries, given our exceptional situation, in which both the Russian embargo, the whole dairy crisis – which in fact is still the result of brussels politics – and the African swine fall that has hit us. It has really caused a catastrophe.  The day before yesterday, our farmers were not in Brussels, but in Tallinn. They also demanded more effective action from the Estonian government and municipalities. Against this background, the news of last night has been very positive and very well received.  I believe that this will also help to strengthen the solidarity of the people of Estonia, also to help the people of other countries. But it's certainly not enough. This is not financially sufficient and is not sufficient for other measures. The most important thing is probably that the Commission has planned to focus on the original producer, the first link of the whole supply chain, all the aid measures and organisational measures, including VAT issues and the reduction of red tape. We look forward to further action and hope that we can still overcome this crisis together

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the title of this debate sticks out just a little bit. It is called the ‘Ongoing crisis in the agriculture sector’. Now, given that the Commissioner is here to try to help us solve these problems, it is a little bit worrying that only last July – and even after that – we were told by him that there was no crisis. ‘Ongoing’ suggests it has been going on for quite a while. I am just wondering, Commissioner, how long you think it has been going on, because on the last few occasions you met us you told us there was no crisis? The big problem is not going to be solved by throwing a few quid at farmers. It is like giving Roscommon a one point lead in a hurling match against Kilkenny – nice thought, but it will not solve the problem. The problem will be solved by making the big smaller so they do not continue to crush the producers. We need to fund producer groups, but I find it very interesting that the Commission seems to want to limit their size. I do not see much work on limiting the size of Tesco or Lidl or Aldi. That is the only way we will get it to work, because otherwise they will continue to crush the producer. If you are serious, you will do something about this, Commissioner, though I will not hold my breath.

name: Jordi Sebastià (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, have you been surprised by this crisis? Because she must be the only one in this room who didn't expect her. We have long known that the European Union's import regime is very damaging to our producers. We've known for a long time that the prices that the big distribution chains are paying our producers a pittance, they suffocate them, they don't allow them to survive. And the Commission is proposing the only thing it proposes to us is a voluntary code of good practice. That's useless. We also knew that, with deregulation, the dairy sector and the pig sector were going to go into crisis. And we also knew the Russian veto was there. And what have you done? Practically nothing: aid that does not help the situation and which are also random, some do and some do not. What do I say to the producers in my country? What do I tell the khaki producers, the producers of the grenade? That We Valencians are not Europeans? This problem of European agriculture is not an acute problem, it is a chronic problem. And now you come here with 500 million euros, thinking that's going to fix something? Do you know the budget of Real Madrid Football Club? 540 million euros.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE).
text: – Mr President, first of all I want to welcome the EUR 30 million that the Commission has made available and put aside for the migrant issue because I was disturbed to hear in this Parliament that in some migrant and refugee camps people are being given only 800 calories a day and there is no milk for babies. This is really important from a humanitarian point of view.  Commissioner, I welcome the joined-up thinking between the President of the Commission, Mr Juncker, and yourself on agriculture issues and I welcome your rapid response. I have been here a while and I have seen previous Commissioners ignore our call for a response, so I welcome all of those things and, in particular, your focus on the food supply chain. You have our support on that, so keep up the work. Let me talk about what is happening globally. In Canada, where they have tightly regulated price and market controls, they are dumping milk. They have a problem in their marketplace. In New Zealand, where they have a free market with no controls, their farmers are literally going out of business with huge mental health and financial problems being experienced. In the US, with counter-cyclical payments, they have greater volatility than we do. There is no quick fix. We have to put our heads together and find one.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I thank you for the presence of the Council and the Commission and I hope that Commissioner Hogan will be fully recovered. The measures announced for the agricultural sector are welcome. It is certain that the Commissioner was listening, but he only heard it when he wanted it and what he wanted. The Commissioner has repeatedly denied the warnings that this house has made to him in relation to the milk sector. It took farmers to go to Brussels to get their needs straight and at a good time.  These measures, I repeat, are welcome, but they are not the solution to the problems that are becoming structural in the milk sector and which have been exacerbated by the Russian embargo. We need solutions for yesterday and capable of guaranteeing a fair price to producers and maintaining production where there are no alternative economic activities and we need productive regions with comparative disadvantages to be properly taken into account in the configuration of support and new instruments that can effectively regulate supply.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL).
text: Commissioner, Minister, I have the impression that you are not listening. You do not hear the cries of anguish, suffering and sometimes despair that are rising from our campaigns. It is no longer a crisis, as they say, it is a torrent of misfortune that is falling and that is hard for the peasants. On the other hand, the processing industries and the banks are getting more profit from this situation. You can't leave it to the measurements you've announced. There is no alternative but to pay for work through basic prices with regulated production volumes. We have to go back to milk quotas. Legislation is also needed to ensure that the processing and retail industry stops plundering peasant labour. On the other hand, we must use all the intervention mechanisms at our disposal for the price of milk, pork and beef as well as vegetables. It's urgent.

name: Elisabeth Köstinger (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner, thank you very much for the opportunity to have this debate with you today. I also believe that it is really time to help farmers in Europe in this very tense and difficult situation. Massive fears of existence are palpable in the companies. It just doesn't work out at the back and in the front. And the measures adopted – and I agree with you on this – of almost EUR 500 million are really very, very much money, especially in times of tight budgets; for our farmers, however, it is really only drops on the hot stone. I believe that it really is time and very important to consider how we can secure the markets in the long term, how we can also secure operating incomes. This will be essential. For example, the boosting of markets is very important, but I believe that we must also pay particular attention to trade. Our colleague Mairead McGuinness is currently working on a very important report, including on unfair trade practices, on concentration in the trade market as well.  We see it again and again: as soon as prices rise, it takes a very long time before they are actually passed on to farmers. If there is a difficult situation on the market, retail chains are the first to tighten the price screw among farmers. This must finally stop!

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the agricultural world is on its knees as a result of a crisis of which the continuous contraction in prices and profitability margins is only one aspect. Global oversupply has now reached alarming percentages, and the closure of the Russian market and the growing demand difficulties in the Chinese market are a further criticality.  The CAP itself does not have effective instruments to deal with this state of crisis: there is a need for immediate solutions and a new approach on the part of the European Commission. Yesterday in Luxembourg, the extraordinary eur 500 million aid package, the private storage of cheese and meat and the extraordinary promotion for the two sectors on the internal market and in third countries were confirmed. However, I regard this as a sign of goodwill, but it does not address the issue of falling prices for agricultural products and does not respond to the problem of unfair trade practices.  These two points require direct action by the European Competition Authority on the food chain, in particular on the issue of the price of production and consumption. There is no traditional action that can change the scenario, Commissioner, a qualitative leap forward in European policies is essential.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I welcome the Commission's decision to allocate EUR 500 million to support farmers. However, we are witnessing today a dark period for agriculture in the European Union and, by implication, in Romania. The embargo imposed by Russia, the elimination of quotas on the milk market but, above all, this year's drought put the entire agricultural sector at a major difficulty. I would, however, like to draw attention in particular to the difficult situation of livestock farmers who, in the face of the current crisis, are put in a position to slaughter their animals because they are no longer coping with the maintenance costs, due to the high price of feed, and thus claim much more sustained support. We also cannot further ignore the major differences between direct subsidies received by farmers in the Member States, which, in relation to the same single market, creates unacceptable inequities. I would therefore stress once again the need for a linearity of subsidies for all farmers in the Member States. Thanks.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D).
text: Mr President, as early as January 2015, I was announcing this crisis which was inevitable. Inevitable because, while we had not yet come out of milk quotas, we had already produced 4.5% more in one year at European level. New Zealand earned 8.1% and Australia 2.6%. Even though consumption is increasing slightly globally, the world is full of milk. And what do I hear? Neoliberal sorcerer's apprentices, often from northern Europe elsewhere, tell us that we need to find other markets, while the world is full of milk. They tell us that we have to be competitive — I point out that in Denmark one in two dairy industrial farms is virtually bankrupt — and they argue that we must always adapt. This is an insult to European farmers because many of them have already adapted and modernised to meet the standards that we ourselves have set and which are more drastic. So there are crises in the dairy sector, in the pork, beef and fruit and vegetable sectors and because liberal Europe continues to advocate for the destruction of market regulation.  So that's what we have to do. Here we have some helpers that are welcome, but they are obviously insufficient. New supply-regulating mechanisms are needed to restore decent prices that will allow farmers to make a living from their work.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: - Mr. President, I commend the swift response of the Commission and Commissioner Hogan and the approval of EUR 500 million for crisis interventions in the dairy sector. Unfortunately, the Commissioner himself is as aware as all of us here that the funds envisaged will not be sufficient to patch up all the loopholes resulting from political decisions, which farmers have had no influence on. I am of the opinion that we also need to think more strongly and strongly support measures that will be more effective than existing ones in order to save in the dairy sector what is saved yes. It is difficult for all farmers, yet this crisis is felt far more strongly in new Member States where a farmer must give 3 l of milk for 1 l of water.  In Croatia, for example, 75% of the money earmarked to support agriculture does not end up in the hands of small farms to which this money is earmarked, but in the hands of large companies. In addition, Croatian farmers pay up to 5 times more interest on loans than their Western European counterparts and are in a state of debt bondage. Faced with disloyal competition and a government that doesn't care about them, they rightly wonder how they will survive, and therefore of course they have high expectations of you, Commissioner Hogan, because they know that you understand them well.

name: Maria Noichl (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner, there is a saying that 'if the horse is dead, then go down'. And I would like to transfer this saying: change your consultants if your consultants no longer have new ideas for you! Because the ideas you have put forward are really ideas from the last century. No other industry, not a single other industry produces with closed eyes in an oversaturated market. And it is not right to use taxpayers' money to buy out overproduction, store it or export it anywhere else.  That is, there is a adjusting screw, and the adjusting screw means to reduce the amount. It's like driving a car: sometimes throttle, sometimes brake. Now it's time to brake. Farmers need the framework conditions to ensure that the quantity can be braked in solidarity.  I would like to remind you, Commissioner, that if the horse is dead, you will go down!

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the origin of the crisis we are experiencing is determined by many causes, we have repeated them, colleagues have repeated them this evening: very low prices due to the crisis, the blocking of exports to Russia, the situation on the Chinese market, a bureaucracy that continues to be omnivorous anyway – we can call it that, unfortunately also as a means of exercising power by politics. We have a huge cost of energy which affects not only the life of industry, but also the life of our agriculture.  So the initial solutions identified by the Commission, in my view, are correct: economic intervention is a good thing, and the identification of the storage instrument by private individuals is also good, but they postpone the problem, as we know. Then we show that we understand that the first link in the chain is not what the product often looks like, the first link in the chain is the manufacturer, that is, it is an entrepreneur. Let us show attention to a person who is not only destined to take, that is to say to receive the resources that we rightly allocate to him, but is destined to undertake, that is, to release his energies in order to generate value.

name: Paul Brannen (S&D).
text: – Mr President, does the Commissioner agree that fairness in agricultural markets is not just about producers, processors and retailers, but is also about consumers? Much of what we have addressed this evening is essentially about the short—term difficulties in the supply chain, especially in the dairy sector.  I agree with the Commissioner that raising the milk intervention price is not the right answer. Instead, we should be unleashing the power of the consumer, unleashing the power of the customer. A significant minority – maybe even a majority – of EU customers want to help our EU farmers. This could be achieved if we had an independent fair price certification scheme, similar to the existing Fairtrade mark which guarantees a fair price is being paid to the farmer in the developing world. Such a scheme would enable the customer to easily identify our farmers’ products, even if this means paying an additional, slightly higher, price. Many will do so. Customers and farmers alike need a fair deal to guarantee a fair price at the farm gate.

name: Annie Schreijer-Pierik (PPE).
text: – Last Monday I stood between the farmers to support them in their protest. That's where I heard the concerns of our family businesses. Yesterday it became clear that dutch farmers received EUR 30 million as aid. We're happy with that. But that money must go to those who really need it. In addition, we must set up a European stability fund as soon as possible, as agreed in Belgium through the Belgian Agri-Food Chain Consultations, which was unveiled last week. The fund should be a safety net for affected farmers during another agricultural crisis. Agriculture ministers must also sit down to create a level Playing Field in Europe, especially when it comes to inspection costs. Finally, the most important item on the agenda in the near future: the position of the farmer in the chain. Like my colleague Mairead McGuinness, I think the power of the supermarkets is too great. In order to change this situation, the competition rule needs to be changed. Commissioner Hogan, I would therefore urge you to continue discussing this with Magrethe Vestager, your fellow Commissioner. Otherwise, we'll keep talking and nothing will get off the ground and no money will end up on the kitchen table.

name: Norbert Lins (PPE).
text: Mr President, Minister, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for the work he has Thank you for allowing us to have this debate here this evening. I have the impression that we are talking the situation – now I am speaking in particular for my region and my country – almost a little worse than it actually is. I believe that the Commission has done the right thing. Nor do I believe that we should underestimate the measures now. EUR 500 million is a great deal of money. I could, of course, also imagine more, especially more, for promotion. I think we have seen in the years, especially in 2013 and 2014, when we had more outlets, especially after China and, of course, russia, that the price of milk there was very, very good. I believe that we should also take advantage of these opportunities in other regions of the world. And we should also put more money into our hands for this.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the eur 500 million that has been announced as the solution to this profound crisis will only depart from structural decision-making for two or three months from now, Commissioner. The amount allocated to Portugal is insufficient. What do you mean when you allocate EUR 4.8 million to a country when in one of its regions, the Azores alone, the losses are already in the case of OVER 30 million?  To apply the same key allocation of funds to Member States that are suffering the enormous impact of this crisis on an equal footing with others that have contributed to it happening is unfair. As regards information and promotion programmes, I ask you: do you consider that the agricultural sector, in particular the regions such as the Azores, which accumulates losses, will be able to co-finance any action? I would ask you to consider full funding in the regions most affected by the milk crisis, otherwise only large European companies will have that capacity. Commissioner, milk production in the Azores is a structural pillar of our economy because because of our natural constraints we have no alternatives. We know how to produce milk and produce it with great quality and its non-decisions, the fact that we do not look at these regions, as provided for in the Treaties, is leading to a slow death of the sector with enormous financial, social, family and economic losses.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – Greetings, Honourable Commissioner, Mr Hogan. On my part, too, thanks for the action to at least some time try to alleviate the difficult crisis, the deep crisis in the agricultural sector. I agree with those who point out that it was probably a late reaction and that we had detected this crisis a few months earlier than now in the autumn, and that the amount is also relatively low. In Slovenia, with 1.4 million, we will not solve the crisis, but it is necessary to work in the future. On the one hand, it will probably have to intervene in agricultural policy, but on the other hand I also support the efforts made by my colleague McGuinness in the area of trade practices, because I believe that the European consumer is willing to pay more than half a litre of milk for a litre of milk, and that order must also be done in this area. On the other hand, it also stimulates the integration of European farmers so that they can better resist, above all, the pressures of large and concentrated trade.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the European dairy sector, including my region, Galicia, one of the most important producing regions in Europe, has been suffering from a continuous price decline for months for a variety of reasons, including the disappearance of milk quotas, the Russian veto, the decline in exports to China and overproduction in Australia and New Zealand, as stated above. The Spanish Public Administration reacted by introducing various measures, also of a legislative nature, as well as aid for the most disadvantaged farms. In Spain, an agreement is being finalized involving distribution, industry and farmers to, in substance, try to balance the value chain, seek the stability and sustainability of this chain. But in addition to efforts at national level, efforts are needed at European level, of course. That is why I welcome the measures announced by the Commission following meetings with the Ministers of Agriculture these days, but, Commissioner, we must continue to combat price volatility. I hope that these measures will have an effect, but I reiterate my request, already expressed in other ways, that it may be necessary to raise, increase, the intervention prices.

name: José Blanco López (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, as has been said, the viability of many dairy farms, in my homeland, Galicia, is in danger. And in this crisis not only is the viability of a sector at stake: a way of life is at stake, that our rural environment is still alive, that our rural environment remains populated. But also our food security. Not everything can be limited to the law of supply and demand. Europe must protect its food sovereignty, it must promote a living field that nourishes our internal market for quality food. Commissioner, it is urgent - it has just been said and I repeat this — to raise the prices for intervention, as the sector and many Member States have demanded. Give us good news at this time of night and say it's going to raise intervention prices. The measures, ladies and gentlemen, are insufficient: 40 billion for the bank bailout, just 25 million to help the dairy sector in Spain and, in the first place, Galicia.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Mr. President, in my country Croatia, the crisis in the agricultural sector is undoubtedly hitting small producers that are struggling to cope with rising production costs and who have not been sufficiently facilitated by placing products on the common market. The constant raising of prescribed production standards may seem to benefit consumers, but it harms them in the long run because it reduces the possibility of choice. Due to the over-regulation of the agricultural sector, production and marketing of products are increased, and only large producers can survive this.  The certain decline of small family farms thus leaves consumers without quality products that could be competitive so that politics does not intervene so much in agriculture. Europe must preserve its tradition of family farming, and this is only possible through tax and administrative relief of small family farms and greater availability of information and funds.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, producers in the primary sector must participate in the value chain generated by agri-food processing and marketing. Today, large industries run the market without giving up work or the social and environmental role of farmers and ranchers. We need more interprofessional agreements to stabilize prices, committed institutions to accompany initiatives and sanction breaches, more cooperatives, innovation in the sector, shorter sales chains, quality, food security and new technologies to contact the end consumer. We need labeling that provides assurance and promotes producer-consumer empathy. In my country we have problems, yes, but dairy farmers who have taken and followed these steps—such as the Kaiku cooperative, Iparlat, etc.—are better facing these turbulence. I think they are a reference and a hope, and they deserve recognition today.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. In the Polish region where I come from, a drought that no one remembers has reduced the harvest of crops for cattle by more than fifty percent. The owners of these dairy farms are not so much faced with the problem of reduced profitability of production or loss of liquidity – the owners of these farms face the problem of losing all the production potential of primary stocks, which they have built up for many years, perhaps even for generations. I think that this problem in the European Commission's proposal has not been properly weighed and taken into account. Eur 500 million may indeed be a significant amount, but milk producers in Europe will only pay much more penalties for the previous year. In Poland, the previous year'skars amount to one hundred and sixty million euros, and support for the dairy and pig sector is less than thirty million. This is clearly insufficient support, Commissioner.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, if I am here, at this late hour, it is to draw your attention to an issue essential for the very future of agriculture in Reunion and, in particular, sugar cane.  You know that a trade agreement has been signed between the European Union and Vietnam, providing for a liberalisation tariff quota of 20,000 tonnes. It is with astonishment, I must tell you, that we have learned that, in this agreement, there was no provision for the exclusion of special sugars, contrary to the commitments made by the European Commission and the assurances that you had also given us to do everything possible to protect the outermost regions in these trade agreements.  There are a few days left in the drafting of the details of this agreement to act that these special sugars are excluded from this agreement or, at a minimum, to find the mechanisms to ensure that the entry of Vietnamese special sugars into the European market is limited.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, in Greece the ongoing crisis in the agricultural sector has financially destroyed farmers. The memorial governments, at the behest of the troika, over-taxed Greek farmers. The tax raid has also been illegally extended to the Community aid they receive. Typically, over the past five years, the income of Greek farmers has fallen by one and a half billion euros, while the taxes they paid have increased by 150%. At the same time, the crisis that erupted as a result of the Russian embargo has financially destroyed the agricultural sector. Moreover, greek farmers who are impoverished by the memorandum are unable to cope financially as they were also tested by last year's natural disasters. And the tombstone for Greek farmers came from the SYRIZA-ANEL co-government which, with the support of the New Democracy, PASOK and Potamos, through the third memorandum, proceeded to increase the taxation of agricultural oil and to further increase the unaffordable taxation on farmers. The European Union must therefore take immediate action on the crisis in the agricultural sector and finance, above all, small and medium-sized farmers throughout Europe and, of course, my own country, Greece.

name: Peter Jahr (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Thank you, Commissioner, for allowing us to discuss the issue today. Nor do I want to repeat everything that my colleagues have said, except a small thank you for the programme, because it is a right step in the right direction. And you also live in the market economy of politics. And politics is also a sign of providing money. I wanted to refer to another problem, which I see as the main problem, particularly in the dairy sector. Why are we not making progress? I think that in the dairy sector, our main problem is that our regulatory measures date back to the last century. We need to align them with a market economy. By 'we' I mean not only the Commission and the Members, by which I also mean farmers and dairies.  Our intervention mechanisms are too slow, cumbersome and planned. Dairies must be able to store milk powder and butter on their own. And we also need to bring more market economy into pricing. It is incomprehensible in itself that we still do not have contract prices and daily prices for milk production. If we implement this together, we can look to the future with optimism.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I wish to thank all the contributors to this very important debate here this evening. First of all, can I acknowledge to everybody in the House that there are difficulties and I have said that all along, contrary to what my good friend from Ireland stated earlier. I said there were going to be challenges, there were going be difficulties and volatility in 2015, and there is. All of you have demonstrated in your contributions this evening the empathy that you are showing to your sector. That is why the agricultural sector is receiving a package of EUR 500 million.  We do not have an unlimited budget as this House, and indeed the Council will verify, but we have some resources and I have put a package together of EUR 500 million in response to the concerns that have been expressed, not because there was a protest in Brussels but because you have been saying it for a number of months, and indeed in the Nicholson report in that debate in July we clearly signalled that the challenges ahead may require a multi-faceted response, and that is what this package is about.  Number one, I would like to remind people – and particularly my good friend from Galicia, when he talked about the banks getting EUR 40 billion of a bailout – that we give farmers EUR 40 billion a year per annum in direct payments, which is 42% of all the income of many of our farmers in the European Union, so we should not allow that to go unnoticed: that we do make a major contribution to the income of keeping as many farmers as possible in rural areas, by providing the value added in terms of employment to the 46 million people that are employed in the food sector, and providing good quality food for our consumers, as Mr Brannen, my colleague from the UK, rightly pointed out. There are four major areas that this package is going to be targeted at. Number one, there is an immediate cash flow problem for farmers. We have responded to that by relaxing the controls, and I hope that the members of Committee on Budgets who are here tonight will be able to understand that in two years’ time, when we come to scrutinise the performance of the department of DG AGRI and myself in relation to budget controls: that this is an exceptional situation which required an exceptional response in relation to relaxing some of the controls, to allow Member States to be able to pay money up to 70% in the case of direct payments, and up to 85% in rural development monies. Because to help cash flow, farmers need money now. They do not need a response that is going to take months and months. These measures that we are speaking about can be put in place with your help and support in five weeks. It is a matter for the Member States to be able to pay out that money as quickly as they possibly can.  Secondly, in relation to cash flow, there is a figure of EUR 420 million in terms of targeted aid. The criterion we used for that was the milk deliveries in the last milk year. We responded to the pigmeat crisis as well in terms of the fall in prices. We responded to the lower price in many countries, particularly in the eastern part of our European Union and Belgium, where we had a considerable reduction in the milk price, below the European average. We included for the first time, I would say to my Polish colleague, drought as a criteria. I am the first Commissioner to actually give money to Poland or anywhere else for drought, and it is probably a precedent that may come back to haunt me in the future. It is not a large amount of money, but it is certainly a clear indication of the difficulties faced by farmers who have been afflicted by drought, and it contributed to the envelope that Poland received in respect of that matter.  The second set of measures, then, are market measures. I could have decided to go down and agree with the temporary intervention price and an increase in the reference price. That would take, in the legislative process, about 18 months, so that is kicking the can down the road. If that is what you wanted to do I certainly was not prepared to do that. We needed immediate measures, and the private storage aid measures under Article 219 is what I invoked, where I developed a new scheme that was much more flexible and 100% financed from the European taxpayer.  This is going to be broadened to include skimmed milk powder and cheese and we are putting Member State quotas in place because we learned from the last experience that a few Member States could gobble up the entire quota. We are giving an initial quota to every Member State, but then allowing Member States to come back in after three months if they require more quotas. I think that is a fair distribution and a fair way of giving every Member State an opportunity in the first instance under this PSA scheme.  Could I say to the people who are saying that the market orientation is wrong that if I heard a lot of speakers tonight after the reduction in the Fonterra Global Dairy Auctions, I am sure over the summer months I would hear a lot of people saying that our market orientation is in trouble, but over the last four weeks there have been three auctions. The first one in August was 14.9% of an increase in prices, two weeks later 10.9% of an increase, and yesterday 16.8% of an increase in global dairy prices. So that hopefully will, in the true traditions of the marketplace, be able to feed itself in to higher prices – albeit there is a lag time before getting that to the farmer. But I think it is positive in terms of the market sentiment that this will create, and hopefully that will feed itself into farmers’ pockets.  In relation to the food chain, can I say to my colleague Mr Flanagan that I know he does not know a lot about hurling in Roscommon, and I would not expect him to, but coming from a county that knows the score a little, I hope you do not end up as a hurler in the ditch in this food chain issue because we are going to make, I think, major strides in this area in terms of engagement with the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development (AGRI Committee) and the Council. The President of the Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, in the State of the Union speech, said quite explicitly in his speech that there is a problem in relation to the food chain, and that is a recognition about what everybody has been saying here, about the fact that the producer is not getting a fair crack, to put it that way, in relation to the outcome of the particular transactions in agriculture.  I gave a commitment at my hearings, and indeed since, that I will promote, with other Commissioners the opportunity, legislative or otherwise, to ensure that we are actually going to redress the balance in favour of the producer in the context of the actors in the food chain. I know that Ms McGuinness is preparing a report for the AGRI Committee and that my colleagues Commissioner Bieńkowska and Commissioner Vestager are certainly more engaged than ever before with me in relation to seeing what we can do in order to improve matters in the food chain.  So the experience in Spain and the experience in the UK are models we can look at and see how best practice there can be implemented, perhaps, on a European-wide basis. If it is working well in a Member State, then let us see what is the best value we can get out of an evaluation of those particular schemes to see what can be done to replicate them around the European Union.  The fourth aspect is a societal response. At a time when we have huge demands on financial resources in the European Union, with the biggest crisis in the European Union for decades in terms of migration and refugees, we are responding with product, through charities and existing structures in the World Food Programme, and in various other ways through DG ECHO in order to respond to that. EUR 30 million is a modest amount of money, but it is certainly a contribution that we are making and we may be expected to make more in the future in order to deal with this particularly appalling humanitarian situation.  On the School Milk Scheme – with which Mr Tarabella has been quite extensively involved – and on how we can broaden the scope of that scheme, we are certainly ready to assist in completing that work as soon as we possibly can, with additional finance if necessary as well, as mentioned, the value of EUR 20 million. Targeted aid, may I say to those Members who mentioned it, can be used with a maximum flexibility. Member States can use this particular envelope for whatever they effectively wish in order to ensure that farmers are certainly getting the benefit, and also they can use it for structural reforms. Madam Herranz García from Spain mentioned, as well as others, that there is no point in throwing money at a problem now, and then hoping that we will have no problems in 2016. We need to use some of this money in a targeted and focused way to reform the sectors, to reform many of the structures that badly need reform, including more producer organisations and a more flexible approach in relation to that to get people more organised in collective bargaining. Agriculture is a cyclical business, it is unpredictable, and this is its hallmark for people involved in that business, and we will certainly have to be flexible and nimble in order to deal with it.  I do not subscribe to the notion that we have to invoke the Crisis Reserve at the moment. Farmers are getting lower prices and why would people be advocating that they should take a reduction in their direct payments as well at a time when they need a cash flow increase rather than a reduction in payments? I cannot understand that logic at the moment and why we would deal with it in that way.  The co-legislators decided in 2013 that we were adopting a reform that was going to be market orientated, and I am doing whatever I can through the various mechanisms that I have at my disposal to implement that particular policy faithfully. I am implementing what you required, and I can say to the French delegation that the quotas are gone; supply management issues are gone. That is what was decided some time ago and we are going to respect that, but we have tools at our disposal that we are using – some I have already explained – but in my view the French situation is considerably exacerbated by the problems in the food chain. There is a reasonable price being able to be received for milk, but it is not getting to the farmer. It is getting to everybody else in the food chain but not enough is going to the farmer. Maybe there are national as well as European responsibilities that we can collectively look at to try and help the French – and the UK situation is no different – so that we can get a reasonable return for the producer. As I have said many times, if we do not have a producer, then we will not have a product and we will not have product for employment as well as for the benefit of the consumer. In relation to the Azores, I think Madam Ribeiro knows my views very well. EUR 4.8 million has been allocated in a targeted aid package to the Minister for Agriculture in Portugal. It is a matter for the Member State government to decide how that is going to be allocated. So your job is to ensure that the Azores, as well as the regional government of Azores, get a fair proportion of that particular assistance that is now available to Portugal, because the maximum flexibility in the distribution of that is a matter for the Member States.  Can I say in relation to Galicia, and many people have mentioned Galicia, that it has a very serious problem in relation to its dairy sector but I know that Minister Tejerina has implemented a proposal in recent times of EUR 300 per cow in order to assist income and resolve the short-term difficulties – hopefully they are short-term – in relation to the dairy farmers in Galicia. That is a meaningful response and I congratulate her on doing so. Can I thank everybody for their contributions. I acknowledge that we have challenges. I acknowledge as well that we will continue to monitor the situation very carefully for the future, but I am also saying that we made a meaningful response of EUR 500 million in very challenging financial circumstances for the European Union. I am glad that we were able to secure that with the help of President Juncker and I hope that Member States will spend it well on behalf of the farming community.

name: Fernand Etgen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, honourable Members, when I appeared before the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development in July, I told you that the Luxembourg Presidency will continue to monitor market developments closely and will not hesitate to bring the matter back to the attention of ministers, if necessary. The Presidency has taken the situation seriously and, as of 24 July, we have convened an extraordinary meeting of agriculture ministers for 7 September. We discussed again the package of measures presented by the Commission at our informal meeting in Luxembourg yesterday. First of all, I note that, in your speeches, some questions and suggestions overlap broadly with those of the Council. I encourage the Commission to pay attention to this. Despite differences of opinion on some issues, it is now up to our two institutions to contribute to the finalisation of this first package of measures as quickly as possible, and in the first place on three points. Firstly, as part of the ongoing budget negotiations for the 2016 budget, as soon as the Commission has sent us the letter amending the budget so that funding is available. Secondly, as part of our respective procedures for reviewing delegated acts corresponding to certain measures. Finally, by proceeding quickly with negotiations on mechanisms to assist in the distribution of fruits and vegetables and milk in schools. This is only the first step. It must be deepened and, without questioning the market orientation of the CAP, to continue the effort of solidarity with the actors of the agricultural world. The Commissioner answered a number of questions and comments. So I'm going to limit myself to a few considerations on a number of points. In response to Jan Huitema, as I already pointed out in my initial speech, a well-conducted simplification programme can lead to a reduction in costs for farmers, at no additional cost to the EU budget. As some of you have also pointed out, this package of measures must be put into perspective and the amount must be assessed in the context of the other challenges that President Juncker mentioned before you in his State of the Union address. Finally, I would like to point out that many measures such as improving the transparency and fairness of the food chain can also contribute to the sustainability of the sector without having a direct budgetary cost. Several speakers talked about a possible increase in the intervention price. My first point is that given the differences in production costs between Member States, or even between regions, it is difficult to define an effective price level. My second point is that any change in intervention prices requires a proposal from the Commission in one form or another. At this stage, although calls have been made for an increase in the intervention price for milk, this interest is far from unanimous. On the other hand, I note that the Commission considers that this is not an appropriate response and that there are other instruments to respond to the market situation. In conclusion, I can assure you that the Council intends to carry out an initial assessment of the deployment of the measures at the November Council and that we will carry out a rigorous evaluation of the effectiveness of this package in the coming months.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. – Recent months are 20 significantly difficult for different production sectors of European agriculture, especially for the dairy sector. This is due to a number of factors, including the Russian embargo and the inclement weather of recent months. On more than one occasion, the European Parliament has sounded the alarm about the risk of market imbalance. However, a blockade of the city of Brussels last 7 September was needed for the Commission to put a package of measures on the table, which are nothing more than conjunctural solutions which do not address the under-depth problem. Once again, the need for effective and permanent crisis management tools with which we can deal with successive agricultural crises is highlighted, so as not to have to act on them with exceptional measures, as is happening these days. The functioning of the value chain is another factor in which we believe that a proactive role from the Commission is necessary for the agricultural income market to generate fair prices for producers.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. – The Russian embargo and the crisis in China have considerably undermined the European export market and negatively affected the European producers of such products as beef, pork and milk. We need to find a solution to help farmers who are on the edge on bankruptcy; this entails not only creating new effective risk management instruments for farmers but also looking for new markets to meet the supply.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This debate on the current crisis in the agricultural sector in Europe and France does nothing to resolve the situation of thousands of producers and farmers who expect this European Union to have another agricultural policy, allowing them to live with dignity in their production with minimum purchase prices rather than survive on new subsidies distributed in an emergency. The end of the measures against Russia would also lift the country's embargo on our agricultural products and give oxygen to our agriculture. The Commission must realar that it can no longer continue in this leak forward with its liberal ideology.
