We need to return to better market regulation, responsible public procurement to support our producers and strict control of our imports so as not to put our agriculture in competition with intensive agriculture like those in the United States that do not have the same health or social standards as ours and thus compete unfairly with our producers.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – The global milk market is becoming increasingly volatile. Livestock farming and the resources used for milk production are very vulnerable and, as a result, buying-in prices are lower than production costs. As the safeguard mechanism in place in the European Union has failed as a sufficient rescue in the event of a fall in milk prices, on 7 September 2015 there were mass protests in Brussels organised by the European Milk Council and copa-COGECA. The campaigns required fair prices for agricultural production, with particular attention to the milk, fruit and vegetables and meat sectors. The agricultural sector has been the hardest hit by political events, but there is also a surplus of production in the dairy sector, which is leading to falling prices. The European Commission is proposing a support package to address farmers' disadvantages. Farmers must be guaranteed the movement of cash flows, as well as targeted support to the dairy sector, especially in those countries where the crisis has hit hardest. It is essential to maintain demand promotion and supply reduction. To this end, it is proposed to extend the current private storage scheme and the period of public interventions. It also promotes the strengthening of supply chains. It is proposed to set up a high-level expert working group to engage in credit for farmers and mechanisms for reducing financial risks. The Commission recognises the need to strengthen relations between agriculture and the general public. This proposes to pay more attention to the members of the most vulnerable groups, such as taking into account the current refugee crisis and ensuring food supplies to them, for example through the distribution of dairy products.

name: Jørn Dohrmann (ECR)
text: Written. – Agriculture in Europe is in the most serious crisis for many years. European farmers, as a business group, are paying the price for the sanctions in connection with the Russia crisis, adding that the changes in the milk sector have meant that many dairy farmers have been completely changed in terms of their activities. As if that is not enough, some countries such as Denmark are adding a decisive crack at implementing EU rules in this area considerably more stringently than their neighbouring countries.  The agricultural crisis is also very much a crisis for the outlying regions of Europe, where agriculture is a very important profession in terms of jobs, economy and culture. The European agricultural sector is thus suffering from a number of challenges, and one might ask whether it is too late to address these challenges – and whether the storage of agricultural products in order to stabilise the market is a good idea... It can only help to pull the problem out.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. – The dairy sector is also in serious crisis in Hungary, the purchase price of raw milk has fallen to historic lows and is currently around 24 cents per litre, which does not cover the cost of production, which is around 35 cents per litre. The situation in Romania is even worse, where the fall in the purchase price stopped at around 10 cents. I thank the European Commission, and in particular you, for delivering EUR 420 million in emergency aid to EU dairy farmers and pig farmers. However, this is only enough to relieve the fire, not to put it out. It is not yet seen when the fall in producer prices will end. The two effective instruments that can now be deployed alone are the increase in the intervention price for skimmed-milk powder, butter and pigmeat, at least temporarily, and the temporary activation of export subsidies.  In my opinion, you are right that regular increases in intervention prices in the dairy sector would send the wrong message to farmers who are already overprot producing milk. They would further increase their production, thus creating really butter mountains and milktavas. However, the problem is so great that it is only by using the above tools that the above tools can be meaningfully helped. The artificial increase in the price of raw milk would be compensated in the medium term by the slow growth of demand on the world market, in particular in the Middle and Far East. The quantity in intervention stores may therefore be sold over time. Instead of an absolute security approach, this braver step should therefore be taken.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. – Due to a number of factors, including the Russian embargo and the inclement weather of recent months, this is being a significantly difficult period for different production sectors of European agriculture, especially for the dairy sector. On more than one occasion, the European Parliament has sounded the alarm about the risk of market imbalance. From the Committee on Budgets, I will work to ensure that this package has sufficient budgetary envelope. Once again, the need for effective and permanent crisis management tools with which we can deal with successive agricultural crises is highlighted, so as not to have to act on them with exceptional measures, as is happening these days. The functioning of the value chain is another factor in which we believe that a proactive role from the Commission is necessary for the agricultural income market to generate fair prices for producers.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. – Recent months are 20 significantly difficult for different production sectors of European agriculture, especially for the dairy sector. This is due to a number of factors, including the Russian embargo and the inclement weather of recent months. On more than one occasion, the European Parliament has sounded the alarm about the risk of market imbalance. However, a blockade of the city of Brussels last 7 September was needed for the Commission to put a package of measures on the table, which are nothing more than conjunctural solutions which do not address the under-depth problem. Once again, the need for effective and permanent crisis management tools with which we can deal with successive agricultural crises is highlighted, so as not to have to act on them with exceptional measures, as is happening these days. The functioning of the value chain is another factor in which we believe that a proactive role from the Commission is necessary for the agricultural income market to generate fair prices for producers.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – As a Member of Polish am disappointed with the results of the extraordinary meeting of agriculture ministers and the meeting of experts. 28.9 million of the EUR 500 million provided by the Commission for aid to Polish farmers are not sufficient.  I would like to ask Commissioner Hogan why aid to farmers in Germany or France is twice as high. This is all the more incomprehensible to me since the amount of EUR 500 million comes mainly from the margin of the EU agricultural budget in 2016, funded by penalties for exceeding the milk quotas, which are largely paid by Polish farmers. Milk producers in Poland suffer not only from the Russian embargo, price volatility or imbalances in the supply chain, but also because of the high penalties for exceeding the milk quotas imposed by the Commission. I therefore call on the Commission once again from this place to abolish these burdens. I would like to remind you that these penalties are not justified on economic grounds, as the limits across the EU have not been exceeded. In the light of one of the most serious agricultural crises in the last decade, such a decision would be a real aid. I also call on the Commission to increase its resources to combat the effects of the worst drought since 2003, which has affected both western and central and eastern European countries, including my home country Poland.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. – The European agricultural crisis is also significantly affecting Castilla-La Mancha. In our region, the impact of general factors, such as the Russian embargo and the dairy crisis, has been particularly compounded by the inclement weather that has hit the central peninsular area this year. The harsh drought, causing significant losses in the harvest of winter cereals, among other crops, and recent storms, which have reduced olive groves and vines mainly in Toledo, Albacete and Ciudad Real, now join the difficulties of a dairy sector that, in the Spanish-Manchego case, is powerful in areas such as Talavera de la Reina. However, the package proposed by the Commission does not go from being a conjunctural solution to a fundamental problem. In this sense, the Socialists are again demanding effective and permanent management tools with which to deal with successive agricultural crises, so as not to have to continue patching problems, as is happening these days. The functioning of the value chain is another factor in which we believe that a proactive role from the Commission is necessary for the agricultural income market to generate fair prices for producers.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D)
text: in writing. – Recent months are 20 significantly difficult for different production sectors of European agriculture, especially for the dairy sector. This is due to a number of factors, including the Russian embargo and the inclement weather of recent months. On more than one occasion, the European Parliament has sounded the alarm about the risk of market imbalance. However, a blockade of the city of Brussels last 7 September was needed for the Commission to put a package of measures on the table, which are nothing more than conjunctural solutions which do not address the under-depth problem. Once again, the need for effective and permanent crisis management tools with which we can deal with successive agricultural crises is highlighted, so as not to have to act on them with exceptional measures, as is happening these days. The functioning of the value chain is another factor in which we believe that a proactive role from the Commission is necessary for the agricultural income market to generate fair prices for producers.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. – The real situation and economic survival of European farmers is threatened by the current crisis and needs to be addressed both by the EU Commission as well as by the respective Member States. In addition, the farmers’ situation is dependent also on their country of residence. What is worrying me especially is the fact that the income gap between countries which joined the EU since 2004, and older Member States, has during the past 11 years remained practically the same or even widened. Ironically, even today, Orwell’s famous saying ‘all are equal but some are more equal than others’ holds true. The current crisis in the dairy sector is a dramatic example of this inequality. In Estonia, milk prices for producers are about one third lower than the EU average. Both the EU and the Member States need to work to eliminate such an unacceptable divide to ensure fair conditions for all participants. The EC has foreseen EUR 500 million extra aid to EU farmers, with Estonia anticipated to get some EUR 7 million. This is clearly not enough to address the crisis and to balance inequality of incomes. They need more both from the EU and from the national budget.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The crisis in the agricultural sector is a direct consequence of the policies for liberalisation of agricultural and livestock production imposed by the European institutions with the endorsement of the Member States. The most dramatic example is also the most recent: the disappearance of milk quotas, followed by the collapse of prices, which is causing numerous farms to disappear. Suddenly, aids are offered: where are the promised benefits? Aid, moreover, that we know is intended to buy social peace and consolidate the concentration of the sector, aimed at dependence on large distribution chains. In northern Spain, this is a family journey: agricultural conversion happens to industrial and mining conversion. The result: unemployment, depopulation and erosion of the productive base. Public policy contradicts itself when it has no more objective than the market. The CAP must ensure the income of small producers, food sovereignty, cohesion in rural areas, the sustainability of agricultural and livestock ecosystems. And that requires deeper changes than the emergency aid we are discussing today.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. – For the past 20 years, the Common Agricultural Policy has paired the liberalisation process with a policy of strengthening producers and producer associations, all with the aim of empowering peasants to collectively sell their products. However, not all manufacturers successfully adapted to such targets, just as not everyone had the same starting chances or conditions to adapt. If we add to the adopted legislative regulations a political crisis such as the one in Ukraine that led to sanctions on Russia, the situation in agriculture in the European Union can rightly be called a crisis. At particular disadvantage are small farmers who make up the majority of agricultural producers in Croatia, the smallest Member State, who find adapting to the new regulations more difficult. For example, the production of most major types of fruits and vegetables in Croatia decreased in the last year. Dairy farmers are particularly affected by the abolition of quotas. If we take into account BiH's refusal to adapt its SSP to Croatia's accession to the EU, at the same time an increasing number of its products are exported to the EU, primarily to the Croatian market, the severity of the problem becomes greater. Organisation in associations must become a strategic imperative for small producers, not only to increase competitiveness in a foreign market, but to meet the needs of their own market. I hope for legislative proposals that would further facilitate and encourage such practices.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. – Not enough is being done to compensate for the deleterious effects of the crisis in a number of agricultural sectors. This time the problem has been triggered by the prohibitions set by Russia on EU agricultural imports as retaliation for the sanctions imposed by the EU on Russia. It is now clear that EU sanctions were imposed without enough thought being given to the retaliatory consequences that would follow. There has been over-reliance by EU decision makers on growth in export markets outside Russia and inside the EU to compensate for losses in Russian markets; on remedial half measures adopted to overcome the arising problems; and on the belief that any losses sustained would be reversible. These assumptions especially the last one, have been too optimistic.  The crisis is not affecting only producers who supplied vegetable, pigmeat and dairy products to Russia. It is also affecting adversely other producers who are finding that sales on their home markets are being undercut by produce diverted from Russian destinations. Among those worst hit are farmers and producers in island and peripheral situations. The compensatory measures addressing this crisis need to be strengthened and broadly disseminated.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. – Over time we have adopted a number of reforms of the Common Agricultural Policy, but the situation of farmers does not seem to be improving. Farmers' incomes are still unstable, price volatility in certain sectors, such as dairy, cannot be combated. The market orientation of the CAP has unfortunately not brought with it fair income for farmers. Retailers often practice unfair policies and, until we can ensure fairness along the food chain, we cannot talk about decent incomes for our farmers. The market access of many producers is still limited, as they are limited to selling their products wholesale at nothing. Our farmers, those who produce the food that we enjoy every day, have below-average and, moreover, even uncertain incomes. I hope that today the Commission will realise that we cannot afford to bankrupt our producers. The allocation of amounts every time crises arise is not a sustainable solution, farmers must have stability and decent incomes.

name: Владимир Уручев (
text: PPE), in writing. – As President Juncker stressed in the State of the Union address, when 'the price per litre of milk is lower than the price per litre of water', we are talking about a crisis in the milk market. Unfortunately, the crisis is gradually covering other sectors such as pork, fruit and vegetables. This requires the adoption of appropriate market measures for the benefit of farmers in all sectors affected by the crisis. The chronic fall in milk market prices has led to significant losses in dairy farmers' incomes.  I therefore welcome the Commission's decision on a special package of measures worth EUR 500 million. to support the sector. A huge part of this amount – a total of 420 million euro. EUR 1.5 billion will be allocated through national financial envelopes as direct compensation to dairy farmers, providing maximum flexibility for Member States and accelerated transfer of advances under rural development programmes. All these measures are a necessary injection to deal with the short-term consequences of the crisis. At the same time, we should not neglect other instruments that can help stabilise the milk market, such as the Milk in Schools scheme. I therefore call for a faster conclusion of negotiations on the new school scheme regulation, which will provide a higher level of European funding for the scheme.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. – With a view to the current agricultural crisis which concerns mostly the dairy and pigmeat sector, I believe it is important to come up with the measures that will reinstate stability in those sectors. European farmers seem to face significantly large cash-flow difficulties. Moreover, as mentioned before, there seems to be a worrying issue concerning pigmeat supply. This might be due to the pigmeat embargo introduced by the Russian Federation, which was one of the most significant importers of pork – this probably influenced the profitability of pig keeping negatively. It caused the deficit in the supply and therefore the increase in prices.  There is also an issue connected with the drought and there are speculations that due to that, the prices of sugar may actually significantly increase. All of the above is definitely not helping the economic crisis we – and by ‘we’ I mean Europe – are currently facing. Therefore, there is a need to provide help for farmers. The financial help is already offered; however, it has not been decided yet how it will be distributed, and that is important to establish.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. – First of all, I would like to thank Commissioner Hogan for attending to much of the european dairy sector's requests. The European Commission should not rule out the option of increasing the intervention price of milk if the aid envisaged is not sufficient to stop the sinking of the price of milk. My group already stated last week, in the letter you sent, that a possible increase in the intervention price of milk should be examined. There are regions in Europe, particularly my region, Navarra, which face high costs and, let's face it, twenty-one cents are not enough to cover the costs they face in this sector. The Commission should not rule out the possibility of innovative ideas, apart from those already presented in the last agricultural package, to help this sector.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is one-minute speeches (Article 163 of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE).
text: - Mr President, the International Organisation for Family Planning received over EUR 10 million from the European Commission for projects inside and outside the EU between 2007 and 2014. Much of this funding comes from the Development Assistance Fund, an aid intended to eradicate poverty in the world and ensure a dignified life for every man. But currently, the organisation's US subsidiary, which is generously funded by taxes from European citizens, is being investigated on suspicions that the organisation was involved in the illegal sale of parts of aborted babies. All this takes place in the European year of development, the year we promote under the slogan "Our world, our dignity, our future". That is why I call on the Commission to remain true to the motto it has devised itself, to preserve the dignity of the EU and to no longer fund the International Family Planning Organisation in the future.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I want to take this opportunity to send a message from this House to my fellow Socialists and my fellow trade unionists in the United Kingdom, who may be led astray by talk of David Cameron’s deal on workers’ rights. I want to say to them that David Cameron has to go back to his Tory Party and tell them that he has done a deal on workers’ rights, when those people in the Tory party know what we do here on workers’ rights. They know what we have been doing for decades in giving rights to people at work which British governments, like the Major government in the 1990s, would never otherwise give if they did not have to. That is why he has to pretend that he has got a deal. I want to assure comrades back in Britain, though, that it will not be a real deal. It will just be the usual smoke and mirrors and blarney from David Cameron.

name: n/a
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Europe is flooded with a millionth wave of migration. There are ill-thought-out and unreasonable proposals to tackle this problem. In addition, President Schulz stated that force arguments should be used against countries that do not comply with the imposed standards for the admission of refugees. These words are unsued and disgraceful. It is worth reminding President Schulz that the mechanism for the forced allocation of refugees is an unacceptable, non-treaty and inhumane solution.  The majority of the public in Poland is against this solution. Poland did not participate in colonialism or destabilise the situation in the Middle East. It was not Poland, and Germany had an open migration policy encouraging online advertising to arrive, offering jobs and housing. Today, Germany is throwing its own mistakes at all the countries of the European Union.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: Mr. President, is life in Europe today barbed wire? Is life in Europe a water cannon? Is life in Europe tear gas today? I must say that Croatia has shown the humane face of Europe in the last 24 hours and I am proud of our citizens and fellow citizens who have made this clear. I ask that the European Commission assist Croatia immediately. Is it possible that the candidate countries, Serbia and Macedonia, are doing a lot more in this refugee crisis than the member states do? I ask that the European Commission immediately assist the candidate countries, Serbia and Macedonia, which have shown a humane face and are helping refugees.  I also ask that the European Commission immediately finance unhcr and refugee camps in Lebanon, Turkey and Jordan because we can be facing another cataclysm of the refugee wave.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL).
text: – We are discussing today the situation of the many refugees heading to the European Union experiencing nightmarish situations and we seem to have tacitly accepted the refugeeisation of all these people. But appeal is not a normal development. People from Syria, Iraq and elsewhere are being forced to flee their homes because of the fighting that has been going on there for years with the co-responsibility of Western states on both sides of the Atlantic. We need to address the cause of the problem. The European Union must, in particular, assist Syrian society in finding a peaceful solution to its internal contradictions and, of course, permanently eradicate the cancer of the Islamic State. The West must rid itself of the dangerous illusion that it can impose its own model of governance everywhere and contain itself in the search for stability and peaceful settlement of disputes.

name: Jordi Sebastià (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, the Spanish Government has received a number of convictions from the Court of Justice of the European Union for its mortgage legislation. He was convicted of leaving customers helpless in the face of bank abuses, which not only stripped them of their homes if they stopped paying any monthly payments, but also indebted them for life. The latest reform of the law aims to cover this injustice with a little makeup and cover the European record, but the reality is that citizens continue almost as helpless and the number of those who lose their home and their savings, and also those of their families, continues to grow. According to the Platform of Mortgage Affected, only in the first quarter of 2015 there were 19 261 evictions in the Spanish State. The need to tackle this injustice is obvious, because we are talking about a fundamental right, the protection of citizens from bank abuses and the Spanish Government's mockery of European justice decisions. If Europe wants to be useful, it must stand firm with Spain and sanction it and also go further so that mortgage laws are the same throughout the European Union.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, the Czech Republic is being threatened by the German Government and allegedly by the European Commission. They say we won't get structural fund subsidies if we don't agree to refugee quotas. Threats and envy, are those European values? Where is the respect for a different opinion? Can't we say no? But you know what, put the subsidies behind your hat. Subsidies are like cancers that ramp up and destroy everything that is healthy in the economy. If we don't get these subsidies, I'm telling you, it's going to be good not only for our economy, but it's going to be especially good for our own dignity and our honor.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: – The purpose of the imposition of sanctions against Russia was to weaken the Russian economy and, moreover, to weaken President Putin's position. The sanctions did not achieve their goal. EU trade has been replaced by other partners, partly due to their own production, while many EU countries have suffered heavy losses from sanctions. In parentheses, Germany is doing well with Gazprom to build Nord Stream 2.  One element of res solving the migrant influx would be to stabilise the situation in Syria. It has been said here in Parliament that this would also require russia's involvement and cooperation with it. I consider that, for such an important cooperation, the political climate would also be helped by the lifting of sanctions that would otherwise have not been effective and would not have been effective.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, tomorrow we will vote on the European Parliament's position on the Council's decision on the implementation of refugee realocation. Again, as last week, we have only one part of the measure on the table. I therefore call on the European Commission to speed up and implement concrete measures to allow the return of those who are not entitled to asylum and concrete measures to stabilise in the countries from which refugees come. By these measures, I mean, on the one hand, humanitarian aid in refugee camps in Turkey, Jordan, Lebanon and also in Iraq. But also peacekeeping operations in the territories from which people are being exote. As last week, I repeat that mandatory quotas are not the solution. The European Commission seems to have recorded our call for Member States to be able to make their own decisions. It therefore proposes the possibility of a temporary exemption from the mandatory quota in exchange for financial compensation. The problem is that the Commission wants to decide whether the reasons for the Member States are adequate. Basically, he keeps the final say. I cannot vote in favour of such a decision. My country, the Czech Republic, is in solidarity, and our leaders have clearly declared their willingness to accept thousands of refugees. But the unity we are calling for cannot be enforced, it cannot be ordered, it must be built on voluntary acceptance.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: – Trust and solidarity: these are the main elements that have allowed us to build together the democratic model and the European Union today. But in recent years, too many times I have thought that what i have built cannot be destroyed. Nothing could be more false than that. The fact that in recent days the Schengen area has been suspended, that certain states are not in solidarity or that they are throwing themselves into financial threats is, in my opinion, real dangers for the European project. The lack of dialogue between us makes us forget the interest of European citizens and privilege political scandals. Europe needs real leadership that allows us to work together. Over five hundred million inhabitants is effectively more than five hundred million opinions and a single minute in which I now say and strongly reaffirm that together we can build the European project, defend it and support it, as I have supported for many years, seven years, together with my organisation, PES Activists Romania. Colleagues, we are talking about refugees but, to see the real problem, it is enough to look at this room, almost empty. The question is whether we still respect European principles, whether there is trust and solidarity between us, so as to guarantee all our citizens, Germans, Spaniards or Romanians, all rights and support for a better life.

name: Dawid Bohdan Jackiewicz (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by A few days ago, a contract was signed in Vladivostok for the construction of the Nord Stream 2 transmission network. This agreement contradicts the idea of European solidarity, as the creation of a gas pipeline strikes at the Polish and Ukraine. In the future, this could lead to the cessation of gas transit through these countries, resulting in an energy crisis in Central and Eastern Europe. Such particular decisions strengthen Gazprom's dominant position in this part of Europe, with negative consequences for everyone in the future. Moreover, one of the main objectives of the Energy Union is strict compliance with Union energy law. In the case of The Northern Gas Pipeline 2, there is a risk that the European Commission will release Gazprom from the rules of the third climate package. There can be no agreement on selective compliance with the law, whether it concerns Germany or the smaller Member States of the European Union. I therefore call on the Commission today to block the above-mentioned contract, and I call on the Member States to respect and respect the provisions of European law and solidarity, which has been so much talked about recently in the context of immigrants. The relationship with Nord Stream 2 is today a real test of European solidarity and may the Union pass this text.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I was planning to talk about another issue, but I have seen the outcome of Monday's meeting of ministers — rather failure — in which they have not even agreed to give minimum shelter, food, health care and census to refugees, and where the only concern has been to fortify borders — Hungary has now used pepper spray and water cannons against refugees. We all know that most of them come from the countries at war — from Syria, from Afghanistan — wars in which different countries of the European Union have participated to overthrow governments that were not related to their interests and to put puppet governments that were. Leave the wars and the human tragedy will end. The representative of the People's Party used to say, representing the Government of my country, that building Europe was tearing down walls. And it is said by someone who has closed the border with Morocco in Melilla, where the refugees have been in for months and where they are prevented from passing. It is the end of cynicism that is handled in this House sometimes. I am sorry. We've been celebrating the fall of the Berlin Wall for a long time. Now it is Europe that builds walls on all sides.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – So climate change is one of the greatest challenges of the modern world, because it has a proven impact on the number and frequency of extreme weather events, on loss of biodiversity, on agricultural production and food security, and not least on human health. It is therefore a challenging task before the European Union and Slovenia, especially how to restructure the economy so that the exploitation of the environment and resources for the sake of economic growth is no longer taken for granted. Above all, a more responsible handling of the environment is the challenge that we have to face, and it is, in fact, the so-called circular economy and, of course, the so-called green economy that can offer new opportunities. I therefore consider it of paramount importance that the Ministry of the Environment and Spatial Planning of Slovenia published a draft framework programme for the transition to a green economy and called on the Participants to participate in this. However, we have reason to believe, of course, that the NGOs taking care of this sector will also be invited to participate and, of course, also be properly supported.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, two years and three months ago the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia handed down a first-instance verdict to six Bosnian Croats who were officials during the Homeland War. As vice-president of the delegation for Bosnia and Herzegovina, for relations between the European Parliament and Bosnia and Herzegovina, I feel called upon to express concern at the length of the procedure. More than 11 years have passed since the voluntary surrender of the six to The Hague, and this trial has become one of the longest trials in the former Yugoslavia. The International Criminal Court in The Hague was established with the aim of establishing and maintaining peace. I want to believe that in the trial against Jadranka Prlić, Bruno Stojic, Slobodan Praljko, Milivoj Petković, Valentin Coric and Berislav Pusic, justice and truth will be served and that the verdict will be delivered quickly. We must be guided by the truth if we are to reach the reconciliation of the people and the establishment of lasting peace, and the truth is that military operations in Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina during 1995 created preconditions for the end of the war and the establishment of peace, and that the cause of the war in Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina is Milošević's greater Serbian policy, the consequences of which are Srebrenica and Vukovar – the greatest crimes since World War II in Europe.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, every day hundreds of TIRs import food products into Italy that have no indication of their place of origin or labels and that magically become Made in Italy agri-food. A proposal for a European made in regulation providing for compulsory indication of origin for products intended for consumption was presented by the Commission in 2005. The text has been blocked in the Council for 5 years with serious consequences in terms of food fraud.  Today, the label in the European Union is anonymous for about half of the products, from pasta to fruit juices, from milk to cheeses, from cured meats to tomato paste thanks to the Made in regulation, the obligation to indicate the origin of the agricultural product on the label would be extended to all food products, thus reducing food fraud that generates a turnover of about two billion euros per year. Traceability and transparency of labels will ensure greater safety for consumers, but also higher incomes for producers, who suffer considerable damage from food fraud. We are not wasting any more time, the Council is taking this opportunity by finally adopting the Made in Regulation.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I would like to raise the same problem that Colleague Jackiewicz spoke about, because in this Parliament we are talking so much about European solidarity, we have condemned Russia for its aggressive policy towards Ukraine, for not respecting human rights. We have talked a lot about this recently in Strasbourg, and we are also talking about the Energy Union and solidarity in this area. How do you get to all this with this recently signed nord stream 2 agreement?  More recently, Germany, including in the person of President Schulz, has been trying to play the role of a teacher of European values and morality. Nord Stream, which has already linked Russia to Germany, has been at odds with these values from the outset, and this shows, of course, that in those cases where economic interests are at stake, the values and idealism proclaimed by German politicians, including, unfortunately, President Schulz, are coming to the fore. I think we should call for reflection on this project and also devote more time to this project.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to stand up for Czech farmers, especially cow farmers and milk producers, in my speech. The price of milk in the Czech Republic has fallen below the 1996 threshold and is less than seven crowns per litre, that is, in the amount of EUR 0.26. Cow breeders are pushed into a completely unequal position by customers, they are dictated prices completely below real costs. The situation of Czech farmers is made all the worse by the fact that milk prices have been below the European average in the Czech Republic for a long time. While in Germany, for example, prices fall from a higher base, there was no such pillow in our country. The situation is critical for many Czech farmers. And literally by fighting for your own existence. It was caused by the 2-effect edite. By abolishing milk quotas and the Russian embargo. I consider it necessary to relax the current situation on the European milk market. I support an increase in the intervention price for dairy products and the temporary launch of pro-export aid to markets outside the EU. We must help farmers, because their activities are important not only for the agricultural activity itself, for production, but also for the care of the countryside.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR).
text: – When new problems arise with immigrants, we should not forget about the rights of European autochton ethnic minorities. And that is exactly what the Polish national minority in Lithuania, which has lived in those lands since 700 years. Unfortunately, the rights of local Poles and other minorities are constantly restricted. Five years ago, the National Minorities Act was repealed, and today the rights of ethnic minority schools are restricted by closing them. In defence of their rights, parents and pupils organised a joint strike on 2 September involving 90% of Polish schools. Unfortunately, instead of dialogue, government representatives were frightened by the €500 fines that strike. The use of communist methods and intimidation of protesters are unacceptable in the European Union. I call on the European Parliament to protect pupils from ethnic minority schools and their parents in my homeland.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Europe has a drug problem and one that we can no longer afford to ignore. Legal highs are cheap, readily available and on the rise as a convenient high street alternative to illegal street drugs. Labelled as ‘not for human consumption’, these new psychoactive substances have effects that are wholly unpredictable and increasingly deadly.  Leading charities in regions like my own of North-East England – charities such as Changing Lives – have called for legislation to close legal loopholes and take on the vendors and the organised crime groups that exploit them. Parliament has supported action. As long as the Council continues to stall on this desperately—needed regulation, the death toll in regions like my own will continue to climb. We cannot afford to wait. The time to act is now.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the European Union promotes structural reforms, a curious euphemism for labour market reforms. In Spain, labour reforms have led to increased labour precariousness, wage devaluation and increased forced part-time, and have also sought to end collective bargaining, requiring more flexibility and less protection for workers. How can the European Union promote such reforms and ignore their consequences? How can you allow the closure of companies with benefits, some of them, such as Bosal, recipients of public subsidies? How can you continue to promote companies with profits firing thousands of workers, such as Vodafone, which in Spain is going to lay off 1,300 workers? How can you continue to attend only to the voracity of multinationals? The Commission is silent, but we don't. We are with the workers and their struggles. Not at the close of Bosal! Not Vodafone's ERE!

name: Daniel Buda (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the watchword in the European Union today is solidarity. The wars in Syria and Afghanistan, but not only have prompted the biggest waves of refugees in decades, which see Europe not only a place of hope, but also a place of peace and stability, as has been said. The refugee crisis is taking on new dimensions every day, which is leading to a collective responsibility of the European Union. Romania has been and is part of the solution, strongly pronouncing for human solidarity, rejecting radical manifestations, barbed wire fences, water cannons and tear gas, acting in the spirit of respecting the values of citizens' rights and freedoms, regardless of race or religion. However, I consider that account must be taken of the ability of the Member States to fulfil their obligations objectively when we talk about refugee relocations, and there is therefore insufficient to establish figures which, in any case, can change from one hour to the next.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Mr. President, the refugee column knocked on the Croatian door and now I guess it is clear to everyone that this humanitarian and security crisis will not spare anyone. Member States are closing borders, raising troops, blocking stations and pointing fingers at each other looking for the main culprit in the chaotic situation. But it is increasingly clear that the main culprit lives here, in Brussels. The European Commission, this stateless government, with its messages of unreserved solidarity and openness to migrants, has only encouraged tens of thousands of people from Asian and African countries where there is no war to seek happiness in Europe together with real refugees. As the European Commission does not have a country of its own, it cannot take care of anyone without forcing EU members who are increasingly receding to pressure. The huge differences between the Commission's amibiations and European reality now result in chaos that is a serious threat to Member States' security and social systems.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, on 15 October the Euro-marchas, people from all corners of Europe arriving here in Brussels, saying 'oxy': no to austerity policies; not poverty; ATCI, AECG and ACS; not racism; a resounding rejection of capital Europe; a rejection of this European Union that drowns out the peoples and people of Europe. In the face of the corrupt, in front of those of the accounts in Switzerland, in front of those who make wars and erect fences, there are millions of people, people who will not be silenced, who are fighting and who are building an alternative. We'll be with them because we're on the side of dignity. Which side do you want to be on?

name: Claude Rolin (PPE).
text: Mr President, today hundreds of taxis demonstrated in the city of Brussels. Their claim: to stop the development of the American company Uber.  With new technologies, new practices are being developed. Some are clearly part of the collaborative economy bringing a breath of fresh air to the functioning of our society. On the other hand, other companies, such as the multinational Uber, are taking advantage of this new trend to impose new forms of work and services that are completely flexible, allowing them to evade their contribution to the functioning of society, both in terms of taxation and social security. These practices are not acceptable and it is essential to legislate to regulate and delineate the activity of this type of enterprise in order to avoid the development of a socially and socially harmful economic model.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the institutions of government in the north of Ireland are experiencing a crisis. This crisis has been brought about by unacceptable reductions to the budget allocated by the British Government. The crisis has been exacerbated by cynical political opportunism on the part of Unionist political parties. The only way through this is all-party talks and extensive discussions. The British Government has not taken an even-handed, nor an impartial, approach and, as for the Irish Government, it has detached itself almost entirely. Recently this Parliament endorsed a resolution supporting the Irish peace and political processes – processes which are now under attack. We in Sinn Féin are calling on the President of Parliament, Martin Schulz, to apply positive pressure on the co—guarantors of the Good Friday Agreement – the British and Irish Governments – to press for inclusive, all-party talks to commence without precondition and without delay. In the past, outside help has assisted us in breaking deadlocks. Assistance this time should come from Parliament in order to protect and defend the Irish peace and political processes, which act as a beacon light to other areas that are emerging from conflict.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – Solidarity is the word that is most pronounced in recent days in Europe, and I support the measures prepared by the Commission for the Council, which will receive support tomorrow in Parliament, and help Hungary, Italy, Greece. It is likely that such measures will also be needed in the coming days for Croatia and Slovenia, where a wave of refugees is being 700. However, I also miss the sincere help of the other two European countries, which have already suffered a great deal of woes with the refugee crisis, macedonia and Serbia. I believe that solidarity must also be with these two countries, as well as with the others affected by the crisis in the coming weeks. There must be sincere solidarity with the western Balkan countries in the area of pre-accession assistance, as well as in the future cohesion policy, because if we do not have a roughly level playing field in Europe, no matter what part of Europe we are in, we will also in future witness the kind or other refugee crises that we do not want.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the discussion on this item on the agenda.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, Mr Juncker presented himself as the President of a political commission. Unnecessary statement, since the members of the Commission have always made politics, however, with the mask of technocrats. From REFIT to TTE, from financial liberalization to euro reform, the Commission proposes a single objective: to eliminate the rights of citizens and workers or to empty them of content through unlimited competition. In this difficult-to-understand context, where is the novelty of your proposals? The only novelty would be that it complied with the implementation of a minimum income, to which it committed itself in its investiture, or that, apart from promising an alleged social package, it would also commit sufficient resources to carry it out. All the masks fell in Greece. A society in which the market is the law and the people, their subjects: that is Juncker's agenda. It is serious that Parliament grants legitimacy to these proposals. It won't be with my vote, not the left vote.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: – I was unable to accept the proposal for a decision on the direction of the Commission's work, and I voted against it. The decision does not set out a turnaround that would be expected to solve the Union's fundamental problems. Economic policy is characterised by increasing centralisation, and economic governance deprives member states, Parliament and government of their own budgets. The indebted countries of the periphery give no hope of getting out of the debt trap. He's not trying to solve the immigration crisis, he's just trying to deal with it. It is a clear advocate of the conclusion of the EU-US Free Trade Agreement. Since I have one minute, I will no longer list the reasons why it is perhaps understandable that this was an unacceptable proposal.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Dear colleagues, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. The European economy is not developing due to sustained stagnation in demand. Its symptoms include low demand, low inflation, low levels of investment.  The question is: how can demand be revived when unemployment is high in many Countries of the European Union, especially among young people? The unemployed can't buy anything for themselves. Many Europeans have large loans and are forced to give up a significant amount of income to banks. What extra spending can be said about here? The wages of thousands of working Europeans are not growing. Many of them are not sure they will be fired tomorrow. They are not sure about their future. No wonder they accumulate money for a non-white day, not spend. If people do not buy goods and services, jobs are reduced in many sectors and a vicious circle is formed, stagnation is emerging. Consequently, it is very important for the Commission to support job creation and maximum inclusion in the labour market in its work programme next year. In my opinion, that is the main objective. There's a way out of stagnation.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I am happy to support this Commission programme for 2016, because, in my opinion, it really answers questions, whether economic, social or environmental. I also appreciated the Commission's commitment to supporting its activities in particular in those areas where there is a humanitarian crisis. I really welcomed that very much. I also want to say that I supported this programme precisely because it is also aware of the risk of so-called climate refugees. This means those who may be heading to Europe or other areas precisely because they have been affected by drought or other natural disasters. For this reason, I have supported this Commission proposal, and I also hope that many of the preparations announced by the Commission will be implemented in real life so that the European Union is truly well prepared for future dangers.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. Today, the European Parliament voted on its views on the Commission's work programme 2016. Europe is facing major challenges, which are also addressed by the joint resolution tabled by the Liberal, Christian Democrat, Socialist and Green Group. It is about strengthening European competitiveness by boosting investment, it is a united voice for foreign policy, it is about the fight for human rights and it is about solving Europe's migration challenges together. The majority of the report was good, which led me to vote in favour in the final vote.  However, there were problematic paragraphs in the resolution I chose to vote against when they came up in separate votes. These included, for example, eu tax requirements, minimum wages and centralised labour market policies which are flagrant violations of the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution on the Commission's Work Programme for 2016 in order to influence the work of the Community Executive.  After the vote was postponed in July, the Socialists have succeeded in including: (1) the introduction of a clear social dimension, which is mentioned in several paragraphs; (2) the introduction of explicit references to the Europe 2020 Strategy for Growth and Job Creation; (3) references to the refugee crisis; (4) the mention of socialist elements linked to China's imposition and financial crisis.  Taken together, the Resolution requires the European Commission to have a common asylum and refugee mechanism adapted to new needs; follow-up to the joint report of the 'five presidents', which calls for the reduction of economic disparities between euro area members; the relaunch of a smart strategy for sustainable and inclusive growth; and new investment with a view to reducing inequalities, unemployment and equal access to social services. This is not our last word, because in December 2015 the European Socialists will return to the content of the programme presented by the Commission.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted outright against the Juncker Commission's work programme for 2016 because it represents a clear continuity of the neoliberal and 'austereidal' policies that are causing so much suffering to the European working classes. With this work programme, the Commission is promoting a European Union where market law is imposed on the rights of citizens and workers through deregulation and unlimited competition. REFIT, TTE, financial liberalization, euro reform: these are the Commission's priorities for this period. There's no way I can support them, so I voted against it.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF)
text: Written. 'This European Parliament is made up of colliding planets. The wide guard between the eurocritic knights and the Europhile vote cattle in this House is reflected in the various motions for resolutions of the political groups. The joint motion for a resolution – submitted by S&D, ALDE, Greens/EFTA and PPE – again consists of more of the same. Even more union, even fewer powers for the Member States. Even more planned economy, even less bottom-up cooperation from society. Internal problems and imbalances can only be addressed by creating even more integration, according to the joint resolution. This is despite the fact that the ECB itself has come up with a study showing that EMU has created these imbalances. It is therefore the typical pathological attitude of the euro lunatics that returns here today: Your EU project fails thoroughly. And in that, funnily enough, you will find a justification for creating even more EU. Cynicism without borders. Against this nonsense only fits a negative voice.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I cannot accept the content of the Commission Work Programme 2016, and therefore voted against it. I did so chiefly on two grounds: It pursues a counterproductive agenda on the migration issue, which will make matters worse rather than better – and fails to take into account those refugees in non-EU countries; It continues to cover areas which should be dealt with directly by the Member States rather than the European Union as a whole.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution. I think it gives a credible political signal that the major pro-European political groups in the European Parliament managed to reach a common decision and  paved the path for the Commission’s work for the year to come based on close cooperation and detailed guidelines. Bearing in mind the ongoing Eurozone crisis and the escalating refugee crisis, I fully support the EP resolution’s call for action in such policy areas as migration and asylum – including the stepping up of border controls and a more effective asylum system, an ambitious strategy for smart growth, and finalisation of the European Economic and Monetary Union.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which contains Parliament's recommendations for the Commission's activities in 2016. I support the basic recommendations that the Commission should ensure the completion of the single market, together with a strategic action plan for economic union, political union and external action.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. U2012 Paragraph 16: Minimum income is an instrument of last resort, is non-contributory, and is aimed at people who are unable to find work (structural unemployment) or who do not have access to the benefits of social security. Both the Commission and the Council have issued recommendations specifying that the right to sufficient resources and social assistance should be applied by 'fixing a sufficient amount of resources considered sufficient to meet basic human dignity needs, taking into account the different standards of living in each Member State'. Since Parliament, I have worked for the adoption of a directive on adequate minimum income schemes, which would give meaning to the article on combating social exclusion from the Charter of Fundamental Rights. For all these reasons, I can only vote against the amendment.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I would like to thank the authors of the document for their hard work negotiating on this Commission work programme, which I have supported. In doing so, I had to differ from my group's line on a number of points, for example in my support for the need for the Commission to submit a proposal on minimum wages or fundamental social standards such as the quality of public employment services. I have also supported, unlike my group, the need to strike an appropriate balance between flexibility and safety for both employers and employees.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This Commission's work programme for 2016 is not surprising and continues on the path it has been charting for several years, far from the European ideal of economic prosperity, security and peace. The technocrats in Brussels, with the complicity of the elected representatives of the majority EPP, PES and ALDE groups, are literally selling our Europe to markets and lobbyists and leaving the European Union in a catastrophic situation with the recent "migrant" crisis. It is time to open our eyes and radically change policy. The Juncker plan will not suffice and is just another artifice designed to cover up the real problems. The Europe of free and sovereign nations, which I defend, will set clear priorities: SMEs-TPE, safeguarding our jobs, our agriculture and our values, the fight against cynical international treaties like the TTIP that I refuse, or the protection of our citizens in the face of immigration that we can no longer absorb. I therefore vote against this Commission's work programme for 2016 because we cannot be both the arsonist and the firefighter in this crisis.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 As taxes, dares and problems rain down from the EU, citizens pay dearly the price of every euro rip-off like that of the State Rescue Fund, which has cost italians EUR 63 billion for the time being! Time has run out and Europe has reached the end of the line, but the Commission's new work programme for 2016 does not find the long-awaited and necessary answers, for example on the subject of immigration. On the contrary, the text welcomes new cape measures such as TTIP and plans for new interference in the competences of the Member States. That is why I voted against the report: we must immediately call into question a non-sense currency such as the euro and rewrite the treaties and the wrong rules of this dictatorship. We need facts, we need courage. It is no longer just an economic choice, but an ethical choice and a civil choice. The future of all our children is at stake.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution on the Commission's Work Programme for 2016 in order to influence the work of the Community Executive.  After the vote was postponed in July, the Socialists have succeeded in including: 1) the introduction of a clear social dimension; (2) the introduction of explicit references to the Europe 2020 Strategy for Growth and Job Creation; 3) references to the refugee crisis; 4) mentions with a progressive approach to taxation and the Chinese financial crisis.  Taken together, the Resolution requires the European Commission to have a common asylum and refugee mechanism adapted to new needs; follow-up to the joint report of the 'five presidents', which calls for the reduction of economic disparities between euro area members; the relaunch of a smart strategy for sustainable and inclusive growth; and new investment with a view to reducing inequalities, unemployment and equal access to social services. This is not our last word, because in December 2015 the European Socialists will return to the content of the programme presented by the Commission.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, which parliament has put up with demands for 2016. commission's work programme. High unemployment, inequality, poverty and low social standards remain the main challenges faced by EU citizens. The EU is also focused on restoring the trust of its citizens, and Parliament therefore calls on the Commission to use its full powers to increase European integration and to develop an agenda to ensure that Europe strengthens its economic recovery in a fairer and inclusive single market, create more quality jobs and reduce social inequalities. The Commission is invited to ensure that that education and training remain its top priorities, with a focus on access to, equality, modernisation and promotion of quality EDUCATION and training systems in the EU, in particular in the light of the most pressing challenges such as boosting the skills needed for the current and future labour market, promoting vocational education and training and dual training, support for quality vocational training and traineeships, Erasmus+, lifelong learning and media literacy.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I agree with its spirit and most of its points. In particular, I think that the points devoted to growth and employment are very important and interesting. It is essential for the Commission to work to revive the economy of our continent.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution sets out the outlines of the European Commission's broad policy directions in 2016. Some of their objectives are laudable, such as the desire to promote the development of SMEs and the energy transition, to combat mass unemployment, especially among young people, or to reduce social inequalities.  Nevertheless, the solutions advocated to achieve these objectives will have the opposite effects to those expected. Indeed, the report calls for strengthening the single market, the mobility of workers and supporting the removal of all obstacles to sacrosanct international trade, even though it is these policies that have created the disastrous macroeconomic consequences that many EU Member States are experiencing. In addition, the Brussels Commissioners wish to continue the work carried out in the area of cooperation with local authorities, which has contributed to weakening the weight of nation states. Structural funds are sucked in by large metropolises at the expense of the most disadvantaged areas and therefore do not reduce regional disparities.  Not learning anything from its mistakes, the European Commission is dogmatizing a deadly policy. So I voted against it.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the resolution on the European Commission's work programme for 2016. Clearly, this is a text that mostly supports the Commission's work in areas where I do not support the lines taken (monetary policy, TTIP, environmental policies, immigration), or in areas where I would like to see less ingestion in the competences of the Member States (both in economic matters and in the substance of many measures).

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution on the Commission's Work Programme for 2016 in order to influence the work of the Community Executive.  After the vote was postponed in July, the Socialists have succeeded in including: (1) the introduction of a clear social dimension, which is mentioned in several paragraphs; (2) the introduction of explicit references to the Europe 2020 Strategy for Growth and Job Creation; (3) references to the refugee crisis; (4) the mention of socialist elements linked to China's imposition and financial crisis.  Taken together, the Resolution requires the European Commission to have a common asylum and refugee mechanism adapted to new needs; follow-up to the joint report of the 'five presidents', which calls for the reduction of economic disparities between euro area members; the relaunch of a smart strategy for sustainable and inclusive growth; and new investment with a view to reducing inequalities, unemployment and equal access to social services. This is not our last word, because in December 2015 the European Socialists will return to the content of the programme presented by the Commission.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the preparation of the Commission's work programme for 2016. The current situation requires rapid and effective responses in terms of migration policy, taxation and the digital single market. This is the second year of the Commission's mandate chaired by Jean-Claude Juncker. We expect a programme as ambitious as the previous year, which meets our most pressing expectations. The European Parliament will remain vigilant about the implementation of this programme and will make full use of its power as a co-legislator.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the resolution on the Commission's work programme for 2016, in which the European Parliament has expressed the guidelines on which the European executive will have to work. I voted in favour of the text because I believe it has included the priorities with which the Union must confront itself. I am thinking, for example, of the EU's social problems, especially unemployment, the skills gap, inequalities and social exclusion, the risks of social dumping and the brain drain. In this respect, I believe that investment is absolutely necessary to promote the creation of quality jobs and investment in social dumping that focuses on skills. Other major challenges facing Europe are the substantial reduction of the bureaucratic and administrative burden on citizens and businesses and the review of tax policy. Finally, we must not forget the need to draw up an ambitious framework for climate and energy, making a substantial contribution to the conclusion of a global climate agreement.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the Commission Work Programme as there were a number of problematic aspects. Reading through the aims of the Commission, the focus is supposedly to avoid economic boom and bust cycles, and aimed at restoring economic growth to the EU. However there is no tangible focus on equitable growth or poverty reduction. It shows a clear disconnect between European bureaucrats and the reality that is facing millions of struggling working families right across the EU. The Commission Work Programme’s primary aim seems to be just to ensure that Member States do not deviate from the economic neo-liberal ideology that it is pushing. It does not leave Member States with flexibility to implement alternative policies, which would be pro-investment, pro-growth, pro-jobs. In effect it is working to deny citizens real political choices when electing their governments.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the Commission Work Programme 2016, as I cannot accept its content, specifically its pursuit of a counter-productive agenda on the migration crisis, which will only make matters worse by failing to account for those refugees who are in other parts of the globe, away from EU Member States, or adjoining countries. This programme covers areas which should be dealt with directly by the Member States rather than from a European Union dimension, as a whole. I did however abstain on Paragraph 101, part 2,as I fully support the concept of assistance to genuine refugees, in accordance with the 1951 Geneva Convention on refugees.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution as it sets out a number of important measures that tackle important elements for the EU and its citizens. It especially aims to reduce the problem of unemployment across the EU, especially among the long-term unemployed and youth. The role of the private sector and SMEs is highlighted in this process and appreciated by way of more transparent and more easily obtainable financing. The programme does not omit the issue of labour mobility within the EU and points out the actions needed to prevent any abuses of the common market. Notwithstanding, references to the Common Consolidated Tax Base in paragraph 48 go against the notion of subsidiarity and hence I voted against the amendments to this paragraph.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 We cannot support the Juncker Commission's work programme. Together with the M5S Europe delegation, we voted against.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the European Commission's work programme for 2016. Parliament welcomed the measures taken on employment, growth and investment and called on the Commission to pursue these objectives for 2016; stresses the need to introduce an 'SME test' and a mandatory 'competitiveness test' for all future legislative proposals; considers that the use of impact assessments including respect for the principle of subsidiarity should be increased; it supports the fight against fraud and tax evasion and calls on the Commission to publish a Green Paper setting up a body to assess the costs and costs incurred in addition to the Court of Auditors. Finally, the EP underlines the importance of the trade agreements reached by the Union and hopes that rapid progress in the negotiation of TTIP and that further trade negotiations can make further progress in 2016.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because Europe must respond to the issues it faces, with a clear vision and direction and leadership to meet the expectations of its citizens. In particular, on the issues I deal with most, I welcome the amendments introducing aid to farmers in order to anticipate market crises, offering new, stronger instruments to avoid loss of income and communicating what the situation may be by means of more accurate real-time data – which I consider to be extremely important. I would also like to stress my position on the need to correct imbalances in the agri-food chain, in particular to ensure fairness and transparency in relations between primary producers, processors, suppliers and distributors. I believe that transparency is one of the best battles in the European Union.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission adopts an action plan for the next twelve months which shows European citizens and institutional partners how it intends to turn its political priorities into concrete actions. This programme, presented in October, is discussed with the European Parliament and the Council before its adoption, taking the Commission into account the views of the EP when drawing up its priorities for the following year. I believe that the next Work Programme must continue to address the emerging challenges facing Europe, including growth and jobs, the implementation of the Digital Single Market strategy, energy independence and climate change, and a genuine European Agenda for migration flows. In this regard, I consider it urgent to combat irregular migration and better management of migration flows, not to neglect a possible review of visa policy and a European solution for the reception of refugees. I welcome the adoption of the European Strategic Investment Fund, awaiting its rapid implementation in concrete investment projects for a rapid and sustainable recovery, as well as the goal of better legislation.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Parliament's resolution on the European Commission's work programme for 2016. The resolution proposes more effective EU action in a number of areas, such as trade, the environment, agriculture and energy, boosting Employment and Growth in Europe and providing a better environment for investment. A very important part of this resolution for me is Parliament's request to the Commission on justice and fundamental rights, which is about the Commission addressing the current shortcomings and loopholes in the values underlying the Union in the areas of human dignity, freedom, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities.  National minorities are not yet adequately protected at EU level, but non-discrimination is a general accepted principle. Parliament strongly supports the fight against discrimination and, by pointing it out, calls on the Commission to propose initiatives to strengthen the fight against discrimination. The Commission's proposals can also serve the interests of indigenous minority communities.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it highlights the European Parliament’s main priorities which it believes the European Commission should strive towards in the upcoming year. I believe that we need to give proper recognition to, and develop, an EU Social Dimension. We need higher social standards throughout the EU, we need to strive for better standards of living, for concrete, effective and fair trade policies and better and more transparent regulation. We need economic growth and job creation whilst making sure that we move towards an energy transition and do a proper shift towards cleaner, more sustainable energy, tackling climate change and recover from the Eurozone crisis. My vote in favour was with a reservation on the reference to specific tax policy regimes as I believe that these issues should respect the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Europe 2020 strategy is a valid basis for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, and if its objectives are confirmed before the end of this year, its implementing instruments must now be updated and strengthened. In this context, a solid solution must be found for all the Social Problems of the Union, in particular unemployment, discrepancies in skills, social differences and exclusion, as well as the risks of social dumping and brain drain. I believe that there is a need for economic recovery and investment to stimulate the creation of quality jobs, skills-focused social investment, childcare and other social services. That is why we need to promote stronger involvement in this regard by the social partners at European and national level.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this non-legislative and non-binding resolution as it encourages the EU Commission to initiate more wide-ranging legislation and wasteful EU spending. It calls for economic and political union and external action, welcomes the Commission agenda on migration, calls for stronger EU control on state aid, calls for more EU control of industrial policy, calls for a mandatorily Common Consolidated Corporate Tax base, calls for stronger Economic and Monetary Union, and calls for the EU to join the European Convention of Human Rights (ECHR).  All of this will transfer more power from our elected and accountable national government to unelected bureaucrats in Brussels, as well as wasting more of the UK taxpayer’s money.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. Europe must react with clarity of vision and direction, with a spirit of leadership, ambition and courage to the challenges we face, both inside and abroad, to show that it is capable of meeting citizens' expectations, offering them perspectives and generating confidence. The EU must present itself as a truly democratic union, a parliamentary democracy and an area where citizens can direct and shape their continent for the sake of preserving and consolidating their standard of living. The Commission must therefore take on the 10 strategic priorities as its main desideratum, thereby giving a new impetus to jobs, growth and investment, fighting tax fraud and tax evasion, creating a connected and inclusive digital single market, making the Union more energy resilient and endorsing a visionary climate change policy. The Commission must prepare a strong response to the EU's social problems, including unemployment, skills shortages, social inequalities and social exclusion, as well as the risks of social dumping and brain drain.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. After the vote was postponed in July, the Socialists have managed to introduce a clear social dimension in the text, as well as explicit references to the Europe 2020 Strategy for Growth and Job Creation or the Refugee Crisis.  Taken together, the Resolution requires the European Commission to have a common asylum and refugee mechanism adapted to new needs; follow-up to the joint report of the 'five presidents', which calls for the reduction of economic disparities between euro area members; the relaunch of a smart strategy for sustainable and inclusive growth; and new investment with a view to reducing inequalities, unemployment and equal access to social services.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution is clear about the deep crisis facing the EU as to those responsible for this crisis and the strategy of those responsible for the crisis they have created. The eternal consensus between the right and social democracy (with "liberals" and "greens" comcomuping the branch) and the guidelines he has set up here show that those responsible for the current situation have not learned a single lesson from the crisis they have created. It cannot be said that they have not learned from mistakes because they were not mistakes, in fact, rather deliberate options, as can be seen here.
