To economic stagnation and recession, unemployment, poverty, social inequalities, growing divergence between Member States, they respond with the deepening of neoliberal policies that have generated this whole framework and with more limitations on the sovereignty of peoples and democracy, aiming to further advance economic dependence and political subordination of countries such as Portugal, increasingly subjugated by the directory of the great powers , with Germany at its head. Directory that also seeks to deepen the militaristic aspect of the EU to better satisfy its imperial drive. We voted against and with the amendments we have tabled we have signalled an alternative path, which is possible and increasingly necessary and which the peoples, by the struggle, will do theirs.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 As part of its 2016 work programme, the European Commission must strive to complete the labour mobility package and take measures to promote the inclusion and employability of European workers and to address the problems of the long-term unemployed as well as the unemployed under 25. The European Commission must take concrete measures to eliminate persistent discrimination in the labour market, especially with regard to older workers, women, workers with disabilities and young people. It is very important that we appeal to the European Commission to actively address the issue of gender balance and to focus on factors that discourage women from doing business. The European Commission must respond to the migration and humanitarian crisis in Europe by presenting a new legislative proposal for a smart borders package as soon as the pilot project is completed in order to speed up, simplify and strengthen border controls on foreigners travelling to the European Union. The European Union needs to move towards more modern and efficient border management through the use of state-of-the-art technologies, while at the same time providing citizens with proper guarantees. The European Commission must take a more proactive approach to the European Citizens' Initiative and take appropriate action following any successful initiative, and in general focus on addressing the shortcomings and limitations of this instrument.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 This programme is always a shadow of a doubt about the continuation of Europe's failure. Don't change on anything. Continue with the same policies that have been slaughtering the peoples of Europe for years.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the preparation of the Commission's work programme for 2016, because I disagree with too many issues, but above all with the Union's approach to Europe's major problems. I believe that the solutions are in exactly the opposite direction to the one in which the Union is moving.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution on the Commission's Work Programme for 2016 in order to influence the work of the Community Executive.  After the vote was postponed in July, the Socialists have succeeded in including: (1) the introduction of a clear social dimension, which is mentioned in several paragraphs; (2) the introduction of explicit references to the Europe 2020 Strategy for Growth and Job Creation; (3) references to the refugee crisis; (4) the mention of socialist elements linked to China's imposition and financial crisis.  Taken together, the Resolution requires the European Commission to have a common asylum and refugee mechanism adapted to new needs; follow-up to the joint report of the 'five presidents', which calls for the reduction of economic disparities between euro area members; the relaunch of a smart strategy for sustainable and inclusive growth; and new investment with a view to reducing inequalities, unemployment and equal access to social services. In December 2015, the European Socialists will return to the content of the programme presented by the Commission.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution on the Commission's Work Programme for 2016 in order to influence the work of the Community Executive.  After the vote was postponed in July, the Socialists have succeeded in including: (1) the introduction of a clear social dimension, which is mentioned in several paragraphs; (2) the introduction of explicit references to the Europe 2020 Strategy for Growth and Job Creation; (3) references to the refugee crisis; (4) the mention of socialist elements linked to China's imposition and financial crisis. In December 2015, the European Socialists will return to the content of the programme presented by the Commission.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly voted in favour of the EP resolution on the European Commission's work programme for 2016, because the S-D Group has fought hard to improve the initial text by making the message to the European Commission much stronger on some key points, such as the EU Social Agenda and the implementation of a European social dimension to respond to EU problems , such as unemployment, inequality and social exclusion. The EU needs a clear social dimension to foster economic recovery and promote investment in sectors with a strong employment impact and social investment that focus on skills, care for children and the disabled and other social services. To this end, the social economy and the enterprises and social enterprises on which it is based must play an important role. A key role can play in the full implementation of the Strategic Investment Fund (EFSI) and therefore in the approval of investment projects in the Member States that contribute to a solid recovery and balanced growth and the creation of quality jobs. Finally, I welcome the call to help farmers anticipate market crises by offering them new and, above all, means of avoiding loss of income.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Commission's 2016 Work Programme prioritises the full implementation of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) so that the EU economy can feel its first effects, including in terms of social development. Our aim is to continuously raise social standards, implement concrete, effective and fair trade rules and better and more transparent regulation across the EU. We need stable economic growth, the creation of new jobs, while at the same time taking into account sustainable development, including the energy market, and thus addressing the inevitable climate change.  The European Commission must take concrete steps to eliminate established discrimination on the labour market, especially against older workers, people with disabilities, young people or women after maternity leave.  An important aspect is also the fact that we are currently facing a migration crisis in Europe and it is necessary to swiftly approve a new package of legislative proposals in order to speed up, simplify and strengthen border controls for foreigners travelling to the European Union. The future of the EU will depend on the implementation of these plans.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution as a whole, and particularly voted against calling on the Commission to come up with improved EU initiatives on a mandatory Common Consolidated Corporate Tax base – which is utter madness, and unfortunately was carried.  No two nations are alike, and tax competition is crucial for countries like Ireland, who have been able to attract a great deal of investment (mainly from the USA) thanks to this flexibility.  Just more EU power-grabbing.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. The Commission must have a work programme aimed at solving the most pressing problems affecting Europe. It must therefore, as this Resolution rightly points out, submit a proposal for the next phase of the Europe 2020 Strategy for Employment and Growth which gives a strong response to unemployment, shortages of skilled workers, social inequalities and exclusion, as well as the risks of social dumping and brain drain. It also needs to continue working to achieve a true digital single market with a view to creating a digital economy in which Europe can exercise global leadership. Nor should we forget this indispensable project, which is the union of energy, which must be based on a competitive internal energy market, a strong system of European governance, research and innovation, and new investments that improve cross-border infrastructure and interconnections. Finally, the rapid implementation of the European Agenda on Migration is vital to address the current refugee crisis with measures to ensure its most basic rights. Parliament will be at the side of the Commission for the achievement of all these objectives.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the Commission's Work Programme Resolution for 2016. The openly conservative bias of the document is part of the neoliberal logic underlying the Commission's different programmatic movements. At some points, the work programme seems to recognise the effects of precariousness or the forms it takes in the EU, such as youth unemployment or the danger to pensions; but as far as the causes are concerned, the document is unable to locate them in the proposals that guided the previous European Commission. Moreover, the document appears as a roadmap for the liquidation of economic sovereignty, including some presumably positive points such as tax equalisations and the persecution of tax havens, although it is not clearly specified what kind of redistribution can be expected from plausible tax equalisation. We understand that an executive body that is not elected by citizens has to present, in order to legitimize itself as a body, a programme that delves into the problems afflicting an EU that appears to make water, as well as propose social solutions.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my Labour party colleagues, I voted in favour of this resolution as it examines key European Parliamentary Labour Party concerns about the Eurozone crisis and seeks to address these concerns by creating better regulation and better standards.  The 2016 Commission Work Programme will need to focus on promoting the EU social dimension as well as better standards in industrial policy and should spell out a clear position on the digital revolution and its implications for both social standards and employment in the EU.  Europe is facing a number of crises, from youth unemployment to the crisis in the Mediterranean. We need real solutions, which can only come about when we work together.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution on the Commission's Work Programme for 2016 in order to influence the work of the Community Executive.  After the vote was postponed in July, the Socialists have succeeded in including: (1) the introduction of a clear social dimension, which is mentioned in several paragraphs; (2) the introduction of explicit references to the Europe 2020 Strategy for Growth and Job Creation; (3) references to the refugee crisis; (4) the mention of socialist elements linked to China's imposition and financial crisis. This is not our last word, because in December 2015 the European Socialists will return to the content of the programme presented by the Commission.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour on the resolution on preparation of the Commission Work Programme 2016. Since the EU has endured a lengthy economic crisis which resulted in low growth, increased internal imbalances and a lack of job creation and investment, it is an urgent matter to continue further European integration in the internal market and in the context of economic and monetary union.  To be more precise, in my opinion it is essential to fully and effectively apply existing legislation in the single market and other areas such as environmental law and cohesion policy. I truly support the notions of boosting employment, economic growth and investment. Nonetheless, the Digital Single Market must remain on the top of the agenda, thus we must introduce proper mechanisms to trigger investments on the ground. In that way, opportunities would be generated for the digital activities which could increase job places, enhance innovation and productivity. Therefore, based on these grounds I have voted for this resolution.

name: Jytte Guteland Anna Hedh Olle Ludvigsson och Jens Nilsson (S&D)
text: Written. As far as paragraph 11 is concerned, we Swedish Social Democrats want to give a background to our actions: as far as paragraph 11 is concerned, we are not entirely averse to reducing the tax on labour, but this must be done in a way that improves the tax system as a whole. It is important, for example, that progressiveness is not eroded. Green tax change can be a workable model in this respect. With regard to the creation of a ccctb system (paragraph 48), we believe that the process should be pursued further. Properly designed, such a system could bring important benefits – not least in terms of reducing tax evasion and aggressive tax planning. We believe that better coordination is needed if the EU, with member states' resources, is to contribute to the preservation of peace, the prevention of conflicts and the strengthening of international security. However, we do not fully support all the wordings in paragraph 104 on how European defence cooperation should be extended because we think the text goes too far in its scope. We therefore chose to abstain.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. We Socialists have led the adoption of this Resolution on the European Commission's Work Programme for 2016 calling for the strengthening of European cooperation based on democratic dialogue at a key moment in Europe's future.  I voted in favour of this resolution because, among many other issues: 1.- Clearly expresses its support for the Commission's proposals to improve asylum and migration policy while respecting human rights and fundamental freedoms and for the creation of a permanent relocation system; 2.- Stresses the need to strengthen EMU with a clear social dimension to reduce economic and social disparities between euro area States through better coordination of economic and social policies; 3.- Envisages the relaunch of the Europe 2020 Strategy for sustainable and inclusive smart growth, thus safeguarding our social market economy; 4.- Stresses the need for a new social investment initiative, addressing rising inequalities and high rates of poverty.   We will closely monitor the programme to be presented in October to ensure that the Commission listens to Parliament and provides realistic and European solutions to all these challenges.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ While I was largely in support of the Commission Work Programme 2016, there were a number of issues I could not support and consequently voted against. One of these was the introduction of CCCTB. I believe the EU should seriously examine CCCTB, a Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base. CCCTB in any case must be voluntary, because Member States have a veto on such issues, and the impact of CCCTB in a situation where some Member States are in and some are out would lead to such uncertainty for companies that investment in EU countries would be seriously affected. One of the problems with CCCTB is assessing where the value is created, and furthermore it automatically favours bigger countries because of their large population and consequently large sales. This could negatively affect some Member States, particularly Ireland, the Netherlands etc. and I cannot support such a proposal.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the Commission work programme because I believe it outlines Parliament’s key priorities for the coming year and reflects some of the important issues that have arisen in recent months. We need to address the current refugee crisis and I am glad that this has featured prominently in the report. Additionally, I believe the report keeps focus on many of the other important issues facing the EU at the moment, including environmental, health, social and economic matters.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (
text: alde), in writing. \u2012 I support the resolution regarding the preparation of the 2016 European Commission Work Programme, calling for the inclusion of expiry clauses of the acts proposed by the Commission in order to review them periodically, avoiding over-regulation and at the same time providing the necessary flexibility to European legislation to meet dynamic modern challenges.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the Commission's Work Programme Resolution for 2016. The openly conservative bias of the document is part of the neoliberal logic underlying the Commission's different programmatic movements. name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ 19 - I voted for the European Parliament's resolution on the Commission's work programme for 2016, as Europe faces a challenging period that requires concrete action and answers. I believe it is necessary to set out in detail how the implementation of the Europe 2020 Strategy will continue to ensure growth and jobs. The situation of high unemployment, which requires an urgent response in the form of job creation and solving the EU's social problems, is alarming. I fully support the adoption of the Single Market Strategy, the improvement of information sharing and good practices, and the financing of businesses, in particular SMEs, which are driving the European economy. Green investment must also be further encouraged and awareness of environmental and health issues raised. However, the biggest challenge will surely be the migrant crisis, which requires a decisive and common response from Europe, and in this context I support the European Agenda on Migration, but I think additional support measures are necessary.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution on the Commission's Work Programme for 2016 in order to influence the work of the Community Executive.  After the vote was postponed in July, the Socialists have succeeded in including: (1) the introduction of a clear social dimension, which is mentioned in several paragraphs; (2) the introduction of explicit references to the Europe 2020 Strategy for Growth and Job Creation; (3) references to the refugee crisis; (4) the mention of socialist elements linked to China's imposition and financial crisis. This is not our last word, because in December 2015 the European Socialists will return to the content of the programme presented by the Commission.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although I agree in principle with the Commission's work programme for 2016, mainly because of its intentions in the Union's economic policies, I have decided to abstain because of the non-conceptual solution to the current immigration crisis.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. This text sets out the Commission's priorities for its work for 2016. The European Parliament was invited to give its opinion on these priorities. I therefore voted in favour of this report because it makes growth, employment and investment major areas of work for the Commission, with a focus on the digital single market. The migration component is also present in the Commission's document, which is aware that the migration crisis is one of the main issues of 2016.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I believe that this resolution must be rejected. On many points, it aims to establish a transfer union in order to allow non-contractual transfers within the European Union on the pretext of economic assistance and solidarity. Similarly, there are already concrete plans to move political union forward and to cede fiscal rights to Brussels through the approximation of tax systems, which is not possible at the present stage of the Treaties. I am also opposed to further centralisation of public areas such as labour market policy or health and social policy.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 With its resolution on the Commission work programme for 2016, the European Parliament is tasking the European Commission on the work to be done for the next year, 2016. This resolution highlights many important points for Latvia, such as the geopolitical need to diversify energy supplies and to the European Commission to come forward with a revised Natural Gas Supply Regulation. The European Parliament also recalls the need to develop the so-called Banking Union and to launch a Capital Market Union. I believe that all these initiatives are also in the interests of Latvia, which is why I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution as it urges the Commission to use its right of initiative to its full extent. Europe needs to respond with a clear vision, direction, leadership, ambition and courage to the challenges we face both internally and externally, to show that it is capable of meeting the expectations of our citizens, offering them prospects and creating trust, by making the EU a truly democratic Union, a parliamentary democracy and an arena where citizens can steer and shape their continent in the interests of preserving and consolidating their standard of living.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. On 13 September, the four political groups, the EPP, S&D, ALDE and the Greens, tabled a joint motion for a resolution on the European Commission's work programme for 2016. In it, the four political groups describe what they consider to be the European Union's main thematic priorities for the coming year.  The motion for a resolution contains a number of positive demands. This is to use EU funds effectively, prevent mismanagement and improve budgetary control. It also calls for an evaluation of the costly common agricultural policy. It also aims to increase the efficiency of the repatriation of rejected asylum seekers, while at the same time strengthening humanitarian aid and development cooperation.  On the other hand, the motion also contains a number of demands which speak for further centralisation of the EU towards full economic and political union, disregard the principle of subsidiarity – for example, when calling for quotas for women – and reject restrictive measures as part of a holistic policy to deal with the current refugee crisis. This includes, for example, the explicit condemnation of the temporary reintroduction of border controls at internal borders, although this is expressly permitted under the Schengen acquis. Finally, the motion for a resolution contains far too few constructive criticisms of the Commission's work. I have therefore rejected this motion for a resolution.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is completely unbelievable that the European Parliament over and over again approves reports calling for quotas and completely refuses to talk about another solution. The situation is so much crazier that the European Parliament actually has no role in the quota decision-making process. Only the Council can accept quotas, but the European Parliament has chosen to ignore this reality. In the media space, this causes panic, which is transmitted to Czech citizens. Reason retreats aside, and anger and fear come to the fore. Social media is inundated with hateful rhetoric, in which blood often boils in its veins. Just as everyone has a responsibility to what they write and say, governments should be responsible for how they deal with the situation. Threats from angry bloggers or top state officials do not help the situation at all and escalate it. If we all do not deal with this issue in kind, this may result in a new division of Europe or a transfer of the conflict on redistribution within individual Member States. Now it's not about telling myself which side of the barricade I'm on, it's about whether or not I'm willing or able to look at the situation rationally and without prejudice. Again, I did not support quotas and therefore the whole report over and over again.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted against the new CWP. Instead of helping workers, the work programme is all about making it easier for companies at the expense of workers’ rights and conditions. We question the new Commission’s priorities as set out to MEPs in its annual plan of action. We work for and demand solutions towards growth, a sustainable debt direction, and a strong welfare state.

name: Merja Kyllönen (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. – I voted in favour of the proposal in favour of the ENF Group's TTIP proposal. I see it as so important that I did not resolve my decision to vote on the basis of the fact that the group of the extreme right made the motion itself. I think it is more important to croft the TTIP negotiations.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. This resolution is intended to urge the European Commission to implement an ambitious work programme for 2016. In addition to the need for regulatory reorganisation and simplification, we must, in fact, focus the accelerator on initiatives that promote economic growth and employment in Europe. Parliament has been the spokesman for important demands, such as the fight against tax evasion, a collective and supportive approach to migration policies and the revival of our economy. Initiatives on climate change, especially with a view to the Paris Summit, energy independence and resource efficiency, without forgetting the importance of a sound European governance system, support for research and innovation, new infrastructure investments, and the transition to a digitised society are also of great interest. Interventions and challenges necessary to give certainty and security to the lives of our citizens.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the Commission's work programme for 2016, because it sorts and sums up everything that goes wrong in the European Union. On asylum and immigration, for example, it rejects "any measure that de facto restores border controls, endangering the Schengen area" but does not provide any solution to the problem. It also calls for a revision of the European 'blue card' to offer the prospect of legal migration to the European Union, which already has more than 26 million unemployed. With regard to the euro, paragraph 79 of the resolution urges the Commission to propose 'an ambitious project that brings together all the necessary measures to improve the resilience of the Economic and Monetary Union (EMU) and transform it into a framework for better coordination and enhanced structural convergence, through the Community method'. In other words, we want to give the European Union additional powers at the expense of the Member States.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution on the Commission's Work Programme for 2016 in order to influence the work of the Community Executive.  After the vote was postponed in July, the Socialists have succeeded in including: (1) the introduction of a clear social dimension, which is mentioned in several paragraphs; (2) the introduction of explicit references to the Europe 2020 Strategy for Growth and Job Creation; (3) references to the refugee crisis; (4) the mention of socialist elements linked to China's imposition and financial crisis.
