name: Peter Lundgren (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Paragraph 82, Amendment 45: Our position regarding the TTIP negotiations is that we reject any agreement which includes an investor-state dispute settlement provision that might enable investor-state claims to inhibit the capacity of the Swedish Government to pass legislation addressing perfectly legitimate public concerns, such as health and environmental protection, labour rights or human rights.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Commission's work programme for 2016. As one of the Commission's most important priorities, I consider monitoring the activities of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) as the Commission's main initiative to boost growth and jobs. I hope that, as announced, the EFSI will m.in on combating the social impact of the crisis, including unemployment and poverty.  We also need more support for education and training projects, which should be aimed at ensuring access to quality education for all. EFSI-funded projects should also support the development of dual learning systems, which will in the long term increase the employment, competitiveness and innovation of the Union economy.  In addition, the EU's flagship programmes in the field of education and culture, such as Erasmus+, which directly benefit Europeans, should be strengthened.  We must also face new challenges, including terrorism and progressive radicalisation. In this context, I stress the need for a multi-level approach to these topics, which must take into account the fight against their causes through education, dialogue, substantive assistance to teachers and the strengthening of measures to combat radicalisation and prevent marginalisation.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ A Resolution of the European Parliament calls on the Commission to encourage job creation, as unemployment levels remain very high. It also underlines that the conclusion of new trade agreements is necessary in order to develop an open and competitive European economic framework that can create new jobs, including SMEs.  It welcomes the adoption of the European Fund for Strategic Investments and the European Agenda on Migration developed by the Commission and calls for the implementation of these programmes as swiftly as as can.  The Commission is invited to set out a coherent and clear foreign and security policy strategy, which would aim to identify new and upcoming challenges that the EU will have to face in a fragile security environment.  The Commission is to present initiatives aimed at establishing a 2030 climate and energy framework for the conclusion of a global climate agreement. I supported Parliament's resolution on the Commission's Work Programme 2016, whereas we need an ambitious agenda with a clear vision, focus and courage to address the Union's many challenges.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. – In 2015, the European Union must address major internal and external challenges, from the effects of the economic crisis to the decline in competitiveness and lack of economic growth, high unemployment to mass population migration from Africa to Europe. However, past experience shows that many problems are not addressed in good time or in advance, and the Commission's proposals put forward lack flexibility, firmness, decisiveness and some foresight. Many times, instead of prepared solutions, indecision and lengthiness take place. Such an approach does not help the implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy, but also reduces confidence in the EU itself. The Commission must therefore take action and use all its powers to reverse this unfavourable situation and to increase public confidence in the EU.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the joint motion for a resolution on the Commission's work programme for 2016, because on the one hand it promotes TTIP, as supposedly an opportunity for more growth and strengthening of the labour market, while the truth is that the risks to Greece and the Greeks are enormous, since TTIP endangers various Greek agricultural products that are guaranteed as PDOs, exported to the USA, risking filling Europe with genetically modified foods. TTIP brings about complete deregulation of the European agricultural market and Greek olive oil will be irreparably affected. TTIP abolishes the existing system of judicial protection with US multinationals enjoying a heterogeneous right.  On the other hand, the Commission's work programme does not address the issue of migration. More than 230,000 refugees have flooded into Greece since the beginning of 2015 with the situation still explosive and dramatic. Immediate measures are therefore needed, such as repealing the Dublin III Regulation that turns Greece into a warehouse of souls; implementing the distribution clause for all refugees and illegal immigrants at European Union level; measures against Turkey supporting the slave trade, as Hurriyet revealed on 29/5/2015, and a brave increase in European Union funds to Greece.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the joint resolution on the European Commission's work programme for 2016, as I believe that it contains interesting ideas from which the Eu ropean Executive will be able to draw when setting its priorities for next year. In particular, I welcomed the reference in the document to the need to remove obstacles in the single market, with a view to improving the financing conditions for businesses, in particular SMEs and micro-enterprises.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. In defiance of the principle of subsidiarity, this report strengthens the Commission's powers. Commission proposals on migration should be enforced quickly and without delay, and border controls at national level and the repeal of the Schengen Agreement are condemned. The banking sector and free trade agreements such as TTIP are highlighted positively. I therefore reject this report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This joint resolution of the right and the Social Democrats "urges the Commission to make full use of its right of initiative in order to give a clear direction to the Union, in particular by completing the single market and producing the strategic roadmap for economic union and political union, as well as for external action". For my part, I am opposed to the Commission's initiative, which is necessarily detrimental to the sovereignty of peoples and their interests because of its role as guardian of the ordo-liberalism promulgated by the budgetary treaties. Moreover, its work programme aims only to strengthen competition which "promotes innovation" and to promote the mobility of workers through the application of the Detached Workers Directive. The text praises free trade treaties, which are essential "to establish a competitive European economic framework". Finally, it underlines "the importance of a Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) agreement" to which I am totally opposed. I am voting against this 'work programme' which promises us another year of austerity.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission Work Programme 2016 will play a crucial role in tackling the problems of unemployment and increasing the Union’s competitiveness in the global market. It also stresses the need to develop the digital single market as well as improve the EU’s energy resilience by striving towards a greener economy. Therefore I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Economic and monetary union must have a social pillar. This means a minimum wage, quality public services, affordable housing, access to a basic health care base, jobs for young people... At present, the European Union's social action is limited, under the powers assigned to it by the treaties, to "soft" political coordination on a purely voluntary basis. It would be useful to better engage the European Union in social governance. As Jacques Delors says, we must combine "competition that stimulates, cooperation that strengthens, solidarity that unites".

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the Commission Work Programme 2016, which is the European Parliament response to the recent State of the Union speech by Commission President Juncker and a list of actions which should be closely followed by the Commission in its Work Programme for 2016. The resolution emphasises the urgent need for a strong Social Agenda, with decent social standards, greater investment in people and serious action to reduce inequalities. In addition, Parliament once again urges the Commission in its resolution to adopt the Commission’s proposals for a better European asylum and migration policy.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Seven political groups (PPE, Verts/ALE, EFDD, ECR, ALDE, S&D, GUE/NGL) tabled a motion for the text of the resolution, four of which (PPE, Verts/ALE, ALDE, S&D) withdrew their own proposals and tabled a joint compromise motion. I voted in favour of this draft.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The ENF Group voted strongly against this work programme, which details the Commission's roadmap for 2016. A number of issues are unacceptable, such as the policy of forced reception of illegal immigrants from the Middle East, imposed on States, or the call for economic governance that further strips States of their sovereignty, among others. In general, this roadmap follows, unsurprisingly, the same slope as in previous years and leads to an ever-increasing federalism at the service of Brussels technocracy and its policies, which have proved to be ineffective in recent decades, both economically and socially.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This text sets out the European Commission's work programme for 2016 and calls, among other things, for the relaunch of the Euro-liberal strategy for Europe 2020 and for the rapid implementation of the report of the five presidents on the federalisation of the euro area, a project that is as utopian as it is harmful. This resolution is adorned with all the virtues of democracy "to meet the most urgent expectations of the citizens" when this Parliament is merely a travesty of democracy without people. I am not sure that the citizens of the countries of the European Union agree to support the competition of states, the policy of welcoming the influx of migrants, the removal of all customs barriers, TTIP, or to encourage the mobility of workers which is only a quasi-forced expatriation etc...  In short, the Commission has no legitimacy to legislate on these issues when one looks at the negative consequences of its choices on the Member States. Finally, challenging the very existence of the European Commission, it is normal for me to oppose this text. So I voted against it.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I support the Commission's proposal to focus on 10 strategic priorities. I voted in favour of this report, which focuses on a better way to legislate and assess the impact of legislative projects, particularly on the economic, social and environmental fronts. The report urges the Commission to present a proposal for the next phase of the Europe 2020 Strategy for Growth and Jobs and to make full use of the European Fund for Strategic Investments. Employment must remain the priority of the Commission's action.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Taxation and competitiveness are two sides of the same coin. In the same way that the practice of corruption and tax evasion arises from the same place. We must put an end to the practice of Member States taxing large companies through covert transactions and, on the other hand, the time for letterbox companies is over. All companies must be taxed in the country in which they operate, and it is time to take tax harmonisation seriously.  The gap between EU tax systems is a huge discrimination against micro, small and medium-sized enterprises. I think it is important for companies not only to take advantage of the single market, but also to move forward and to contribute to their common economic development in the form of tax payments. Furthermore, I stress that, with a harmonised tax system, the whole tax system would be much more transparent and that suspicions of tax fraud or corruption could be detected much sooner.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the Commission's work programme to be a quality document that should target the Commission's efforts in areas that are crucial for the Union. I welcome, for example, the accent on combating tax fraud, tax evasion, aggressive tax planning and the use of tax havens. That is why I supported the programme as a whole. However, I consider some of the proposals to be inappropriate and heading in a direction that does not correspond to the deepening of the free market and the promotion of the competitiveness of countries based on their conditions. And they're different between countries. I did not support that part of the resolution on the Commission's work programme for 2016, which talks about promoting fair labour mobility, which is a fundamental freedom of the single market. I am afraid that this wording may sound like a call into question of labour mobility and conditional on certain restrictions. I also did not support the call for a strong response, inter alia, to the risks of social dumping, because I believe that the term 'social dumping' is often used to combat the competitive advantages of workers from the new Member States and ultimately to restrict the free movement of people and services on the EU market.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported it because it draws attention to the concerns facing the EU and provides guidance for better resolution of them.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is to be welcomed that the Commission has announced 10 strategic priorities for its activities, but it is essential to ensure that the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are always respected in the implementation of its priorities.  In order to create a single market, the Commission should fully exercise its right of initiative. A strategic action plan for economic union, political union and external action should be drawn up. Particular attention should be paid to shifting the tax burden from labour to other forms of sustainable taxation.  In view of the current situation of some Member States, I believe that discussions should be launched on the establishment of a support programme for countries that would express their willingness to negotiate an exit from the euro area because their membership in it has become unsustainable and unbearable.  I believe that greater attention should be paid to social problems. Better coordination of member states' social policies should be ensured and social partners should be involved at European and national level.  Attention should be paid to the European Agenda on Migration drawn up by the Commission, which raises a number of issues and should be revised as soon as possible. I believe that the European Union's migration policy requires a new approach to immigration and refugee problems due to the new circumstances.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the work done by the rapporteur, I thank him and welcome the promised commitment to economic growth and labour, combating illegality in tax matters, digitising the single market and international policies, both trade and diplomatic, with confidence in a more incisive role for the EU worldwide that is truly achievable. More specifically, I am very enthusiastic about the promise of concrete initiatives in the field of health. For these reasons, I have chosen to guarantee my vote in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Nowadays, when the EU is engulfed in the greatest humanitarian crisis and security threats in its existence, it is the Commission's duty to bring its work in line with the current needs of the Union, contributing to the continuation of cohesion and overall improvement of the lives of EU citizens. Therefore, notwith regardless of all the external problems the Union is dealing with, the Focus of the Commission's work must continue to focus on growth and jobs without losing sight of the man himself and his dignity. In support of this resolution, I would like to commend the Commission's efforts so far in agricultural policy and wish that in 2016 the policy of swift and adequate measures in response to the many challenges in this sector continues. Unfortunately, the budgetary constraints of the agricultural budget are known, but the consequences of crises resulting from political decisions need to be addressed with additional funds, as has recently been done in the event of a crisis in the dairy sector. In 2016, I believe that the Commission must come out with proposals to reduce bureaucratic burdens and remove regulatory burdens as a contribution to the simplification of the Common Agricultural Policy. In addition, I expect appropriate initiatives and even legislative proposals to contribute to reducing the scope of UTPs in the food chain, but also improving overall quality of life in rural areas.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support the adopted resolution as a result of protracted negotiations and compromises among political groups in the European Parliament. I am pleased that the views and positions of my political grouping as a valuable contribution to the protection of our citizens have been respected. The Commission's future work programmes need to address key challenges of the 21st century such as climate change, energy independence, resource efficiency, the transition to a digital society, global competition, gender equality, while taking into account the cost of a disunited Europe. I join calls on the Commission, as the EU's main challenge remains regaining citizens' trust, which should be seen as a source of hope and a driver of sustainable growth, job creation and greater social cohesion, to use all its powers to lead the deepening of European integration and set out a programme to improve Europe's economic recovery in a fair and inclusive single market while creating more quality jobs and reducing social inequalities. Today, when the European Union is facing more crises, both within and beyond its borders, coordinated action by all European institutions is of utmost importance. I am therefore pleased that this resolution also expressed its common position to the European Parliament, whose representatives, as the only directly elected citizens, bear particular responsibility in their efforts to overcome existing crises.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the Joint Resolution on the Commission's work programme for 2016. The Europe 2020 strategy remains a solid cornerstone of the European Union's smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, which must respond to key challenges of the 21st century such as global competition, climate change, energy independence, resource efficiency and rising inequality and unemployment. It is necessary to focus funding on political priorities but also on a balanced and above all flexible way that will allow the budget to be adapted to unforeseen circumstances. We are witnessing a series of tragedies caused by the refugee crisis that has hit Europe. We need to be better prepared for these situations and have pre-elaborated strategies. In addition to this migration crisis, the European Union has been grappling with the economic crisis that is causing, including social problems, for some time. With this resolution, the European Parliament encourages the Commission to come up with a strong response to address these problems, notably unemployment, lack of professional workforce, social inequality and exclusion, as well as the risk of brain drain.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am very glad that the resolution on the Commission's work programme, the final proposal of which was pushed by members of the Social Democratic Faction, was adopted today by a large majority of MEPs and strongly supported by all pro-European-minded political groups. The proposal reflects the current challenges facing the EU and also responds to European Commission President Juncker's State of the Union address last week. The European Commission will present its programme in October, and I believe that today's clearly declared priorities of the European Parliament will be reflected in its proposals or serve as the main pillars for the Commission's detailed proposals. Precisely because the Social Democrats were the main force in negotiating the final form of the resolution, the social democrats' priorities are reflected in the main priorities of the resolution. In particular, it concerns the completion of economic and monetary union, the significant updating and implementation of the content and formal lines of communication of the European Strategy 2020, the adoption of permanent functional legislation for managing migration and asylum policy, and last but not least, a significant strengthening of the social dimension in the form of investment in measures to combat the increase in poverty and unemployment, particularly in the areas of public services, childcare and education from an early age to active employment policies.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission must have a work programme capable of responding promptly to the expectations of its citizens. 2016 will be a decisive year in particular for issues related to the common approach to immigration, security and energy independence, job creation and support for SMEs. I hope that the Commission will be able to exercise its right of legislative initiative more strongly in order to give the EU strong and authoritative leadership. I welcome the Commission's desire to focus its work on the ten strategic priorities set out by Mr Juncker.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Although I agree with many of the Commission's proposals for 2016, in particular as regards respect for the principle of subsidiarity, better regulation, the proper implementation of existing legislation, the efficient use of taxpayers' money, the fight against fraud and, finally, the importance of the TTiP, I could not support the motion for a resolution in view of the proposed formula of EU leadership, political union, EU tax policy, the Community method, the social market economy, the Istanbul Convention and the reference to the regulation stipulating the control of legal migration.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution on the Commission's work programme for 2016 as a whole, but I did not vote in favour of some parts of it that could be interpreted as supporting the mechanism of mandatory quotas for the distribution of refugees. In particular, I welcomed the provisions in the work programme, which speak of the need to create European legislation only in areas where it is really necessary, and to revise the legislative proposals already being prepared in this regard. My strong support is also for proposals to significantly reduce the administrative burden and bureaucracy in the EU.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has adopted the joint resolution on the European Commission's work programme for 2016. This document sets out Parliament's priorities and the direction the Commission should take. I voted in favour of this text because it supported, among other things, reviving growth, promoting the competitiveness of SMEs and combating unemployment.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution contains Parliament's recommendations for the preparation of the Commission's Work Programme for 2016. In general terms, Parliament calls on the Commission to present an ambitious work programme that can address the challenges of climate change, energy independence, the transition to a digital society, respect for democratic values and fundamental rights, job creation, growth and investment. Among other priorities, emphasis is the call for the removal of obstacles to the single market, the implementation of the digital single market and the internal energy market, the development of a capital markets union, the strengthening of measures to combat tax fraud and tax evasion, the adoption of a comprehensive approach to migration and asylum and a proposal for the next phase of the Europe 2020 strategy , as well as the plan of measures to be taken to deepen EMU. I voted in favour.

name: Laurenţiu Rebega (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the European Commission's 2016 programme downplays the most important phenomenon currently facing the European Commission, that of the influx of migrants, which is expected to intensify next year. In the light of the new challenges to which the Union is subject, the Commission must also restore the sovereignty of national states with regard to the control of internal borders, as well as asylum policies, in order to cope with the wave of economic immigrants from the Arab area, who are trying to gain refugee status. The European Commission's programme also does not include a package of proposals on tightening and streamlining laws limiting the movement of terrorists by strengthening the external borders of the European Union. Another lack of the European Commission's programme proposal for 2016 is the lack of proposals to improve the framework for combating illicit arms trafficking, illicit trafficking in human beings. Also, the lack of new regulations imposing an effective standard for travel documents, combating the phenomenon of fraudulent use of identity, are arguments that have led me to vote against the Commission's proposal for a work programme for 2016.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this non-legislative and non-binding resolution as it encourages the EU Commission to initiate more wide ranging legislation and wasteful EU spending. It calls for economic and political union and external action, welcomes the Commission agenda on migration, calls for stronger EU control on state aid, calls for more EU control of industrial policy, calls for a mandatory Common Consolidated Corporate Tax base, calls for stronger Economic and Monetary Union, and calls for the EU to join the European Convention of Human Rights (ECHR).  All of this will transfer more power from our elected and accountable national government to unelected bureaucrats in Brussels, as well as wasting more of the UK taxpayer’s money.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported the resolution on the European Commission's work programme for 2016.  The Union faces and must respond to multiple challenges. The European Commission's work programme is decisive in this regard as it will determine the EU's actions for the coming year. We need a clear vision and there is no shortage of work: to start a new dynamic for jobs, growth and investment, to respond responsibly and with dignity to the migration issue, to establish greater integration within the Economic and Monetary Union. We must also manage the transition to the digital society, establish an energy union that respects climate and environmental commitments, create a strong Europe diplomatically, guarantee an area of justice in which European citizens are safe,... All this with, in the background, the need to make political decisions that trump technical considerations. The resolution essentially takes up these priorities, and for that reason I voted in favour.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Serving as a bridge between the left and the right represented in the EP, the Socialist Party played a key role in the adoption of this resolution on those that should be the Commission's priorities for 2016. With the intention of trying to overcome the various crises facing Europe, a number of concrete proposals have been put forward: the total rejection of any attempt to limit the provisions contained in the Schengen Agreement and the adoption of a more efficient European asylum and migration policy, including an urgent relocation system; a European policy that focuss on social investment and combats inequalities, poverty and unemployment through access to quality public services; an ambitious strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth through better implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy; the continuation of the reform of economic and monetary union in order to reduce the economic and social disparities of the countries that make up the euro area.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution on the Commission's Work Programme for 2016 in order to influence the work of the Community Executive.  After the vote was postponed in July, the Socialists have succeeded in including: (1) the introduction of a clear social dimension, which is mentioned in several paragraphs; (2) the introduction of explicit references to the Europe 2020 Strategy for Growth and Job Creation; (3) references to the refugee crisis; (4) the mention of socialist elements linked to China's imposition and financial crisis.  Taken together, the Resolution requires the European Commission to have a common asylum and refugee mechanism adapted to new needs; follow-up to the joint report of the 'five presidents', which calls for the reduction of economic disparities between euro area members; the relaunch of a smart strategy for sustainable and inclusive growth; and new investment with a view to reducing inequalities, unemployment and equal access to social services. This is not our last word, because in December 2015 the European Socialists will return to the content of the programme presented by the Commission.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has welcomed the Commission's migration programme, as indicated by the recommendations on the European Commission's 2016 work programme, in which I voted. The relocation and resettlement of asylum seekers must indeed be priorities. There is a need not only to develop emergency solutions, but also and above all to put in place a long-term sustainable migration policy, including a permanent relocation mechanism to be activated in the event of an emergency.  Other objectives that are all challenges presented in this resolution are the mobility of workers that the Commission must present before the end of the year, a European definition of tax havens based on OECD criteria, an ambitious climate and energy framework for 2030 and, of course, the aid to farmers through new market instruments to anticipate and absorb market shocks. On the other hand, I voted against the amendment on the conclusion of a Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) agreement, since we have not, to date, achieved any appeasement on the evolution of the discussions and the protection of European standards.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the Commission's work programme for 2016, because I strongly believe in the creation of European leadership that favours the establishment of a single market and strong cohesion between the Member States. The work programme that we have voted on is characterised by strategies that promote growth; employment; investment; the fight against fraud and tax evasion; the creation of a digital single market; the development of the copyright sector; the creation of a competitive internal energy market; the improvement and development of transport and infrastructure; the protection of the environment, agriculture and fisheries; efficiency of international trade policies and legislative reinforcement. In addition, the text calls for a fairer monetary and economic union, following a well-coordinated and detailed plan, using a well-defined unitary method. All these objectives are aimed at achieving economic, social and structural growth in the European Union.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the Commission's Work Programme Resolution for 2016. The openly conservative bias of the document is part of the neoliberal logic underlying the Commission's different programmatic movements. At some points, the work programme seems to recognise the effects of precariousness or the forms it takes in the EU, such as youth unemployment or the danger to pensions; but as far as the causes are concerned, the document is unable to locate them in the proposals that guided the previous European Commission. Moreover, the document appears as a roadmap for the liquidation of economic sovereignty, including some presumably positive points such as tax equalisations and the persecution of tax havens, although it is not clearly specified what kind of redistribution can be expected from plausible tax equalisation. We understand that an executive body that is not elected by citizens has to present, in order to legitimize itself as a body, a programme that delves into the problems afflicting an EU that appears to make water, as well as propose social solutions.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission Work Programme 2016 rightly defines as an important objective the elimination of rampant tax evasion and avoidance, as well as aggressive tax planning by multinational corporations. Measures that, in a transparent and consistent manner, seek to attain this goal in the context of a level playing field are desirable. A very serious problem arises, however, when the measures contemplated go beyond the stated objective and prepare the ground for tax harmonisation. This goes against the interest of peripheral regions and islands having limited endowments. When adopting European regulations they have, among others, removed protective trade barriers, adopted consumption taxes that follow continental models, phased out state aid, adopted stringent budgetary rules and abandoned exchange rate autonomy. This has severely curtailed their competitiveness. The only element that remains for them to safeguard this is fair tax competition. The resolution on the Commission Work Programme for 2016 endorses a mandatory common consolidated tax base. In the current circumstances, these proposals amount to a first substantial step towards harmonisation. They are hugely detrimental to the development prospects of islands and regions at the periphery of the Union. I cannot therefore approve of them.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted outright against the Juncker Commission's work programme for 2016 because it represents a clear continuity of the neoliberal and 'austereidal' policies that are causing so much suffering to the European working classes. With this work programme, the Commission is promoting a European Union where market law is imposed on the rights of citizens and workers through deregulation and unlimited competition. REFIT, TTE, financial liberalization, euro reform: these are the Commission's priorities for this period. There's no way I can support them, so I voted against it.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ After much negotiation between my Group, the Socialists and Democrats, and the European People’s Party – as well as with the Liberals and the Greens – the joint motion for a resolution had the backing of over two—thirds of Parliament. With S&D positions involved, this motion for a resolution will be strong on the EU social dimension, a fairer taxation policy, better standards in trade policy and a clear position on the digital revolution and what that means for social standards. Furthermore, along with my Group, I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because it addresses some key concerns regarding the eurozone crisis and looks at creating better regulation and better standards. Particularly important in this report was the inclusion of the holistic approach to migration and asylum, which ‘stresses the need to provide safety for asylum seekers in the process of requesting refugee status and to remove refugees’ need to choose risky routes into the EU.’ It was great that we were able to include so many other political Groups in this joint motion, and we were able to combat the influence of those who care little for democracy and inclusion.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the case of the European Parliament resolution on the Commission work programme for 2016, I voted against this document in line with the EKR's position. Although the proposed programme contains a number of positive initiatives, I could not agree at the same time with serious proposals that are not in line with the condition of subsidiarity, such as the harmonisation of social and migration policies for Member States. I also reject the appeal for the EU's accession to the Istanbul Convention.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Resolution on the Commission Work Programme 2016 in its first part addresses the very important issue of better law-making under the Regulatory Fitness and Performance Programme (REFIT). In this context, it is crucial in the first phase to define meaningfully the legislation that needs to be revised or repealed if it is no longer appropriate or has a lower EU added value, or if it no longer corresponds to its original purpose today. Crucially, however, REFIT should not be used as an excuse to deregulate or lower ambitions in the area of social and environmental standards. The key objective of simplification should be to increase quality, inter alia by improving the impact assessment, not quantity. At the same time, it makes sense to reduce the administrative and administrative burdens and thus the costs associated with the new proposals. Any excessive promotion of deregulation under the pretext of drafting better legislation or reducing the burden can have long-term negative consequences for EU policy objectives, including environmental, social, health and safety standards. By reducing the administrative and administrative burden, we must strive to create quality jobs while preserving existing jobs in Europe, thereby strengthening competitiveness and sustainable growth. As the resolution draws a satisfactory attention to the potential risks of REFIT, I supported it in the vote.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. On 13 September, the four political groups, the EPP, S&D, ALDE and the Greens, tabled a joint motion for a resolution on the European Commission's work programme for 2016. In it, the four political groups describe what they consider to be the European Union's main thematic priorities for the coming year.  The motion for a resolution contains a number of positive demands. This is to use EU funds effectively, prevent mismanagement and improve budgetary control. It also calls for an evaluation of the costly common agricultural policy. It also aims to increase the efficiency of the repatriation of rejected asylum seekers, while at the same time strengthening humanitarian aid and development cooperation.  On the other hand, the motion also contains a number of demands which speak for further centralisation of the EU towards full economic and political union, disregard the principle of subsidiarity – for example, when calling for quotas for women – and reject restrictive measures as part of a holistic policy to deal with the current refugee crisis. This includes, for example, the explicit condemnation of the temporary reintroduction of border controls at internal borders, although this is expressly permitted under the Schengen acquis. Finally, the motion for a resolution contains far too few constructive criticisms of the Commission's work. I have therefore rejected this motion for a resolution.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. I support the resolution and call on the Commission to make full use of its right of initiative. I also expect the Commission to submit a proposal for the next phase of the Europe 2020 strategy for growth and jobs in response to the challenges and opportunities ahead. In the European Year of Development, the Commission needs to deliver visible results in Africa and I call on the Commission to develop and implement a follow-up action plan on the European Humanitarian Aid Consensus to ensure consistency and continued joint implementation of its commitment to the humanitarian principles of humanity, impartiality, neutrality and independence. Balanced trade agreements can serve globalisation to legislate, so I call on the Commission to ensure that European standards are not compromised, and I would stress that trade must play an important role in combating poverty and improving development abroad. I believe that removing barriers to trade and investment globally remains a key priority of the EU's trade strategy. I call on the Commission to focus on combating unjustified protectionist measures. I would like to note the importance of the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP), and I would like to remind the Commission of the importance of cooperation, transparency and information sharing with Parliament throughout the process.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. —The strategies outlined in this report assume a stronger role for the Commission in addressing the difficulties and challenges that await us in the coming years. Better work of the Commission is better work of all other institutions, so I particularly welcome the initiatives presented in this resolution, which underline the importance of facilitating the implementation of adopted legislative measures. Particular emphasis is placed on the Europe 2020 programme. - A strategy for development and employment that must be the basis on which we will build European policies so that challenges in the field of energy and digital sciences do not present us with an insurmountable obstacle.  The programmes and initiatives presented in this report cannot be implemented without adequate financial support, so the report supports the importance of the Commission's financial restructuring as soon as possible, with greater involvement of Member States, so as not to get in the way of projects such as Horizon 2020. - A research and innovation programme that would increase the technological capabilities of the European economy and industry.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this decision, in the hope that, as a result of the compromises reached, the European Parliament could assert its political aspects and expectations for the Commission's activities next year with a strong resolution on the merits and in a number of areas. As a Socialist Member, I attach particular importance to the presentation of social aspects in the implementation of the Commission's entire activities, including its economic crisis management initiatives and tasks; in this regard, I have now found sufficient emphasis on the proposal as a whole. With my vote, I also wanted to contribute to the european Parliament's stable political support for the next period in addressing the challenges of the lack of solidarity in the Member States, in addressing fundamental rights and, more generally, in applying the Community method more effectively. I also consider it important that, as a result of a proper update, the Decision pays due attention to the european legislative, financing and security tasks arising in the short and longer term in dealing with the refugee and migration crisis, both politically and in practice.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Parliament's resolution on the Commission's work programme for 2016 is a comprehensive document outlining the EU's challenges in the near future. It is particularly important to me that, already in the first part of the resolution, Parliament points out the need to achieve the single internal market. On the other hand, both in terms of trade and services, it requires, in my view, a radical improvement by promoting and respecting its principles. Equally important to me is the strong emphasis on the need to support small and medium-sized enterprises, which is a prerequisite for the economic development of the Community. For these reasons, among other things, I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Europe must respond with a clear vision and leadership that shows ambition and courage in the face of the challenges we face, both within the Union and globally. The European Commission's work programme must therefore address these challenges of the 21st century, including climate change, energy independence, resource efficiency, the transition to a digital society, global competition and increasing inequality, and the expectations of our citizens are growing. The current situation of loss of European competitiveness in the global economy, rising unemployment rate, demographic change and ageing population is unprecedented. Our response must be in the form of macroeconomic policies that develop the framework for job creation and the raising of the living standards of European citizens. I am pleased that the Commission's programme is shifting the focus to solidarity and investment and not simply to spending the funds available. My vote is an exhortation to the European Commission, which must come up with a strong response to social problems in the European Union. Economic growth and job creation must be the cornerstone of the European social market economy and the European Union's strategy for sustainable development.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. Nevertheless, I have expressed strong reservations about paragraphs and amendments which, in my opinion, undermine the values of solidarity or the rights of citizens, consumers and workers, in favour of ultraliberalism. I would like to acknowledge the work of the various colleagues in the group who have made this text less bitter.

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour the Commission’s 2016 work programme despite the fact that it omitted mentioning a crucial element, namely the situation of Eston Kohver, the Estonian police officer who was illegally kidnaped from Estonian soil one year ago and was recently sentenced to 15 years imprisonment on trumped-up charges. The European Parliament adopted an urgency resolution on this matter last week in Strasbourg, which is why it is regrettable that this matter was not included in the Commission work programme 2016. This would have given the EU an even stronger mandate to push for the resolution of this issue.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ If it is necessary that the Commission make full use of its right of initiative in order to give the Union a clear direction in 2016, particularly by completing the single market and producing the strategic roadmap for economic union and political union, as well as for external action, I abstain on the final vote of this resolution. Indeed, the draft resolution supports the creation of an obligatory resettlement mechanism which I am opposed to.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ Parliamentary groups EPP, S&D, ALDE and The Greens co-signed a joint resolution on the Commission's 2016 work programme.  The resolution contains a number of aspects that can support, such as the requirement to respect the principle of subsidiarity, better quality legislation, consistent application of existing legislation, more efficient use of taxpayers' money, fight against fraud, and the importance of TTIP agreements. However, with the many aspects that the resolution contains, I must express extreme disagreement. These also includes a requirement to express leadership ambitions at Union level, a call for a political union, a tax policy at Union level, a 'Community' method, an economy focused on the social dimension, and many proposals addressing migration issues.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the motion for a resolution as it touches on important topics such as new incentives for job development, growth and investment. It calls for an ambitious EU industrial policy that will enable the development of new products and the restructuring of industrial processes through innovation. It also promotes the fight against tax fraud, tax evasion, aggressive tax planning and the use of tax havens, which we meet too many times today in the business world. The area of justice and fundamental rights is based on mutual trust in the resolution and proposes an integrated approach to migration and the resolution of asylum claims. At the same time, it touches on the energy union's future-oriented climate change policy.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the Commission's Work Programme Resolution for 2016. The openly conservative bias of the document is part of the neoliberal logic underlying the Commission's different programmatic movements. At some points, the work programme seems to recognise the effects of precariousness or the forms it takes in the EU, such as youth unemployment or the danger to pensions; but as far as the causes are concerned, the document is unable to locate them in the proposals that guided the previous European Commission. Moreover, the document appears as a roadmap for the liquidation of economic sovereignty, including some presumably positive points such as tax equalisations and the persecution of tax havens, although it is not clearly specified what kind of redistribution can be expected from plausible tax equalisation. We understand that an executive body that is not elected by citizens has to present, in order to legitimize itself as a body, a programme that delves into the problems afflicting an EU that appears to make water, as well as propose social solutions.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I could not support the Commission's plans as a whole, although they also contain some positive points, such as reducing administrative burdens.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. On 13 September, the four political groups, the EPP, S&D, ALDE and the Greens, tabled a joint motion for a resolution on the European Commission's work programme for 2016. In it, the four political groups describe what they consider to be the European Union's main thematic priorities for the coming year. The motion for a resolution contains a number of positive demands. This is to use EU funds effectively, prevent mismanagement and improve budgetary control. It also calls for an evaluation of the costly common agricultural policy. It also aims to increase the efficiency of the repatriation of rejected asylum seekers, while at the same time strengthening humanitarian aid and development cooperation.  On the other hand, the motion contains a number of demands for further centralisation of the EU towards full economic and political union, a complete transformation of the monetary union along the lines of the Italian lira, which disregards the principle of subsidiarity – for example, when calling for quotas for women – and reject restrictive measures as part of a holistic policy to deal with the current refugee crisis. This includes, for example, the explicit condemnation of the temporary reintroduction of border controls at internal borders, although this is expressly permitted under the Schengen acquis. I therefore had to reject this path to greater centralisation and socialism.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the Commission's Work Programme Resolution for 2016. The openly conservative bias of the document is part of the neoliberal logic underlying the Commission's different programmatic movements. name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this non-legislative resolution which sets out the European Parliament’s recommendations for the European Commission’s 2016 work programme. The text urges the Commission to show a strong and clear political vision on the most pressing challenges ahead, from energy supply and climate change to job creation, migration, the rule of democracy and fundamental law. Last but not least, the resolution underlines the need to fight tax fraud and evasion and calls for a comprehensive and global approach to the issues of asylum and migration. All in all, the text stresses that European citizens’ most urgent expectations should be at the core of the Commission’s work programme in 2016, while ensuring that democracy and social and environmental standards of living are not compromised.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. By this text, the European Parliament intends to transmit to the Commission a number of specific proposals for its work programme in areas of importance such as boosting employment, growth and investment, the digital single market, energy union, the internal market, economic and monetary union or migration policy. We are therefore talking about a text which, with its proposals, enriches the work programme, so I consider it necessary to vote in favour.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution on the Commission's Work Programme for 2016 in order to influence the work of the Community Executive.  After the vote was postponed in July, the Socialists have succeeded in including: (1) the introduction of a clear social dimension, which is mentioned in several paragraphs; (2) the introduction of explicit references to the Europe 2020 Strategy for Growth and Job Creation; (3) references to the refugee crisis; (4) the mention of socialist elements linked to China's imposition and financial crisis.  Taken together, the Resolution requires the European Commission to have a common asylum and refugee mechanism adapted to new needs; follow-up to the joint report of the 'five presidents', which calls for the reduction of economic disparities between euro area members; the relaunch of a smart strategy for sustainable and inclusive growth; and new investment with a view to reducing inequalities, unemployment and equal access to social services. This is not our last word, because in December 2015 the European Socialists will return to the content of the programme presented by the Commission.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the resolution on the Commission's work programme for 2016, a text that is totally unsatisfactory and inadequate, which renounces the call for a change of course, confining itself to general statements and to endorse policies that have amply demonstrated that they do not work, dragging Europe into an endless crisis. Yet it could have been an important tool to remind the Commission to put the real interests and needs of citizens, the commons and to put finance back at the service of the real economy and society. Instead, this resolution goes in the opposite direction, welcoming unacceptable and risky initiatives such as the capital union, TTIP and the Juncker plan, or pushing for the further strengthening of the current economic governance framework, as well as for the full implementation of unsustainable and absurd budgetary rules. It could not be otherwise, given that this report is the result of yet another unfortunate attempt to find a compromise between the seemingly irreconcilable visions of the main parties of the establishment. For these reasons, although there are a number of points in the text that we can support, including the references to the need to introduce a minimum citizenship income and to make effective use of taxpayers' resources, on which I have fought hard, I could not support this resolution.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt (ECR)
text: Written. The N-VA delegation abstained in the vote on the resolution before us. We can agree on a large number of paragraphs. For example, the N-VA supports the European Commission's ambitions on trade policy, safeguarding and deepening the internal market, the agenda for better regulation, energy and climate policy, and a coherent foreign and security policy. However, the resolution also contains a number of problematic points for the N-VA. For example, we are reluctant to accept a mandatory common corporate tax base, the opening of the multiannual budget, and proposals for more own resources for the EU. Finally, many paragraphs in the resolution show a lack of respect for the fundamental principle of subsidiarity.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted in favour of this resolution. The European Commission came up with an overview of its proposed work in 2016. I voted in favour of the amendments that I consider important, such as calls to reduce administrative and bureaucratic ballast, a balanced and fair tax policy, facilitating job creation and ambitious EU policies on industry and SMEs, combating the use of tax havens, TTIP, launching a defence research policy, etc.

name: Paavo Väyrynen (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 Parliament's position on the Commission's work programme for 2016 contains many good emphasis, including less but better legislative development, promotion of digitisation, favouring SMEs and emphasising European values and human rights. However, the document contains many unacceptable positions. Among other things, it proposes a permanent mandatory burden-sharing of asylum seekers with member states. Nor do I accept the so-for-all. five presidents' proposals for a full economic union in the euro area, nor any other proposals that would lead to a narrowing of the member states' decision-making powers and a strengthening of supranational decision-making. That is why I voted on many points, contrary to my group's position, and in the final vote I supported the rejection of the resolution.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution says everything about the contradictions of this European Union and the crises generated by them. The facts and answers unfortunately show that those responsible for the current situation have not learned a single lesson from the crisis they have created. They do not want to learn the lesson because it is not a mistake but a deliberate political option in the service of capital and the great powers that command in this European Union through the parties that support their interests. For peoples, stagnation, economic recession, unemployment, poverty, social inequalities and growing divergence between Member States continue. And the responses continue with the deepening of neoliberal policies that have generated this whole framework and with more limitations on the sovereignty of peoples and democracy, aiming to take even further the economic dependence and political subordination of countries like Portugal. This neoliberal, federalist and militarist European Union has no future and is now part of the problem and not of the solution. We are for another Europe of peoples, solidarity and respect for the sovereignty of each State and for its right to opt for its own development strategy. Another Europe that must be built on the rubble of this.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. In defiance of the principle of subsidiarity, this report strengthens the Commission's powers. Commission proposals on migration should be enforced quickly and without delay, and border controls at national level and the repeal of the Schengen Agreement are condemned. The banking sector and free trade agreements such as TTIP are highlighted positively. I therefore reject this report.

name: Kristina Winberg (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Amendment 45 to paragraph 82 – Our position regarding the TTIP negotiations is that we reject any agreement which includes an investor-state dispute settlement provision that might enable investor-state claims to inhibit the capacity of the Swedish Government to pass legislation addressing perfectly legitimate public concerns, such as health and environmental protection, labour rights or human rights.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This motion for a resolution stresses that Europe must take on a whole series of key challenges of the 21st century and how the Union must respond to the serious employment and economic crisis, the lack of investment and growth. I could not support this proposal because it runs counter to the resolution tabled by my group, which called, in fact, for less Europe, for the blocking of TTIP, for greater transparency, for more democratic involvement and for a strong criticism of austerity and the single currency. I believe that it is absolutely necessary to change the current approach, giving The Member States the opportunity to implement their fiscal and economic policies without restrictions; we must insist that economic governance move from the austerity policies imposed by the European Union and the euro cage to greater freedom of action for the Member States. Indeed, economic and statistical indicators reveal a dangerous and widespread tendency towards recession in the European Union, a recession certainly due to the economic restrictions imposed at EU level, a trend that absolutely must change, offering the Union the possibility of a new approach.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I hereby close the explanations of vote.
